analyzed: buddha anussatiyāḥ upacāra samādhi niṭṭha ttā vuttam yāva sakala sarīram pharamānaḥ ti  pīti samuṭṭhānehi paṇīta rūpehi sakala sarīram pharamānaḥ dhamma saṅgha guṇe anussarantassa api  yāva sakala sarīram pharamānaḥ pīti sambojjhaṅgaḥ uppajjati iti yojanā evam sesa anussatīsu
translated: “As far as access” is said because the recollection of the Buddha ends in access concentration. “Pervading the whole body” means🔽pervading the whole body with the sublime materiality originated by the happiness. The same method applies to the recollection of the Sangha and the recollection of virtue.🔽“As far as access” means as far as access concentration. “Pervading the whole body” means pervading the whole body with the happiness originated by the recollection of virtue.

original: pasādanīyasuttantapaccavekkhaṇāya ca yojetabbaṃ tassāpi vimuttāyatanabhāvena taggatikattā.
analyzed: pasādanīya suttanta paccavekkhaṇāya ca yojetabbam tassa api vimutta āyatana bhāvena taggatika ttā
translated: The same method applies to the recollection of generosity.🔽“At such a time” means at a time of danger from famine, etc., as stated.

original: Evarūpe kāleti dubbhikkhabhayādīsūti vuttakāle. Samāpattiyā…pe… na samudācarantīti
analyzed: evarūpe kāle iti dubbhikkha bhaya ādīsu uti vutta kāle samāpattiyā āpe na samudācaranti iti
translated: “Does not occur” means does not arise.

original: idaṃ upasamānussatiyā vasena vuttaṃ. Saṅkhārānañhi sappadesavūpasamepi nippadesavūpasame
analyzed: idam upasama anussatiyāḥ vasena vuttam saṅkhārānam hi sappadesa vūpasame api nippadesa vūpasame
translated: This is said with reference to the recollection of peace. For although there is a partial allaying of formations in the attainment of the base of nothingness,🔽it is only in the attainment of the base of neither-perception-nor-non-perception that there is an allaying of formations without remainder.

original: viya tattha sapaññāya pavattanato bhāvanāmanasikāro kilesavikkhambhanasamattho hutvā
analyzed: viya tattha sa paññāya pavattanataḥ bhāvanā manasikāraḥ kilesa vikkhambhana samatthaḥ hutvā
translated: The attention given to development is able to suppress defilements

original: upacārasamādhiṃ āvahanto tathārūpapītisomanassasamannāgato pītisambojjhaṅgassa uppādāya
analyzed: upacāra samādhim āvahantaḥ tathārūpa pīti somanassa samannāgataḥ pīti sambojjhaṅgassa uppādāya
translated: He is possessed of the kind of happiness and rapture that is conducive to access concentration.

original: hotīti. Pasādanīyesu ṭhānesu pasādasinehābhāvena saṃsūcitahadayatā lūkhatā. Sā ca
analyzed: hoti iti pasādanīyesu ṭhānesu pasāda sineha abhāvena saṃsūcita hadaya tā lūkha tā sā ca
translated: It is the hardness of the heart that is indicated by the absence of confidence and affection towards objects that inspire confidence.

original: tattha ādaragāravākaraṇena viññāyatīti āha “asakkaccakiriyāya saṃsūcitalūkhabhāve”ti.🔽Kāyacittadarathavūpasamalakkhaṇā passaddhi eva yathāvuttabodhiaṅgabhūto passaddhisambojjhaṅgo,
analyzed: tattha ādara gārava akaraṇena viññāyati iti āha asakkacca kiriyāya saṃsūcita lūkha bhāvā iti  kāya citta daratha vūpasama lakkhaṇā passaddhi eva yathā vutta bodhi aṅga bhūto passaddhi sambojjhaṅgo
translated: This is known by the fact that one does not show respect and deference.

original: tassa passaddhisambojjhaṅgassa. Paṇītabhojanasevanatāti paṇītasappāyabhojanasevanatā.
analyzed: tassa passaddhi sambojjhaṅgassa paṇīta bhojana sevana tā ati paṇīta sappāya bhojana sevana tā
translated: Tranquillization is the characteristic of the allaying of the tautness of body and mind. The tranquillity enlightenment factor is the tranquillity that is a factor of the path, as described above.🔽By the words “by the use of superior food” is meant the use of superior requisites of medicine.

original: Utuiriyāpathasukhaggahaṇehi sappāyautuiriyāpathaṃ gahitanti daṭṭhabbaṃ. Tañhi tividhampi
analyzed: utu iriyāpatha sukha ggahaṇehi sa ppāya otu iriyāpatham gahitanti daṭṭhabbam tat hi tividham pi
translated: It should be understood that the use of superior climate and posture is included by the words “by the use of superior requisites of medicine,” for these three kinds of superior requisites are the cause of tranquillity in the two ways,

original: sappāyaṃ seviyamānaṃ kāyassa kallatāpādanavasena cittassa kallataṃ āvahantaṃ duvidhāyapi
analyzed: sappāyam seviyamānam kāyassa kalla tā āpādana vasena cittassa kalla tam āvahantam
translated: by arousing the pliability of the mind through the pliability of the body.

original: passaddhiyā kāraṇaṃ hoti. Sattesu labbhamānaṃ sukhadukkhaṃ ahetukanti ayameko anto,
analyzed: passaddhiyāḥ kāraṇam hoti sattesu labbhamānam sukha dukkham ahetukan ti ayam ekaḥ antaḥ
translated: The view that the pleasure and pain of beings are without cause is one extreme.

original: issarādivisamahetukanti ayaṃ dutiyo, ete ubho ante anupagamma yathāsakaṃ kammunā🔽hotīti ayaṃ majjhimā paṭipatti. Majjhatto payogo yassa so majjhattapayogo, tassa
analyzed: issara ādi visama hetukanti ayam dutiyaḥ ete ubho ante an upagamma yathāsakam kammunā  hoti iti ayam majjhimā paṭipatti majjhattaḥ payogaḥ yassa saḥ majjhatta payogaḥ tassa
translated: It is produced by kamma.🔽The state of having the middle way as one’s practice is the middle way as practice.

original: bhāvo majjhattapayogatā. Ayañhi pahānasāraddhakāyatā-saṅkhātapassaddhakāyatāya kāraṇaṃ
analyzed: bhāvaḥ majjhatta payoga tā ayam hi pahāna sāraddha kāya tā saṅkhāta passaddha kāya tāya kāraṇam
translated: For this is the cause of the tranquillization of the body called “the tranquillization of the body by the tranquillization of the defilements.”

original: hontī passaddhidvayaṃ āvahati. Eteneva sāraddhakāyapuggalaparivajjana-passaddhakāyapuggalasevanānaṃ
analyzed: hontī passaddhi dvayam āvahati etena iva sāraddha kāya puggala parivajjana passaddha kāya puggala sevanānam
translated: It brings about the two kinds of tranquillization. And it should be regarded as commending the avoidance of a person whose body is agitated and the cultivation of a person whose body is tranquillized,

original: tadāvahanatā saṃvaṇṇitāti daṭṭhabbaṃ.
analyzed: tad āvahana tā saṃvaṇṇitā iti daṭṭhabbam
translated: since it brings about those two.

original: Vatthuvisadakiriyā indriyasamattapaṭipādanā ca “paññāvahā”ti vuttā. Samathāvahāpi tā honti samathāvahabhāveneva paññāvahattāti vuttaṃ “vatthuvisada…pe… veditabbā”ti.
analyzed: vatthu visada kiriyā indriya samatta paṭipādanā ca paññāvahā ati vuttā samathāvahā api tāḥ honti samathāvaha bhāvena iva paññāvaha ttā ti vuttam vatthu visada pe veditabbā ati
translated: The purification of the object and the balancing of the faculties are called “conducive to wisdom” because they bring about concentration. But they are also conducive to concentration. It is because they bring about concentration that it is said: “The purification of the object and the balancing of the faculties should be understood as conducive to concentration” .

original: Karaṇakosallabhāvanākosallānaṃ nānantariyabhāvato rakkhaṇakosallassa ca taṃmūlakattā
analyzed: karaṇa kosalla bhāvanā kosallānam na ānantariya bhāvataḥ rakkhaṇa kosallassa ca taṃ mūlaka ttā
translated: Because the development of skill in means and skill in components is not interrupted, and because guarding is rooted in that,

original: “nimittakusalatā nāma kasiṇanimittassa uggahaṇakusalatā”icceva vuttaṃ. Atisithilavīriyatādīhīti🔽ādi-saddena paññāpayogamandataṃ appamādavekallañca saṅgaṇhāti. Tassa paggaṇhananti
analyzed: nimitta kusala tā nāma kasiṇa nimittassa uggahaṇa kusala tā iccā iva vuttam ati sithila vīriya tā ādīhi iti  ādi saddena paññā apayoga manda tam appamāda vekallam ca saṅgaṇhāti tassa paggaṇhanam ti
translated: “Skill in the sign” is skill in apprehending the kasiṇa sign.🔽By “and so on” is meant sluggishness of understanding and lack of heedfulness.

original: tassa līnassa cittassa dhammavicayasambojjhaṅgādisamuṭṭhāpanena layāpattito samuṭṭhāpanaṃ.
analyzed: tassa līnassa cittassa dhammavicaya sambojjhaṅga ādi samuṭṭhāpanena laya āpattitaḥ samuṭṭhāpanaṃ
translated: “Its arousing” is its arousing from the state of depression by producing the enlightenment factors beginning with investigation of states.

original: Vuttañhetaṃ bhagavatā –🔽“Yasmiñca kho, bhikkhave, samaye līnaṃ cittaṃ hoti, kālo tasmiṃ samaye dhammavicayasambojjhaṅgassa
analyzed: vuttam ha etam bhagavatā  yasmin ca kho bhikkhave samaye līnam cittam hoti kālo tasmin samaye dhammavicaya sambojjhaṅgassa
translated: For this is said by the Blessed One:

original: bhāvanāya, kālo vīriyasambojjhaṅgassa bhāvanāya, kālo pītisambojjhaṅgassa bhāvanāya.
analyzed: bhāvanāya kālaḥ vīriya sambojjhaṅgassa bhāvanāya kālaḥ pīti sambojjhaṅgassa bhāvanāya
translated: “Bhikkhus, when the mind is depressed, then for the arousing of the unarisen enlightenment factor of investigation of states … for the increase, growth, and fulfilment by development of the arisen enlightenment factor of investigation of states,🔽two things are to be cultivated:

original: Taṃ kissa hetu? Līnaṃ, bhikkhave, cittaṃ, taṃ etehi dhammehi susamuṭṭhāpayaṃ hoti.
analyzed: tat kissa hetu līnam bhikkhave cittam tam etehi dhammehi su samuṭṭhāpayam hoti
translated: For what reason? Because, bhikkhus, the depressed mind is rightly directed by these things.

original: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, puriso parittaṃ aggiṃ ujjāletukāmo assa, so tattha sukkhāni
analyzed: seyyathā api bhikkhave purisaḥ parittam aggim ujjāletu kāmaḥ assa saḥ tattha sukkhāni
translated: Suppose a man wanted to make a small fire burn up, he would put dry grass on it …

original: ceva tiṇāni pakkhipeyya, sukkhāni gomayāni pakkhipeyya, sukkhāni kaṭṭhāni pakkhipeyya,🔽mukhavātañca dadeyya, na ca paṃsukena okireyya, bhabbo nu kho so puriso parittaṃ
analyzed: ca iva tiṇāni pakkhipeyya sukkhāni gomayāni pakkhipeyya sukkhāni kaṭṭhāni pakkhipeyya  mukha vātañca dadeyya na ca paṃsukena okireyya bhabbaḥ nu kho so purisaḥ parittam
translated: and he were to throw dry grass, dry cow-dung, and dry timber into it,

original: aggiṃ ujjāletunti. Evaṃ, bhante”ti.🔽Ettha ca yathāsakaṃ āhāravasena dhammavicayasambojjhaṅgādīnaṃ bhāvanā samuṭṭhāpanāti veditabbā, sā anantaraṃ vibhāvitā eva.
analyzed: aggim ujjāletun ti evam bhanta iti  ettha ca yathāsakam āhāra vasena dhammavicaya sambojjhaṅga ādīnam bhāvanā samuṭṭhāpanā ati veditabbā sā anantaram vibhāvitā eva
translated: and he were to blow on it with his mouth and not scatter soil over it, would that man be able to make a little fire to appear?”—“Yes, venerable sir.”🔽And here the development of the investigation-of-states enlightenment factor, etc., should be understood as the arousing of the respective kinds of nutriment, which has been explained already in the Description of the Factors of Awakening .

original: Accāraddhavīriyatādīhīti ādi-saddena paññāpayogabalavataṃ pamoduppilāvanañca saṅgaṇhāti.
analyzed: acca āraddha vīriya tā ādīhi iti ādi saddena paññā apayoga balavatam pamo duppi lāvanam ca saṅgaṇhāti
translated: “Over-exerted energy, etc.”: the word “etc.” includes over-exerted faith, over-exerted understanding, over-exerted strength, over-exerted confidence, and over-exerted gladness.

original: Tassa niggaṇhananti tassa uddhatassa cittassa samādhisambojjhaṅgādisamuṭṭhāpanena
analyzed: tassa niggaṇhanam ti tassa uddhatassa cittassa samādhi sambojjhaṅga ādi samuṭṭhāpanena
translated: “Suppressing that”: suppressing that excited consciousness by arousing the concentration enlightenment factor, etc.,

original: uddhatāpattito nisedhanaṃ. Vuttampi cetaṃ bhagavatā –
analyzed: uddhata āpattitaḥ nisedhanam vuttam api ca itam bhagavatā
translated: and by preventing the danger of excitement. For this is said by the Blessed One:

original: “Yasmiñca kho, bhikkhave, samaye uddhataṃ cittaṃ hoti, kālo tasmiṃ samaye passaddhisambojjhaṅgassa
analyzed: yasmin ca kho bhikkhave samaye uddhatam cittam hoti kālo tasmin samaye passaddhi sambojjhaṅgassa
translated: “Bhikkhus, when the mind is excited, that is the wrong time to encourage development of the tranquillity enlightenment factor,

original: bhāvanāya, kālo samādhisambojjhaṅgassa bhāvanāya, kālo upekkhāsambojjhaṅgassa bhāvanāya.
analyzed: bhāvanāya kālo samādhi sambojjhaṅgassa bhāvanāya kālo upekkhā sambojjhaṅgassa bhāvanāya
translated: It is time to develop the enlightenment factor of equanimity.

original: Taṃ kissa hetu? Uddhataṃ, bhikkhave, cittaṃ, taṃ etehi dhammehi suvūpasamayaṃ hoti.
analyzed: tat kissa hetu uddhatam bhikkhave cittam tam etehi dhammehi su vūpasamayam hoti
translated: And why is that? Because an excited consciousness is easily calmed by these things.

original: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, puriso mahantaṃ aggikkhandhaṃ nibbāpetukāmo assa, so tattha
analyzed: seyyathā api bhikkhave purisaḥ mahantam aggi kkhandham nibbāpetu kāmaḥ assa saḥ tattha
translated: Suppose a man wanted to extinguish a great mass of fire.

original: allāni ceva tiṇāni….pe… paṃsukena ca okireyya, bhabbo nu kho so puriso mahantaṃ aggikkhandhaṃ
analyzed: allāni ca iva tiṇānipe paṃsukena ca okireyya bhabbaḥ nu kho so purisaḥ mahantam aggi kkhandham
translated: If he threw dry grass, dry cow-dung, and dry timber into it, and scattered sand and soil over it, would that man be able to extinguish that great mass of fire?

original: nibbāpetunti. Evaṃ, bhante”ti.🔽Etthāpi yathāsakaṃ āhāravasena passaddhisambojjhaṅgādīnaṃ bhāvanā samuṭṭhāpanāti🔽veditabbā. Tattha passaddhisambojjhaṅgassa bhāvanā vuttā eva, samādhisambojjhaṅgassa
analyzed: nibbāpetunti evam bhante iti  ettha api yathāsakam āhāra vasena passaddhi sambojjhaṅga ādīnam bhāvanā samuṭṭhāpanā ati  veditabbā tattha passaddhi sambojjhaṅgassa bhāvanā vuttā eva samādhi sambojjhaṅgassa
translated: “Yes, venerable sir.”🔽Herein, the development of the enlightenment factors of tranquillity, concentration, and equanimity should be understood as the arousing of these respectively, according to the method stated in the Paṭisambhidā.🔽Herein, the development of the enlightenment factor of tranquillity has already been stated.

original: vuccamānā, itarassa anantaraṃ vakkhati. Paññāpayogamandatāyāti paññābyāpārassa appabhāvena.
analyzed: vuccamānā itarassa anantaram vakkhati paññā apayoga manda tāya ati paññā byāpārassa appa bhāvena
translated: The development of the enlightenment factor of concentration is stated in the passage: “When he brings to mind and gives attention to the sign of concentration” .🔽The development of the enlightenment factor of equanimity is stated in the passage: “When he brings to mind and gives attention to the sign of equanimity” .🔽The development of the enlightenment factor of equanimity is stated in the passage: “When he brings to mind and gives attention to the sign of equanimity” .🔽The development of the enlightenment factor of equanimity is stated in the passage: “When he brings to mind and gives attention to the sign of equanimity” .

original: Yathā hi dānaṃ alobhappadhānaṃ, sīlaṃ adosappadhānaṃ, evaṃ bhāvanā amohappadhānā.
analyzed: yathā hi dānam a lobha ppadhānam sīlam a dosa ppadhānam evam bhāvanā a moha ppadhānā
translated: Just as giving is the expression of non-greed, and virtue that of non-hate, so this is the expression of non-delusion.

original: Tattha yadā paññā na balavatī hoti, tadā bhāvanā pubbenāparaṃ visesāvahā na hoti,
analyzed: tattha yadā paññā na balavatī hoti tadā bhāvanā pubbena aparam visesa āvahā na hoti
translated: Herein, when understanding is not strong, then the development of meditation does not lead to distinction as it did previously,

original: anabhisaṅkhato viya āhāro purisassa yogino cittassa abhiruciṃ na uppādeti, tena taṃ
analyzed: an abhisaṅkhataḥ viya āhāro purisassa yogino cittassa abhirucim na uppādeti tena tam
translated: and like food that is not properly swallowed it does not give rise to confidence in the mind of the meditator, and so

original: nirassādaṃ hoti. Tathā bhāvanāya sammadeva vīthipaṭipattiyā abhāvena upasamasukhaṃ
analyzed: nirassādam hoti tathā bhāvanāya sammad eva vīthi paṭipattiyāḥ abhāvena upasama sukham
translated: it is without relish. And as there is no proper course of progress in the development, he does not find the bliss of peace,

original: na vindati, tenapi cittaṃ nirassādaṃ hoti. Tena vuttaṃ “paññāpayoga…pe… nirassādaṃ hotī”ti.
analyzed: na vindati tena api cittam nirassādam hoti tena vuttam nirassādam hoti iti
translated: and so the mind is without confidence. Hence it was said above: “The mind is without confidence when understanding is over-used” .

original: Tassa saṃveguppādanañca pasāduppādanañca tikicchananti taṃ dassento “aṭṭha saṃvegavatthūnī”tiādimāha.
analyzed: tassa saṃvega uppādanam ca pasāda uppādanañca tikicchananti tam dassentaḥ aṭṭha saṃvega vatthūni itiādim āha
translated: He should arouse in himself a sense of urgency and confidence. The method for doing this is shown in the following two paragraphs beginning with “Eight grounds for a sense of urgency” .

original: Tattha jātijarābyādhimaraṇāni yathārahaṃ sugatiyaṃ duggatiyañca hontīti tadaññameva
analyzed: tattha jāti jarā byādhi maraṇāni yathāraham sugatiyam duggatiyam ca honti iti tad aññam eva
translated: Herein, birth, ageing, disease, and death are respectively the first, second, third, and fourth grounds for a sense of urgency in the case of a good destiny, and in the case of a bad destiny they are respectively the fifth, sixth, seventh, and eighth grounds for a sense of urgency.

original: pañcavidhabandhanādikhuppipāsādiaññamaññavibādhanādihetukaṃ apāyadukkhaṃ daṭṭhabbaṃ.
analyzed: pañcavidha bandhana ādi khuppipāsā ādi aññamañña vibādhana ādi hetukam apāya dukkham daṭṭhabbaṃ
translated: The suffering of the states of loss should be regarded as having as its cause the five kinds of bonds, etc., and mutual enmity, etc., as its condition.

original: Tayidaṃ sabbaṃ tesaṃ tesaṃ sattānaṃ paccuppannabhavanissitaṃ gahitanti atīte anāgate🔽ca kāle vaṭṭamūlakadukkhāni visuṃ gahitāniyeva. Ye pana sattā āhārūpajīvino tattha
analyzed: tayā idam sabbam tesam tesam sattānam paccuppanna bhava nissitam gahitam ti atīte anāgate  ca kāle vaṭṭa mūlaka dukkhāni visum ye pana sattāḥ āhāra upajīvino tattha
translated: All this is included in the suffering of the present life of the various beings. But in the past and in the future🔽the suffering of the round is included separately. But the suffering of livelihood that is not shared by others,

original: ca uṭṭhānaphalūpajīvino, tesaṃ aññehi asādhāraṇaṃ jīvikadukkhaṃ aṭṭhamaṃ saṃvegavatthu
analyzed: ca uṭṭhāna phala upajīvino tesam aññehi asādhāraṇam jīvika dukkham aṭṭhamam saṃvega vatthu
translated: which is the eighth ground for the arousal of zeal, should be regarded as included in the case of those beings who live by food and who live by the fruits of their exertions.

original: gahitanti daṭṭhabbaṃ. Ayaṃ vuccati samaye sampahaṃsanāti ayaṃ sampahaṃsitabbasamaye
analyzed: gahitanti daṭṭhabbam ayam vuccati samaye sampahaṃsanā ati ayam sampahaṃsitabba samaye
translated: This is called “cheering at the proper time”: at the proper time for cheering, in other words, at the time for arousing zeal,

original: vuttanayena saṃvegajananavasena ceva pasāduppādanavasena ca sammadeva pahaṃsanā,
analyzed: vutta nayena saṃvega janana vasena ca iva pasāda uppādana vasena ca sammad eva pahaṃsanā
translated: he cheers properly, that is, he arouses zeal by arousing a sense of urgency and by arousing confidence,

original: saṃvegajananapubbakapasāduppādanena bhāvanācittassa tosanātiattho.
analyzed: saṃvega janana pubbaka pasāda uppādanena bhāvanā cittassa tosana ati attho
translated: the meaning is, he satisfies the mind of development by arousing confidence preceded by arousing a sense of urgency.

original: Sammāpaṭipattiṃ āgammāti līnuddhaccavirahena samathavīthipaṭipattiyā ca sammadeva bhāvanāpaṭipattiṃ āgamma.
analyzed: sammā paṭipattim āgamma ati līn uddhacca virahena samatha vīthi paṭipattiyā ca sammat eva bhāvanā paṭipattim āgamma
translated: Having come to right practice: having come to right practice of development by arousing a sense of urgency and by the practice of the middle way free from sluggishness and restlessness.

original: Alīnantiādīsu kosajjapakkhikānaṃ dhammānaṃ anadhimattatāya alīnaṃ, uddhaccapakkhikānaṃ
analyzed: alīna nti ādīsu kosajja pakkhikānam dhammānam anadhimatta tāya alīnam uddhacca pakkhikānam
translated: Not sluggish: not having much sluggishness due to states on the side of sloth. Not restless: not having much restlessness due to states on the side of restlessness.

original: anadhimattatāya anuddhataṃ, paññāpayogasampattiyā upasamasukhādhigamena ca anirassādaṃ,🔽tato eva ārammaṇe samappavattaṃ samathavīthipaṭipannañca. Tattha alīnatāya paggahe,
analyzed: an adhimatta tāya an uddhatam paññā apayoga sampattiyā upasama sukha adhigamena ca a nirassādam  tatas eva ārammaṇe sama pavattam samatha vīthi paṭipannam ca tattha alīna tāya paggahe
translated: It is not sluggish because it is not dull. It is not dispirited because it is not disinclined to the attainment of the bliss of serenity through the excellence of its means of knowledge.🔽And it is not distracted because it occurs evenly in the object and is entered upon in the path of serenity. Herein, it does not become occupied with exertion because it is not sluggish.

original: anuddhatāya ca niggahe, anirassādatāya sampahaṃsane na byāpāraṃ āpajjati. Alīnānuddhaccatāhi🔽ārammaṇe samappavattaṃ, anirassādatāya samathavīthipaṭipannaṃ, samappavattiyā vā
analyzed: an uddhatāya ca niggahe a nirassāda tāya sampahaṃsane na byāpāram āpajjati alīna an uddhacca tāhi  ārammaṇe sama pavattam a nirassāda tāya samatha vīthi paṭipannam sama ppavattiyā vā
translated: It does not become occupied with restraining because it is not excited. It does not become occupied with encouraging because it is not dispirited.🔽And because it is not sluggish and not excited,

original: alīnaṃ anuddhataṃ, samathavīthipaṭipattiyā anirassādanti daṭṭhabbaṃ. Ayaṃ vuccati
analyzed: a līnam an uddhatam samatha vīthi paṭipattiyā a nirassādanti daṭṭhabbam ayam vuccati
translated: it occurs evenly in the object. And because it is not dispirited, it is entered upon in the path of serenity. Or alternatively, it is not sluggish because it occurs evenly in the object. It is not excited because it is entered upon in the path of serenity. And it is not dispirited because it occurs evenly in the object and is entered upon in the path of serenity. This is called

original: samaye ajjhupekkhanatāti ayaṃ ajjhupekkhitabbasamaye cittassa paggahaniggahasampahaṃsanesu
analyzed: samaye ajjhupekkhanatā ati ayam ajjhupekkhitabba samaye cittassa paggaha niggaha sampahaṃsanesu
translated: equanimity as right predominance of the mind at the time of right predominance of the mind.

original: byāvaṭatāsaṅkhātaṃ paṭipakkhaṃ abhibhuyya upekkhanā vuccati. Esāti samādhibojjhaṅgo
analyzed: byāvaṭa tā saṅkhātam paṭipakkham abhibhuyya upekkhanā vuccati esā ati samādhi bojjhaṅgo
translated: This is said to be equanimity as the overcoming of opposing qualities called “occupation” in the exertion, restraining, and encouraging of cognizance at the time of right predominance of the mind. This is the concentration enlightenment factor.

original: anuppanno uppajjati. Arahattamaggena bhāvanāpāripūrī hotīti etena nippariyāyato samādhivepullappattopi
analyzed: anuppannaḥ uppajjati arahatta maggena bhāvanā pāripūrī hoti iti etena nippariyāyataḥ samādhi vepulla ppattaḥ api
translated: and when it has arisen, it is fulfilled by the Arahant Path.🔽By this he shows the fulfilment of concentration in the ultimate sense.

original: arahā evāti dasseti.
analyzed: arahāḥ eva ati dassa iti
translated: and when it has not arisen, it arises. And by the words “perfection of development comes about through the Arahant path” he shows that the Arahant has reached the fullness of concentration in the absolute sense.

original: Anurodhavirodhapahānavasena majjhattabhāvo upekkhāsambojjhaṅgassa kāraṇaṃ tasmiṃ
analyzed: anurodha virodha pahāna vasena majjhatta bhāvaḥ upekkhā sambojjhaṅgassa kāraṇam tasmin
translated: The equanimity enlightenment factor has as its cause the state of neutrality which is the abandoning of approval and resistance.

original: sati sijjhanato, asati ca asijjhanato, so ca majjhattabhāvo visayavasena duvidhoti🔽āha “sattamajjhattatā saṅkhāramajjhattatā”ti. Tadubhayavasena cassa virujjhanaṃ passaddhisambojjhaṅgassa
analyzed: sati sijjhanato asati ca so ca majjhatta bhāvaḥ visaya vasena duvidhā ti  āha satta majjhatta tā saṅkhāra majjhatta tā ti tad ubhaya vasena ca ssa virujjhanam passaddhi sambojjhaṅgassa
translated: For it succeeds when that exists and fails when it does not. And that neutrality is twofold according to the object,🔽so he said “neutrality towards creatures, neutrality towards ideas.” And its non-occurrence is due to the development of the tranquillity enlightenment factor,

original: bhāvanāya eva dūrīkatanti anurujjhanasseva pahānavidhiṃ dassento “sattamajjhattatā”tiādimāha.
analyzed: bhāvanāya eva dūrīkatanti anurujjhanassa iva pahāna vidhim dassentaḥ satta majjhatta tā ati ādim āha
translated: which is why he said “neutrality towards creatures” and so on, showing the way to abandon occurrence.

original: Tathā hissa sattasaṅkhārakelāyanapuggalaparivajjanaṃ “uppattiyā kāraṇa”nti vuccati.
analyzed: tathā hi ssa satta saṅkhāra kelāyana puggala parivajjanam uppattiyāḥ kāraṇan ti vuccati
translated: For the avoiding of the person who indulges in the seven kinds of talk is called “the cause of its arising.”

original: Upekkhāya hi visesato rāgo paṭipakkho, tato rāgabahulassa puggalassa upekkhā “visuddhimaggo”ti
analyzed: upekkhāya hi visesataḥ rāgaḥ paṭipakkhaḥ tatas rāga bahulassa puggalassa upekkhā visuddhi maggo ti
translated: For greed is the opposite of equanimity, and equanimity is the “path to purity” for a person in whom greed abounds.

original: vuccati. Dvīhākārehīti kammassakatāpaccavekkhaṇaṃ attasuññatāpaccavekkhaṇanti imehi
analyzed: vuccati dvīhākārehi iti kammassaka tā paccavekkhaṇam atta suñña tā paccavekkhaṇam ti imehi
translated: is said. By two modes: by the mode of reflecting on the fact that kamma is one’s own, and by the mode of reflecting on the voidness of self.

original: dvīhi kāraṇehi. Dvīhevāti avadhāraṇaṃ saṅkhārasahitāya saṅkhyāsamānatāya dassanatthaṃ.
analyzed: dvīhi kāraṇehi dvīhā iva ati avadhāraṇam saṅkhāra sahitāya saṅkhyā samāna tāya dassana attham
translated: By two: this is a restrictive particle. It is stated in order to show that the number is the same as the number of formations together with the self.

original: Saṅkhyā eva hettha samānaṃ, na saṅkhyeyyaṃ sabbathā samānanti. Assāmikabhāvo anattaniyatā.
analyzed: saṅkhyā eva ha ittha samānam na saṅkhyeyyam sabbathā samānanti a ssāmika bhāvaḥ an atta niyatā
translated: The number is the same here, not the things that are numbered, in every way. The state of having no owner is the non-determination of self.

original: Sati hi attani tassa kiñcanabhāvena cīvaraṃ aññaṃ vā kiñci attaniyaṃ nāma siyā, so🔽pana koci natthevāti adhippāyo. Anaddhaniyanti, na addhānakkhamaṃ, na ciraṭṭhāyi
analyzed: sati hi attani tassa kiñcana bhāvena cīvaram aññam vā kiñci attaniyam nāma siyā so  pana koci nattha iva ati adhippāyaḥ an addha niyanti na addhāna khamam na cira ṭṭhāyi
translated: For if there were a self, then the robe, or something else, would be called one’s own, as something belonging to it. But there is no such thing at all. This is the meaning. Not determined by the life-continuum: not enduring as long as the life-continuum, not lasting long,

original: ittaraṃ aniccanti attho. Tāvakālikanti tasseva vevacanaṃ.
analyzed: ittaram aniccanti attho tāvakālikanti tassa iva vevacanam
translated: not permanent. This is the meaning. For a time only: this is a synonym for the same.

original: Mamāyatīti mamattaṃ karoti. Mamāti taṇhāya pariggayha tiṭṭhati. Dhanāyantāti dhanaṃ🔽dabbaṃ karontā. Assāti upekkhāsambojjhaṅgassa arahattamaggena bhāvanāpāripūrī hoti.🔽Tathā hi arahato eva chaḷaṅgupekkhānipphatti.
analyzed: mamāyati iti mamattam karoti mama ati taṇhāya pariggayha tiṭṭhati dhanāyanta iti dhanam 🔽dabbam karontā assa ati upekkhā sambojjhaṅgassa arahatta maggena bhāvanā pāripūrī hoti 🔽tathā hi arahataḥ eva chaḷaṅgu pekkhā nipphatti

original: Asubhārammaṇā dhammāti asubhappakārā asubhajhānassa ārammaṇabhūtā dhammā. Kāmaṃ indriyabaddhāpi
analyzed: asubha ārammaṇāḥ dhammā ati asubha ppakārāḥ asubha jhānassa ārammaṇa bhūtāḥ dhammāḥ kāmam indriya baddhā api
translated: “Things that are the object of foulness”: things that are a state of foulness, that are the object of foulness jhāna. Of course, the head hairs, etc., are bound up with faculties,

original: kesādayo asubhappakārā eva, visesato pana jigucchitabbe jigucchāvahe gaṇhanto “dasā”ti
analyzed: kesa ādayaḥ asubha ppakārāḥ eva visesataḥ pana jigucchitabbe jigucchāvahe gaṇhantaḥ dasāti
translated: but he said “ten” in order to include only what is specifically disgusting and causes disgust.

original: āha. Yathā manasikaroto sabhāvasarasato tattha asubhasaññā santiṭṭhati, tathā pavatto🔽manasikāro upāyamanasikāro. Asubhe asubhapaṭikkūlākārassa uggaṇhanaṃ, yathā vā tattha🔽uggahanimittaṃ uppajjati, tathā manasikāro asubhanimittassa uggaho. Upacārappanāvahāya
analyzed: āha yathā manasikaroto tattha asubha saññā santiṭṭhati tathā pavatto  manasikāraḥ upāya manasikāraḥ asubhe asubha paṭikkūla ākārassa uggaṇhanam yathā vā tattha  uggaha nimittam uppajjati tathā manasikāraḥ asubha nimittassa uggahaḥ upacāra ppanā vahāya
translated: The attention given to them in such a way that the perception of foulness becomes settled in them by its own nature is “attention given to the method.”🔽The learning of the aspect of contemplation of foulness in foulness is “apprehending the sign of foulness.” The attention given in such a way that the learning sign arises is “apprehending the sign of foulness.”

original: asubhabhāvanāya anuyuñjanā asubhabhāvanānuyogo.
analyzed: asubha bhāvanāya anuyuñjanāḥ asubha bhāvanā anuyogaḥ
translated: The practice of the development of foulness meditation, which is the means to the abandoning of the hindrances, is “application to the development of foulness.”

original: Manacchaṭṭhānaṃ indriyānaṃ suṭṭhu susaṃvaraṇe sati avasaraṃ alabhanto kāmacchando
analyzed: suṭṭhu su saṃvaraṇe sati avasaram kāmacchandaḥ
translated: When the six bases beginning with the eye are well restrained by the restraint of the faculties, sensual desire is abandoned because it gets no opportunity.

original: pahīyateva, tathā bhojane mattaññuno mitāhārassa thinamiddhābhibhavābhāvā otāraṃ
analyzed: pahīyate iva tathā bhojane mattaññunaḥ mita āhārassa thinamiddha abhibhava abhāvāḥ otāram
translated: Likewise, when one is moderate in eating and has few wants, sensual desire is abandoned because it gets no opportunity owing to the absence of the over- powering of sloth and torpor.

original: alabhamāno kāmacchando pahīyati. Yo pana āhāre paṭikkūlasaññaṃ tabbipariṇāmassa tadādhārassa
analyzed: a labhamāno kāmacchandaḥ pahīyati yaḥ pana āhāre paṭikkūla saññam tad vipariṇāmassa tad ādhārassa
translated: If he cannot get them, sensual desire is abandoned in him. But when he has the perception of the repulsiveness of food in regard to that and to what is its condition,

original: tassa ca udariyabhūtassa ativiya jegucchataṃ, kāyassa ca āhāratiṭṭhakataṃ sammadeva
analyzed: tassa ca udariya bhūtassa jeguccha tam kāyassa ca āhāra tiṭṭhaka tam sammadeva
translated: and he has great loathing for what is in the belly and for the body as the vessel for what is eaten, and he understands clearly how the body is sustained by nutriment,

original: jānāti, so sabbaso bhojane pamāṇassa jānanena visesato bhojane mattaññū nāma. Tassa
analyzed: jānāti saḥ sabbasas bhojane pamāṇassa jānanena visesataḥ bhojane mattaññū nāma tassa
translated: then he is called one who has moderation in eating in the sense of knowing the right measure in nutriment in all its aspects.

original: kāmacchando pahīyateva, aṭṭhakathāyaṃ pana appāhārataṃyeva dassetuṃ “catunna”ntiādi
analyzed: kāmacchandaḥ pahīyateva aṭṭhakathā ayam pana dassetum catunna nti ādi
translated: Sensual desire is abandoned in him. But in the commentary the words “of the four” are said

original: vuttaṃ. Asubhakammikatissatthero dantaṭṭhidassāvī. Pahīnassāti vikkhambhanavasena🔽pahīnassa. Abhidhammapariyāyena sabbopi lobho kāmacchandanīvaraṇanti “arahattamaggena
analyzed: vuttam asubha kammika tissa theraḥ danta ṭṭhi dassāvī pahīnassa ti vikkhambhana vasena  pahīnassa abhidhammapariyāyena sabbaḥ api lobho kāma chanda nīvaraṇanti arahatta maggena
translated: in order to show that he eats little. The Elder Tissa, the maker of the Subha meditation subject, was a tamer of the belly.🔽“Abandoned”: abandoned by suppression.🔽According to the Abhidhamma all greed is the hindrance of sensual desire.

original: āyatiṃ anuppādo”ti vuttaṃ.
analyzed: āyatim anuppādaḥ ti vuttam
translated: “Non-arising in the future”: this is said of the greed abandoned by the path of arahatship.

original: Mejjati hitapharaṇavasena siniyhatīti mitto, hitesī puggalo, tasmiṃ mitte bhavā,
analyzed: mejjati hita pharaṇa vasena siniyhati iti mittaḥ hita īsī puggalo tasmin mitte
translated: A friend is one who is friendly through sharing what is beneficial. He is a person who is helpful. The state of being a friend is

original: mittassa vā esāti mettā, hitesitā. Sā eva paṭipakkhato cetaso vimuttīti mettācetovimutti.🔽Tattha mettāyanassa sattesu hitapharaṇassa uppādanaṃ pavattanaṃ mettānimittassa uggaho.
analyzed: mittassa vai esā ati mettā hita isitā sā eva paṭipakkhataḥ cetasaḥ vimutti iti mettā cetas vimutti  tattha mettāyanassa sattesu hita pharaṇassa uppādanam pavattanam mettā nimittassa uggahaḥ
translated: Or it is loving-kindness because it is loving-kindness towards a friend, that is to say, the wish for his welfare. It is the deliverance of mind through loving-kindness because it is the mind’s deliverance by way of its opposite.🔽Herein, the arousing and occurrence of loving-kindness towards beings is the apprehending of the sign of loving-kindness.

original: Tenāha “odissakā”tiādi.🔽Tattha attapiyasahāyamajjhattaverivasena odissakatā. Sīmāsambhede kate anodissakatā.🔽Ekādidisāpharaṇavasena disāpharaṇatā mettāya uggaṇhane veditabbā. Uggaho yāva upacārā
analyzed: tena āha odissaka ati ādi  tattha atta piya sahāya majjhatta veri vasena odissaka tā sīmā sambhede kate anodissaka tā  eka ādi disāpharaṇa vasena disāpharaṇa tā mettāya uggaṇhane veditabbā uggahaḥ yāvaḥ upacārā
translated: Hence it is said: “The apprehending of the sign of loving-kindness should be understood as the arousing of loving-kindness towards beings classed as dear ones, and so on” .

original: daṭṭhabbo. Uggahitāya āsevanā bhāvanā, sabbā itthiyo purisā ariyā anariyā devā manussā🔽vinipātikāti sattodhikaraṇavasena pavattā sattavidhā, aṭṭhavīsatividhā vā, dasahi
analyzed: daṭṭhabbaḥ uggahitāya āsevanā bhāvanā sabbā itthiyaḥ purisāḥ ariyāḥ anariyāḥ devāḥ manussā  vinipātikā ati satta udhikaraṇa vasena pavattā sattavidhā aṭṭhavīsatividhā vā dasahi
translated: Herein, the classing as dear ones, and so on, is the classing as dear ones, friends, neutrals, and enemies. The classing as “not-a-person” is the classing as non-human beings. The classing as “direction” is the classing as beings in the directions. The classing as “quadruped” is the classing as the four-footed animals beginning with the cow. The classing as “bird” is the classing as the birds beginning with the fowl. The classing as “tree” is the classing as the trees beginning with the Nā species. The classing as “abode” is the classing as the abodes beginning with the village. The classing as “person” is the classing as the persons beginning with oneself. The classing as “all beings” is the classing as all beings in the ten-thousandfold world-element, and so on. The classing as “all” is the classing as all beings in the ten-thousandfold world-element, and so on, without making any such distinctions as “woman, man, animal, etc.” The classing as “quadruped” and the rest are only mentioned here in order to show that they are included in the classing as “all beings.”

original: disāhi disodhikaraṇavasena pavattā dasavidhā, ekekāya disāya sattādiitthādiaverādibhedena
analyzed: dasavidhā ekekāya disāya
translated: The classing as “all beings” should be understood as the classing as all beings in the ten-thousandfold world-element, and so on, in the following ways: as “all women,” “all men,” “all Noble Ones,” “all not Noble Ones,” “all gods,” “all human beings,” “all those in states of loss,” making nine classes in all; or as the twenty-eight classes consisting of the nine classes of women, the nine classes of men, and the twelve classes of Noble Ones; or as the ten classes consisting

original: asītādhikacatusatappabhedā ca odhisopharaṇamettā. Sabbe sattā, pāṇā, bhūtā, puggalā,
analyzed: ca sabbe sattā pāṇā bhūtā puggalā
translated: And this loving-kindness is of two kinds, namely, limited and measureless. It is of five kinds according to the way in which it is undertaken thus: “May all beings be free from enmity, vexation and affliction, and live happily. May all breathing things … all who are born … all persons … all those who have a personality be free from enmity, vexation and affliction, and live happily.”

original: attabhāvapariyāpannāti etesaṃ vasena pañcavidhā. Ekekasmiṃ averā hontu, abyāpajjā,
analyzed: etesam vasena pañcavidhāḥ ekekasmin averāḥ hontu a byāpajjā
translated: It is of twenty kinds according to the fourfold occurrence of each of these five kinds.

original: anīghā, sukhī attānaṃ pariharantūti catudhā pavattiyā vīsatividhā anodhisopharaṇamettā,
analyzed: anīghā sukhī attānam pariharantu uti catudhā pavattiyā vīsatividhā
translated: This is called “limited loving-kindness” .

original: taṃ sandhāyāha – “odhiso…pe… bhāventassapī”ti. Tvaṃ etassātiādinā kammassakatāpaccavekkhaṇaṃ🔽dasseti. Paṭisaṅkhāne ṭhitassāti kodhe yathāvuttassa ādīnavassa tappaṭipakkhato akodhe🔽mettāya ānisaṃsassa ca paṭisaṅkhāne sammadeva jānane. Sevantassāti bhajantassa byāpādo pahīyati.
analyzed: tam sandhāya āha bhāventassa api iti tvam etassa ati ādinā kammassaka tā paccavekkhaṇam  dassa iti paṭisaṅkhāne ṭhitassa ati kodhe yathā vuttassa ādīnavassa tad paṭipakkhataḥ a kodhe  mettāya ānisaṃsassa ca paṭisaṅkhāne sammad eva jānane sevantassa ati bhajantassa byāpādaḥ pahīyati
translated: The words “and when he cultivates that meditation subject in this way” refer to the development of the meditation subject in the way already described.🔽The words “when he is normally mindful” mean when he is normally mindful of the danger in anger and so on, and of the benefit in patience and so on, as described under the recollection of the Buddha, and when he is normally mindful of the advantages of loving-kindness, compassion, and so on.🔽The words “when he normally resorts to loving-kindness” mean when he normally resorts to the meditation that has loving-kindness as its object.🔽The words “when he normally gives attention to it” mean when he normally gives attention to the meditation subject in the way described.

original: Atibhojane nimittaggāhoti āhārassa adhikabhojane thinamiddhassa nimittaggāho, “ettake
analyzed: ati bhojane nimitta ggāho ti āhārassa adhika bhojane thinamiddhassa nimitta ggāho ettake
translated: The words “when he normally masters it” mean when he normally masters the meditation subject in the way described.🔽The words “when he normally develops it” mean when he normally develops the meditation subject in the way described.🔽The words “when he normally cultivates it” mean when he normally cultivates the meditation subject in the way described.🔽The words “when he normally frequents it” mean when he normally frequents the meditation subject in the way described.🔽The words “when he normally persists in it” mean when he normally persists in the meditation subject in the way described.🔽The words “when he normally devotes himself to it” mean when he normally devotes himself to the meditation subject in the way described.🔽The words “when he normally serves it” mean when he normally serves the meditation subject in the way described.🔽The words “when he normally honours it” mean when he normally honours the meditation subject in the way described.🔽The words “when he normally reveres it” mean when he normally reveres the meditation subject in the way described.🔽The words “when he normally venerates it” mean when he normally venerates the meditation subject in the way described.🔽The words

original: bhutte thinamiddhaṃ uppajjati, ettake no”ti thinamiddhassa kāraṇākāraṇaggāhoti attho.
analyzed: bhutte thinamiddham uppajjati ettake no ti thinamiddhassa kāraṇa akāraṇa ggāhaḥ ti attho
translated: and after eating, drowsiness and sleep arise. Is it only this much? ” is the meaning.

original: Divā sūriyālokanti divā gahitanimittaṃ sūriyālokaṃ, rattiyaṃ manasikarontassapīti
analyzed: divā sūriya ālokanti divā gahita nimittam sūriya ālokam rattiyam manasikarontassa api iti
translated: The light of the sun by day: the light of the sun is the sign apprehended by day.🔽The meaning should be understood in this way.

original: evamettha attho veditabbo. Dhutaṅgānaṃ vīriyanissitattā vuttaṃ “dhutaṅganissitasappāyakathāyapī”ti.
analyzed: evam ettha atthaḥ veditabbaḥ dhutaṅgānam vīriya nissita ttā vuttam dhutaṅga nissita sappāya kathāya api iti
translated: Since the ascetic practices are dependent on energy, it is said: “in the right reflection dependent on the ascetic practices.”

original: Kukkuccampi katākatānusocanavasena pavattamānaṃ cetaso avūpasamāvahatāya uddhaccena
analyzed: kukkuccam pi kata a kata anusocana vasena pavattamānam cetasaḥ uddhaccena
translated: Anxiety also occurs as a mental unrest due to the worry about what has been done and what has not been done. It is similar to agitation in its characteristic of mental unrest.

original: samānalakkhaṇamevāti tadubhayassa pahānakāraṇaṃ dassento bhagavā – “atthi, bhikkhave,🔽cetaso vūpasamo”tiādimāha. Tasmā bāhusaccādi tassa pahānakāraṇanti dassetuṃ “apica
analyzed: samāna lakkhaṇam eva ati tad ubhayassa pahāna kāraṇam dassentaḥ bhagavā atthi bhikkhave  cetasaḥ vūpasamaḥ ti ādim āha tasmā bāhu sacca ādi tassa pahāna kāraṇan ti dassetum api ca
translated: Therefore, the Exalted One, in order to show the cause for the abandoning of both, says: “Monks, there is the calming of the mind.🔽” Therefore, in order to show that the cause for the abandoning of anxiety is learning much, etc., he says: “Moreover, six things.

original: cha dhammā”tiādimāha. Tattha bahussutassa ganthato, atthato dhammaṃ vicārentassa
analyzed: cha dhammā ti ādim āha tattha bahu ssutassa ganthataḥ atthataḥ dhammam vicārentassa
translated: ” Herein, for one who is learned, who reflects on the text and the meaning of the Dhamma,

original: attavedādipaṭilābhasambhavato vikkhepo na hoti. Yathāvihitapaṭipattiyā yathādhammapaṭikārappattiyā🔽ca vippaṭisāro anavasarovāti “bāhusaccenapi…pe… uddhaccakukkuccaṃ pahīyatī”ti vuttaṃ.🔽Yadaggena bahussutassa paṭisaṅkhānavato uddhaccakukkuccaṃ pahīyati, tadaggena paripucchakatāvinayapakataññutāhipi
analyzed: atta veda ādi paṭilābha sambhavataḥ vikkhepaḥ na hoti yathā vihita paṭipattiyā yathā dhamma paṭikāra ppattiyā  ca vippaṭisāraḥ anavasarā uvāti uddhacca kukkuccam pahīyati iti vuttam  yad aggena bahu ssutassa paṭisaṅkhānavataḥ uddhacca kukkuccam pahīyati tad aggena
translated: And there is no remorse because of the attainment of the right state in accordance with the right practice.🔽“Even with great learning, etc., restlessness and remorse are abandoned” is said.🔽It should be seen that just as restlessness and remorse are abandoned in one who is learned, reflective, and mindful, so too they are abandoned in one who is skilled in the questions of the Discipline, skilled in the analysis of the Monastic Law, and skilled in the methods of settling legal issues.

original: taṃ pahīyatīti daṭṭhabbaṃ. Vuddhasevitā ca vuddhasīlitaṃ āvahatīti cetaso vūpasamakarattā🔽uddhaccakukkuccassa pahānakārī vuttā, vuddhabhāvaṃ pana anapekkhitvā vinayadharā
analyzed: tam pahīyati iti daṭṭhabbam vuddha sevitā ca vuddha sīlitam āvahati iti cetasaḥ vūpasama karattā  uddhacca kukkuccassa pahāna kārī vuttā vuddha bhāvam pana an apekkhitvā vinaya dharā
translated: And because of the peacefulness of mind that comes from associating with the elders,🔽the elders’ virtue is said to be the remover of restlessness and remorse. But without regard to the state of being an elder, those who are skilled in the Monastic Law🔽and who remove remorse should be regarded as good friends.

original: kukkuccavinodakā kalyāṇamittāti daṭṭhabbā. Vikkhepo ca bhikkhūnaṃ yebhuyyena kukkuccahetuko
analyzed: kukkucca vinodakā kalyāṇa mittā ati daṭṭhabbā vikkhepaḥ ca bhikkhūnam yebhuyyena kukkucca hetuko
translated: And since distraction is usually the cause of remorse in bhikkhus, the questions of the Discipline, etc.,

original: hotīti “kappiyākappiyaparipucchābahulassā”tiādinā vinayanayeneva paripucchakatādayo
analyzed: hoti iti kappiya akappiya paripucchā bahulassa ati ādinā vinaya nayena iva paripucchaka tā ādayaḥ
translated: are mentioned in the way beginning, “One who is skilled in the questions of the Discipline, etc.”

original: niddiṭṭhā. Pahīne uddhaccakukkucceti niddhāraṇe bhummaṃ. Kukkuccassa domanassasahagatattā
analyzed: niddiṭṭhā pahīne uddhacca kukkucca iti niddhāraṇe bhummam kukkuccassa domanassa sahagata ttā
translated: because worry is associated with grief.

original: anāgāmimaggena āyatiṃ anuppādo vutto.
analyzed: anāgāmi maggena āyatim anuppādaḥ vuttaḥ
translated: The non-arising in the future is stated by the path of non-return.

original: Kusalākusalā dhammātiādīsu yaṃ vattabbaṃ, taṃ heṭṭhā vuttameva. Kāmaṃ bāhusaccaparipucchakatāhi
analyzed: kusala akusalāḥ dhammā ti ādīsu yat vattabbam tat heṭṭhā vuttam eva kāmam bāhu sacca paripucchaka tāhi
translated: As to the profitable, unprofitable, etc., what is to be said has already been said above.

original: aṭṭhavatthukāpi vicikicchā pahīyati, tathāpi ratanattayavicikicchāmūlikā sesavicikicchāti
analyzed: aṭṭhavatthukā api vicikicchā pahīyati tathā api rata nattaya vicikicchā mūlikā sesa vicikicchā ati
translated: Although doubt about the eight questions is abandoned by the questions and the answers in the many ways,

original: katvā vuttaṃ “tīṇi ratanāni ārabbhā”tiādi. Vinaye pakataññutāya ca sati sikkhāya
analyzed: katvā vuttam tīṇi ratanāni ārabbha ati ādi vinaye pakataññu tāya ca sati sikkhāya
translated: nevertheless it is said that “doubt about the three treasures is the root of the rest of doubt” and that “doubt about the three treasures is stated thus ‘about the Buddha, about the Dhamma, about the Sangha.’ ”

original: kaṅkhāya asambhavo eva, tathā ratanattayaguṇāvabodhe sati pubbantādīsu saṃsayassāti🔽āha – “vinaye”tiādi. Okappanīyasaddhā saddheyyavatthuṃ anupavisitvā viya adhimuccanaṃ,
analyzed: asambhavaḥ eva tathā rata nattaya guṇa avabodhe sati pubbanta ādīsu saṃsayassa ati  āha vinaya itiādi okappanīya saddhā saddheyya vatthum an upavisitvā viya adhimuccanam
translated: And when there is knowledge of the three treasures’ special qualities, doubt about the past, etc., is impossible.🔽That is why it is said: “In the Dispensation” and so on.🔽Faith that is to be confirmed is a kind of confidence that is not yet fully developed, like a child’s confidence in its mother.🔽And that is the arousing of such confidence.

original: tañca tathā adhimokkhuppādanameva. Saddhāya ninnapoṇapabbhāratā adhimutti. Arahattena
analyzed: tat ca tathā adhimokkha uppādanam eva saddhāya ninna poṇa pabbhāra tā adhimutti arahattena
translated: The inclination of faith is the state of being inclined towards it. The state of being inclined towards arahatship is the inclination of arahatship.

original: kūṭaṃ gaṇhi sattapi bojjhaṅge vitthāretvā desanāya osāpitattā.
analyzed: kūṭam gaṇhi bojjhaṅge vitthāretvā desanāya osāpita ttā
translated: and the Thread was concluded with the teaching by the extension of the Seven Factors of Enlightenment.

original: Āhārasuttavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: āhāra sutta vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The Commentary on the Food Thread is ended.

original: 2. Pariyāyasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: pariyāya sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: The Discussion of the Discussion🔽are called “several” because of the absence of the name “Community” .

original: 233. Sambahulāti vuccanti saṅghasamaññāya abhāvato. Tato paranti tiṇṇaṃ janānaṃ upari
analyzed: sambahulā ati vuccanti saṅgha samaññāya abhāvato tatas paranti tiṇṇam janānam upari
translated: After that : above the three persons.

original: saṅgho catuvaggakaraṇīyādisaṅghakammavasena kammappattattā. Pavisiṃsūti bhāvini pavisane
analyzed: saṅghaḥ catu vagga karaṇīya ādi saṅgha kamma vasena kamma ppatta ttā bhāvini pavisane
translated: The Community : because of being fit for the Community- transaction of making up a group of four, and so on.🔽They entered : in the future tense, in the sense of the entering that is to be .

original: bhūte viya katvā upacārena vuttanti āha – “paviṭṭhā”ti. Bhāvini hi bhūte viya upacāro.
analyzed: bhūte viya katvā upacārena vuttanti āha paviṭṭhā iti bhāvini hi bhūte viya upacāraḥ
translated: They entered, is what is said by way of a simile as if it were in the past tense. For the future tense is a simile for the past tense.

original: Tenāha – “te panā”tiādi, te pana bhikkhūti attho. Puna te panāti titthiyā titthiyasāvakā ca.
analyzed: tena āha te pana atiādi te pana bhikkhū iti attho puna te pana ati titthiyā titthiya sāvakā ca
translated: Hence he said “But those bhikkhus” , the meaning being “but those bhikkhus”. Again, “but those” is the sectarians and the sectarians’ pupils.

original: Imasmiṃ paññāpaneti “pañca nīvaraṇe pahāyā”tiādinayappavatte imasmiṃ pakāre atthapaññāpane.
analyzed: imasmin paññāpane iti pañca nīvaraṇe pahāya ati ādi naya ppavatte imasmin pakāre attha paññāpane
translated: In this exposition : in this exposition of the meaning in the occurrence of the phrase beginning with “Having abandoned the five hindrances” .🔽It is a distinction because it is a division that is different from each other.

original: Visissati aññamaññato pabhijjatīti viseso, bhedo. Svāyaṃ idha antogadhādhikabhāvo
analyzed: visissati aññam aññatas pabhijjati iti visesaḥ bhedo antogadha adhika bhāvaḥ
translated: This is the excess included here.

original: adhippetoti āha – “ko visesoti kiṃ adhika”nti. Adhikaṃ payasanaṃ payuñjananti adhippayāso,
analyzed: adhippetaḥ iti āha kaḥ visesaḥ iti kim adhikam ti adhikam payasanam payuñjanam ti adhippayāsaḥ
translated: “The excess of the milk-rice is the intention to use it,🔽the excess of the milk-rice is the application to use it.

original: adhikappayogo. Nānā karīyati etenāti nānākaraṇaṃ, bhedoti āha – “kiṃ nānatta”nti.🔽Dutiyapadeti “anusāsaniyā vā anusāsani”nti etasmiṃ pade. Eseva nayoti yathā paṭhamasmiṃ
analyzed: nānā etena ati nānākaraṇam āha kim  dutiya pada iti anusāsaniyā vā etasmin pade yathā paṭhamasmin
translated: “What is the variety?” means “What is the difference?”🔽“In the second case” means in the case of “instruction or advice.”

original: pade atthayojanā, evaṃ dutiyapadepi yojetabbā.🔽Tīṇi ṭhānānīti devamārabrahmaṭṭhānāni tīṇi “sadevake loke”tiādinā loke pakkhipitvā.
analyzed: pade attha yojanā evam dutiya pade pi yojetabbā  tīṇi ṭhānāni iti deva māra brahmaṭṭhānāni tīṇi sa devake loke iti ādinā loke pakkhipitvā
translated: The method is the same as in the first case.🔽“The three instances” are the three instances of gods, Māras, and Brahmas.

original: “Sassamaṇabrāhmaṇiyā pajāya sadevamanussāyā”ti dve ṭhānāni. “Pajāyā”ti ettha pakkhipitvā
analyzed: sa samaṇa brāhmaṇiyā pajāya sa deva manussāya ati dve ṭhānāni pajāya ati ettha pakkhipitvā
translated: The two instances are “in the world with its gods, its Māras, and its Brahmās” and “in this generation with its monks and brahmans, with its gods and men.”🔽Thus, with five terms,

original: iti pañcahi padehi. Uddesanti uddisitabbataṃ. Gaṇananti eko kāmacchandoti gahetabbataṃ
analyzed: iti pañcahi padehi gaṇananti ekaḥ kāmacchandaḥ iti gahetabba tam
translated: “Enumeration” is the act of enumerating. “Calculation” is the act of calculating as “one sensual desire.”

original: gacchati. Attano hatthapādādīsūti nidassanamattaṃ daṭṭhabbaṃ samudāyaṃ ārabbha paṭighassa
analyzed: gacchati attanaḥ hattha pāda ādīsu iti nidassana mattam daṭṭhabbam samudāyam ārabbha paṭighassa
translated: “In his own hands and feet, etc.” is to be regarded as merely an illustration, for the repugnance is in regard to the collection.

original: uppajjanato. Attano khandhesu vimati “ahaṃ nu khosmī”tiādinā.
analyzed: uppajjanataḥ attanaḥ khandhesu aham nu khalu asmi itiādinā
translated: and by its arising. The doubt about his own aggregates is “Am I?”

original: Kiñcāpi sabbaṃ vīriyaṃ cetasikameva, yaṃ pana kāyakammādhiṭṭhānādivasena manasi kāyikapayogasamuṭṭhāpanaṃ
analyzed: kiñca api sabbam vīriyam cetasikam eva yam pana kāya kamma adhiṭṭhāna ādi vasena manasi kāyika payoga samuṭṭhāpanam
translated: Although all energy is mental, still that which is the instigation of bodily effort by directing it to bodily action, etc.,

original: vīriyaṃ kāyikanti laddhapariyāyanti tato visesetvā cetasikanti yathādhippetadutiyatādassanatthaṃ.
analyzed: vīriyam kāyikanti tatas visesetvā cetasikanti yathā adhippeta dutiya tā dassana ttham
translated: is called “bodily” by the conventional term “bodily energy.” So in order to distinguish it from that and to show it as the second in the order in which it is profitable, he said “mental.”

original: Yadipi yathākappitairiyāpathasandhāraṇavasena pavattamānaṃ vīriyaṃ kāyassa tathāpavattassa
analyzed: yadi pi yathā kappita eriyā patha sandhāraṇa vasena pavattamānam vīriyam kāyassa tathāpavattassa
translated: Although it is not tenable to say that energy occurring as the maintenance of the posture in the way described is a condition for the body’s occurrence in that way,

original: paccayabhūtanti na sakkā vattuṃ, tathāpi na tādiso kāyapayogo, tadā pavatto natthīti🔽vuttaṃ “kāyapayogaṃ vinā uppannavīriya”nti. Satisambojjhaṅgasadiso vāti iminā ajjhattike
analyzed: paccaya bhūtanti na sakkā vattum tathā api na tādisaḥ kāya payogo tadā pavatto natthi iti  vuttam kāya payogam vinā uppanna vīriyanti sati sambojjhaṅga sadisaḥ vā ti iminā ajjhattike
translated: nevertheless there is no such bodily effort when it occurs, and so it is said that “energy arises without bodily effort.”

original: saṅkhāre ajjhupekkhanavasena pavattā ajjhattadhammesu upekkhātiādinayaṃ atidisati.
analyzed: saṅkhāre ajjhupekkhana vasena pavattā ajjhatta dhammesu upekkhā iti ādi nayam atidisati
translated: “Like the enlightenment factor of mindfulness” shows that equanimity is the same as the equanimity of the enlightenment factor in occurring by looking on at internal formations with equanimity, and so on.

original: “Missakabojjhaṅgā kathitā”ti vatvā tamatthaṃ vibhāvetuṃ “etesū”tiādi vuttaṃ. Caṅkamantenapi
analyzed: missaka bojjhaṅgā kathitā iti vatvā tam attham vibhāvetum etesu itiādi vuttam caṅkamantena api
translated: “The factors of enlightenment are said to be mixed” . In order to demonstrate the meaning of that, “In these” , etc., is said.

original: ariyamaggaṃ adhigantuṃ sakkāti katvā vuttaṃ “maggaṃ apattaṃ kāyikavīriya”nti. Bojjhaṅgā
analyzed: ariya maggam adhigantum sakkā iti katvā vuttam maggam a pattam kāyika vīriyanti bojjhaṅgā
translated: It is said that “bodily energy” is not reached in the path because it is possible to attain the noble path even while walking.🔽The factors of enlightenment are not found in the sense-sphere states.

original: na labbhantīti nippariyāyabojjhaṅgā na labbhantī. Bojjhaṅge uddharanti pariyāyatoti
analyzed: na labbhanti iti nippariyāya bojjhaṅgā na labbhanti bojjhaṅge uddharanti pariyāyato ti
translated: The intention is that the factors of enlightenment are extracted by way of the indirect method.

original: adhippāyo. Sesāti bahiddhādhammesu sati-dhammavicaya-upekkhā-cetasika-vīriya-savitakka-savicāra-pīti-samādhī
analyzed: adhippāyaḥ sesā ti bahiddhā dhammesu sati dhamma vicaya aupekkhā cetasika vīriya sa vitakka sa vicāra pīti samādhī
translated: The rest are the remaining factors of enlightenment, namely, mindfulness, investigation of states, equanimity, the mental factors of energy, applied thought, sustained thought, happiness, and concentration.

original: dve passaddhiyo ca. Ayaṃ pana nayo pacurappavattivasena aṭṭhakathānayeneva vutto.
analyzed: dve passaddhiyaḥ ca ayam pana nayo pacura pavatti vasena aṭṭhakathā nayena iva vuttaḥ
translated: There are two kinds of tranquillity. This method is stated in the commentary according to the method of the ordinary man.

original: Theravādavasena pana avitakkaavicāramattā pītisamādhisambojjhaṅgā rūpāvacarāpi atthīti
analyzed: thera vāda vasena pana avitakka avicāra mattā pīti samādhi sambojjhaṅgā rūpāvacarā api atthi iti
translated: But according to the Theravada, there is also the factor of enlightenment of concentration accompanied by happiness and free from applied thought and sustained thought in the fine-material sphere.

original: tepi gahetvā dasa missakāva hontīti vattabbaṃ siyāti.🔽Pariyāyasuttavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: te api gahetvā dasa missakā ava honti iti vattabbam siyāti  pariyāya sutta vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: Therefore it should be said that there are ten mixed factors of enlightenment by including those.🔽The commentary on the Pariyāyasutta is finished.

original: 3. Aggisuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: aggi sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: The Aggisutta is commented on.

original: 234. Loṇadhūpananti loṇañca dhūpanañca loṇadhūpanaṃ. Yodhakammanti yodhapuggalena🔽kattabbaṃ kammaṃ. Mantakammanti rājakiccamantanaṃ. Paṭihārakammanti rañño santikaṃ
analyzed: loṇa dhūpanam ti loṇam ca dhūpanam ca loṇa dhūpanam yodha kamman ti yodha puggalena  kattabbam kammam manta kammanti rāja kicca mantanam paṭihāra kammanti rañño santikam
translated: Salt-bath means salt and a bath, a salt-bath. War means the work done by a soldier.🔽Counsel means royal business.🔽Court means the work of reporting to the king what has been said by those who have come into his presence and then of replying to them.

original: āgatānaṃ vacanaṃ rañño nivedetvā tato nesaṃ paṭiharaṇakammaṃ. Tasmāti sabbatthikattā
analyzed: āgatānam vacanam raññaḥ nivedetvā tatas na īsam paṭiharaṇa kammam tasmā ati sabbatthika ttā
translated: Therefore, because of its all-purpose value,🔽he said, “And I have spoken of mindfulness” in this way.

original: satiyā. Evaṃ “satiñca khvāha”ntiādikaṃ avoca. Pubbabhāgavipassanā bojjhaṅgāva kathitā🔽paggahaniggahavinoditattā.
analyzed: satiyā evam satim ca khvāhan ti ādikam avoca pubba bhāga vipassanā bojjhaṅgā ava kathitā  paggaha niggaha vinodita ttā
translated: The enlightenment factors have been called “preliminary”🔽because they are the preliminary stage of insight, which is purified by exertion, cleansing, and development.

original: Aggisuttavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: aggi sutta vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The commentary on the Aggivacchagotta Sutta is finished.

original: 4. Mettāsahagatasuttavaṇṇanā🔽235. Kīdisā gati nibbatti etissāti kiṃgatikā, kiṃniṭṭhāti vuttaṃ hoti. Kīdisī paramā
analyzed: mettā sahagata sutta vaṇṇanā  kīdisā gati nibbatti etissa ati kiṃgatikā kiṃniṭṭhā ti vuttam hoti kīdisī paramā
translated: The Sutta on What is Associated with Friendliness

original: uttamā koṭi etissāti kiṃparamā. Kīdisaṃ phalaṃ ānisaṃsaṃ udayo etissāti kiṃphalā.
analyzed: uttamā koṭi etissa ati kiṃparamā kīdisam phalam ānisaṃsam udayaḥ etissa ati kiṃphalā
translated: What kind of destination, what kind of rebirth does it lead to? What is its culmination? What is its fruit? What is its advantage? What is its end?

original: Saṃsaṭṭhaṃ sampayuttanti idaṃ sahagata-saddassa atthadassanamattaṃ, idha pana mettājhānaṃ
analyzed: saṃsaṭṭham sampayuttanti idam sahagata saddassa attha dassana mattam idha pana mettā jhānam
translated: The word “associated” is used here in the sense of “mixed up with.”

original: pādakaṃ katvā vipassanāpubbabhāgabojjhaṅgā ca “mettāsahagataṃ satisambojjhaṅga”ntiādinā
analyzed: pādakam katvā vipassanā pubbabhāga bojjhaṅgā ca mettā sahagatam sati sambojjhaṅga nti ādinā
translated: And the enlightenment factors that are the forerunner of insight should be understood as “the enlightenment factor of mindfulness accompanied by loving-kindness” and so on.

original: vuttāti veditabbaṃ. Sabbatthāti sabbesu bojjhaṅgesu sabbesu ca brahmavihāresu.🔽Paṭikūleti virajjatīti paṭikūlaṃ, aniṭṭhaṃ. Na paṭikūlaṃ appaṭikūlaṃ, iṭṭhaṃ. Tenāha
analyzed: vuttā iti veditabbam sabbattha ati sabbesu bojjhaṅgesu sabbesu ca brahmavihāresu  paṭikūlā iti virajjati iti paṭikūlam aniṭṭham na paṭikūlam a paṭikūlam iṭṭham tena āha
translated: In all cases: in all the enlightenment factors and in all the divine abidings.🔽The unrepulsive is the opposite of the repulsive. The repulsive is what is unlovely, undesirable. The opposite of that is the repulsive, which is lovely, desirable. Hence it is said:

original: “iṭṭhe vatthusmi”nti. Etthāti appaṭikūlavatthusmiṃ. Evanti paṭikūlasaññī. Satte appaṭikūle🔽asubhapharaṇaṃ, saṅkhāre appaṭikūle aniccanti manasikāraṃ karonto. Asubhāyāti asubhasaññāya.
analyzed: iṭṭhe vatthusmin ti ettha ati appaṭikūla vatthusmin evam ti paṭikūla saññī satte appaṭikūle  asubha pharaṇam saṅkhāre a paṭikūle aniccanti manasikāram karontaḥ asubhāya ati asubha saññāya
translated: “In a desirable object.” There: in the unrepulsive object. Thus: as one who has the perception of the repulsive.🔽Beings: in the unrepulsive. The sign of foulness: the sign of the bloated, etc.,

original: Aniccato vā upasaṃharatīti aniccanti manasikāraṃ pavatteti. “Eseva nayo”ti saṅkhepato
analyzed: aniccataḥ vā upasaṃharati iti aniccanti manasikāram pavattā iti esā iva saṅkhepato
translated: The sign of formations: the sign of impermanence, etc. He directs his mind: he gives attention.

original: vuttamatthaṃ vivarituṃ “appaṭikūlapaṭikūlesū”tiādi vuttaṃ. Chaḷaṅgupekkhanti chasu
analyzed: vuttam attham vivaritum appaṭikūla paṭikūlesu itiādi vuttam chaḷaṅgu pekkhanti chasu
translated: The same method applies to the rest: the meaning of this should be understood by the method stated thus: “In the repulsive and the unrepulsive.”

original: ārammaṇesu pahīnānurodhassa uppattiyā chaḷaṅgavantaṃ upekkhaṃ.
analyzed: ārammaṇesu pahīna anurodhassa uppattiyā chaḷaṅgavantam upekkham
translated: Equanimity about formations: equanimity consisting in the sixfold contemplation of formations.

original: Mettāyāti mettābhāvanāya. Paṭikūlādīsu vatthūsu icchitavihārena viharituṃ samatthatā
analyzed: mettāya ati mettā bhāvanāya paṭikūla ādīsu vatthūsu icchita vihārena viharitum samattha tā
translated: Metta means by the development of loving-kindness. The ability to live in the way desired in the objects of meditation such as the loathsome is

original: ariyānaṃ eva, tattha ca arahato eva ijjhanato ariyiddhi nāma. Tassā ariyiddhiyā ca
analyzed: ariyānam eva tattha ca arahataḥ eva ijjhanataḥ ariyiddhi nāma tassā ariyiddhiyā ca
translated: only found in Noble Ones. And since it succeeds only in the Arahant, it is called Noble Success. And because it is shown by that Noble Success,

original: dassitattā desanā vinivaṭṭetabbā pariyosānetabbā siyā. Arahattaṃ pāpuṇituṃ na sakkoti🔽indriyānaṃ aparipakkattā nikantiyā ca duppariyādānato. Ayaṃ desanāti “mettāsahagataṃ
analyzed: dassita ttā desanā vinivaṭṭetabbā pariyosānetabbā siyā arahattam pāpuṇitum na sakkoti  indriyānaṃ a paripakka ttā nikantiyā ca duppariyādānataḥ ayam desanā ati mettā sahagatam
translated: the teaching can be stopped, can be concluded. One who is unable to reach Arahantship🔽because his faculties are unripe and because of the difficulty of overcoming attachment. This is the teaching. The teaching beginning with “He develops the enlightenment factor of equanimity accompanied by loving-kindness”

original: bojjhaṅgaṃ bhāvetī”tiādinā ayaṃ desanā āraddhā. Yo hi mettājhānaṃ pādakaṃ katvā sammasanaṃ🔽ārabhitvā arahattaṃ pāpuṇituṃ asakkonto parisuddhesu vaṇṇakasiṇesu vimokkhasaṅkhātaṃ🔽rūpāvacarajjhānaṃ nibbatteti, taṃ sandhāyāha bhagavā – “subhaṃ kho pana vimokkhaṃ
analyzed: bojjhaṅgam bhāveti iti ādinā ayam desanā āraddhā yaḥ hi mettā jhānam pādakam katvā sammasanam  ārabhitvā arahattam pāpuṇitum a sakkonto parisuddhesu vaṇṇa kasiṇesu vimokkha saṅkhātam  rūpāvacara jhānam nibbatteti tam sandhāya āha bhagavā subham kho pana vimokkham
translated: was begun. For one who, after making the jhāna of loving-kindness the basis, begins the investigation🔽and is unable to reach Arahantship, produces the jhāna of the fine-material sphere called the “liberation by the beautiful”

original: upasampajja viharatī”ti.
analyzed: upasampajja viharati iti
translated: after purifying the colour kasiṇa. With reference to him the Blessed One said: “He dwells having entered upon the beautiful liberation.”

original: Subhaparamanti subhavimokkhaparamaṃ. Idha loke eva paññā assa. Tenāha “lokiyapaññassāti
analyzed: subha paramanti subha vimokkha paramam idha loke eva paññā assa tena āha lokiya paññassa ati
translated: The “highest beauty” is the beauty of the liberation. It is wisdom here in this world. Therefore it is said: “The meaning is: wisdom of the world.”

original: attho”ti. Arahattaparamāva mettā arahattamaggassa pādakattā. Karuṇādīsupi eseva nayoti
analyzed: attho ti mettā arahatta maggassa pādaka ttā karuṇā ādīsu pi esā iva nayo ti
translated: Loving-kindness is “highest in Arahantship” because it is the footing for the Arahant path. The same method applies in the case of compassion, and so on.

original: karuṇādijhānaṃ pādakaṃ katvā saṅkhāre sammasanto arahattaṃ pattuṃ sakkoti, tassa
analyzed: karuṇā ādi jhānam pādakam katvā saṅkhāre sammasantaḥ arahattam pattum sakkoti tassa
translated: Having made the jhāna of compassion, etc., a footing, he is able to reach Arahantship by comprehending formations.

original: arahatthaparamā karuṇā hoti, evaṃ muditāupekkhāsupi vattabbanti imamatthaṃ atidisati.
analyzed: arahattha paramā karuṇā hoti evam muditā upekkhāsu pi vattabban ti imam attham atidisati
translated: His compassion is “highest in Arahantship.” So too in the case of gladness and equanimity. This is the meaning he shows.

original: Puna desanārambhapayojanaṃ pana “iminā nayenā”ti heṭṭhā atidiṭṭhameva.
analyzed: puna desanā ārambha payojanam pana iminā nayena ati heṭṭhā atidiṭṭham eva
translated: The purpose of the re-arising of the teaching is shown by the words “in this way” , which have already been explained above.

original: Subhaparamāditāti mettākaruṇāmuditāupekkhānaṃ subhaparamatā ākāsānañcāyatanaparamatā,
analyzed: subha parama āditā ati mettā karuṇā muditā upekkhānam subha parama tā ākāsa anañca āyatana parama tā
translated: The “highest beauty” is the highest beauty of loving- kindness, compassion, gladness, and equanimity. It is the base consisting of boundless space,

original: viññāṇañcāyatanaparamatā, ākiñcaññāyatanaparamatā. Tassa tassāti subhavimokkhassa
analyzed: viññāṇañcāyatana parama tā ākiñcaññāyatana parama tā tassa tassa ati subha vimokkhassa
translated: the base consisting of boundless consciousness, and the base consisting of nothingness.🔽The “highest” of each of these is the “highest” of the beauty of the liberation and of the three immaterial jhānas respectively, because it is their support.

original: heṭṭhā tiṇṇaṃ arūpajjhānānañca yathākkamaṃ upanissayattā. Appaṭikūlaparicayāti iṭṭhārammaṇe
analyzed: heṭṭhā tiṇṇam arūpa jhānānam ca yathākkamam upanissaya ttā a paṭikūla paricayā ti iṭṭha ārammaṇe
translated: “Familiarity with the not-repulsive” is the repeated attention given to a desirable object.

original: manasikārabahulīkārā. Appakasirenevāti sukheneva. Tatthāti visuddhatāya iṭṭhesu vaṇṇakasiṇesu.
analyzed: manasikāra bahulīkārāḥ appa kasirena iva ati sukhena iva tattha ati visuddha tāya iṭṭhesu vaṇṇa kasiṇesu
translated: and by frequently giving attention to it. With little difficulty: with ease. There: in the desired kasiṇas because of their purity.🔽The mind enters into: enters into jhāna by way of absorption.

original: Cittanti bhāvanāmayacittaṃ pakkhandati appanāvasena. Tato paranti tato subhavimokkhato
analyzed: cittam ti bhāvanā maya cittam pakkhandati appanā vasena tato paranti tatas subha vimokkhato
translated: After that: after the fine-material-sphere jhāna.

original: paraṃ vimokkhānaṃ upanissayo nāma na hoti, mettāsahagatabhāvo daṭṭhabbo.
analyzed: param vimokkhānam upanissayaḥ nāma na hoti mettā sahagata bhāvaḥ daṭṭhabbo
translated: The immaterial states have no support in the sense of being a proximate cause, but the presence of loving-kindness should be regarded as a support.

original: Sattadukkhaṃ samanupassantassāti daṇḍena abhihaṭappattarūpahetuṃ sattesu uppajjanakadukkhaṃ
analyzed: satta dukkham samanupassantassa ati daṇḍena abhihaṭa patta rūpa hetum sattesu uppajjanaka dukkham
translated: When he sees the suffering of beings: when he sees the suffering that arises in beings through their being struck with sticks, etc.,🔽and he investigates it with knowledge.

original: ñāṇena vīmaṃsantassa. Tayidaṃ rūpanimittakaṃ sattesu uppajjanakaṃ dukkhaṃ ñāṇena🔽karuṇāvihārissa visesato pakkhandatīti katvā vuttaṃ “appakasireneva tattha cittaṃ
analyzed: ñāṇena vīmaṃsantassa tayidam rūpa nimittakam sattesu uppajjanakam dukkham ñāṇena  karuṇā vihārissa visesataḥ pakkhandati iti katvā vuttam appa kasirena iva tattha cittam
translated: And that suffering, which arises in beings through a sign of materiality, enters into his mind with special ease,🔽because it enters his mind with ease when he abides in compassion, but not because it is entirely profitable,

original: pakkhandatī”ti, na pana sabbaso arūpe ānisaṃsadassanato.
analyzed: pakkhandati iti na pana sabbaso arūpe ā nisaṃsa dassanato
translated: since it is shown as a disadvantage in the immaterial states.

original: Viññāṇaṃ samanupassantassāti idaṃ pāmojjagahaṇamukhena tannissayaviññāṇassa gahaṇaṃ sambhavatīti katvā vuttaṃ. Viññāṇaggahaṇaparicitanti vuttanayena viññāṇaggahaṇe paricitaṃ.
analyzed: viññāṇam samanupassantassa ati idam pāmojja gahaṇa mukhena tad nissaya viññāṇassa gahaṇam sambhavati iti katvā vuttam viññāṇa ggahaṇa paricitanti vutta nayena viññāṇa ggahaṇe paricitam
translated: “Contemplating consciousness”: this is said because it is possible to apprehend the consciousness that is the support for that joy by way of apprehending the joy. “Familiar with the apprehension of consciousness”: familiar with the apprehension of consciousness in the way stated.

original: Upekkhāvihārissāti upekkhābrahmavihāraṃ viharato. Ābhogābhāvatoti sukhādivasena ābhujanābhāvato.
analyzed: upekkhā vihārissa āti upekkhā brahmavihāram viharataḥ ābhoga abhāvataḥ ti sukha ādi vasena ābhujana abhāvataḥ
translated: “Dwelling in equanimity”: dwelling in the divine abiding of equanimity. “Because of the absence of attention”: because of the absence of attention to pleasure, etc.

original: Sukha…pe… sambhavatoti sukhadukkhāti paramatthakammaggahaṇe vimukhatāsambhavato.
analyzed: sukha pe sambhavato ti sukha dukkha ati paramattha kammaggahaṇe vimukha tā sambhavato
translated: “Because of the impossibility of liberation”: because of the impossibility of liberation through the apprehension of pleasure, etc., as ultimate realities.

original: Avijjamānaggahaṇadukkhanti paramatthato avijjamānasattapaññattigahaṇaparicitaṃ tassa
analyzed: avijjamāna ggahaṇa dukkham ti paramatthataḥ avijjamāna satta paññatti gahaṇa paricitam tassa
translated: “Painful is the apprehension of what does not exist”: painful is the apprehension of the mere absence of this or that, which is familiar through the apprehension of the designation of a being, which does not exist as an ultimate reality.

original: tassa abhāvamattakassa gahaṇampi dukkhaṃ kusalampi hoti. Sesaṃ suviññeyyameva.🔽Mettāsahagatasuttavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.🔽5. Saṅgāravasuttavaṇṇanā🔽236. Paṭhamaññevāti puretaraṃyeva. Asajjhāyakatānaṃ mantānaṃ appaṭibhānaṃ pageva
analyzed: tassa abhāva mattakassa gahaṇam pi dukkham kusalam pi hoti sesam su viññeyyam eva 🔽mettā sahagata sutta vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā 🔽saṅgārava sutta vaṇṇanā 🔽paṭhamañca iva ati puretaraṃ yeva a sajjhāyaka tānam mantānam appaṭibhānam pageva
translated: Even the wholesome is painful. The rest is quite clear.

original: paṭhamaṃyeva siddhaṃ, tattha vattabbameva natthīti adhippāyo. Pariyuṭṭhānaṃ nāma🔽abhibhavo gahaṇanti āha – “kāmarāgapariyuṭṭhitenāti kāmarāgagahitenā”ti. Vikkhambheti🔽apanetīti vikkhambhanaṃ, paṭipakkhato nissarati etenāti nissaraṇaṃ, vikkhambhanañca🔽taṃ nissaraṇañcāti vikkhambhananissaraṇaṃ. Tenāha – “tatthā”tiādi. Sesapadadvayepi🔽eseva nayo. Attanā araṇiyo pattabbo attattho, tathā parattho veditabbo.
analyzed: paṭhamam yeva siddham tattha vattabbam eva natthi iti adhippāyaḥ pariyuṭṭhānam nāma  abhibhavaḥ gahaṇanti āha kāma rāga pariyuṭṭhitena ati kāma rāga gahitena ati vikkhambheti  apaneti iti vikkhambhanam paṭipakkhataḥ nissarati etena ati nissaraṇam vikkhambhanam ca  tam nissaraṇam ca ati vikkhambhana nissaraṇam tena āha tattha atiādi sesa pada dvaye pi  esa iva nayaḥ attanā araṇiyaḥ pattabbaḥ atta atthaḥ tathā paratthaḥ veditabbaḥ
translated: The intention is that it is already established in the first place, and so there is nothing to be said about it here. “Clinging” is

original: “Aniccato anupassanto niccasaññaṃ pajahatī”tiādīsu byāpādādīnaṃ anāgatattā abyāpādavāre🔽tadaṅganissaraṇaṃ na gahitaṃ. Kiñcāpi na gahitaṃ, paṭisaṅkhānavasena pana tassa vinodetabbatāya🔽tadaṅganissaraṇampi labbhatevāti sakkā viññātuṃ. Ālokasaññā upacārappattā, appanāppattā
analyzed: aniccataḥ anupassantaḥ nicca saññam pajahati itiādīsu byāpāda ādīnam anāgata ttā abyāpāda vāre 🔽tad aṅga nissaraṇam na gahitam kiñcā api na gahitam paṭisaṅkhāna vasena pana tassa vinodetabba tāya 🔽tad aṅga nissaraṇam pi labbhate iva ati sakkā viññātum āloka saññā upacāra ppattā appanā appattā
translated: overpowering, grasping. “With lust, hate, and delusion” means with lust, hate, and delusion as the cause. “With lust, hate, delusion, and the fevers based on them” means with lust, hate, and delusion, and with the fevers based on them. “With lust, hate, delusion, the fevers based on them, and the perversions based on them” means with lust, hate, and delusion, and with the fevers based on them, and with the perversions based on them. “With lust, hate, delusion, the fevers based on them, the perversions based on them, and the taints based on them” means with lust, hate, and delusion, and with the fevers based on them, and with the perversions based on them, and with the taints based on them. “With lust, hate, delusion, the fevers based on them, the perversions based on them, the taints based on them, and the fetters based on them” means with lust, hate, and delusion, and with the fevers based on them, and with the perversions based on them, and with the taints based on them, and with the fetters based on them. “With lust, hate, delusion, the fevers based on them, the perversions based on them, the taints based on them, the fetters based on them, and the underlying tendencies based on them” means with lust, hate, and delusion, and with the fevers based on them, and with the perversions based on them, and with the taints based on them, and with the fetters based on them, and with the underlying tendencies based on them. “With lust, hate, delusion, the fevers based on them, the perversions based on them, the taints based on them, the fetters based on them, and the underlying tendencies based on them” means with lust, hate, and delusion, and with the fevers based on them, and with the perversions based on them, and with the taints based on them, and with the fetters based on them, and with the underlying tendencies based on them. “With lust, hate, delusion, the fevers based on them, the perversions based on them, the taints based

original: vā, yo koci kasiṇajjhānādibhedo samatho. Dhammavavatthānaṃ upacārappanāppattavasena gahetabbaṃ.🔽Kuthitoti tatto. Usmudakajātoti tasseva kuthitabhāvassa usmudakataṃ accuṇhataṃ patto.🔽Tenāha “usumajāto”ti. Tilabījakādibhedenāti tilabījakakaṇṇikakesarādibhedena. Sevālena…pe…🔽paṇakenāti udakapicchilena. Appasanno ākulatāya. Asannisinno kalaluppattiyā. Anālokaṭṭhāneti ālokarahite ṭhāne.
analyzed: vā yaḥ koci kasiṇa jhāna ādi bhedaḥ samathaḥ dhamma vavatthānam upacāra ppanā appatta vasena gahetabbam  kuthitaḥ ti tattas usmudaka jātaḥ iti tassa iva kuthita bhāvassa usmudaka tam patto  tena āha tila bījaka ādi bhedena ati tila bījaka kaṇṇika kesara ādi bhedena  paṇakena ati udaka picchilena appasannaḥ ākula tāya a sannisinnaḥ kalala uppattiyā anāloka ṭṭhāne iti āloka rahite ṭhāne
translated: “Scorched” : burnt. “Steamed” : he has reached the state of being steamed, the state of being heated, of that which is scorched.

original: Saṅgāravasuttavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.🔽6. Abhayasuttavaṇṇanā🔽237. Ekaṃsena bhagavā nīvaraṇāti ekaṃsato eva bhagavā ete dhammā nīvaraṇā citte kusalappavattiyā🔽nīvaraṇato. Kāyakilamathoti kāyaparissamo, so pana aṭṭhuppattiyā paccayattā “daratho”ti
analyzed: saṅgārava sutta vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā 🔽abhaya sutta vaṇṇanā 🔽ekaṃsena bhagavā nīvaraṇā ati ekaṃsataḥ eva bhagavā ete dhammā nīvaraṇā citte kusala ppavattiyā 🔽nīvaraṇato kāya kilamatho ti kāya parissamo so pana aṭṭhuppattiyā paccayattā daratho ti
translated: Hence it is said, “steamed and heated” . “By the various kinds of seeds” : by the various kinds of seeds such as sesame seeds, kidney-beans, mung-beans, etc. “By the various kinds of grass” : by the various kinds of grass such as reeds, sugar-canes, etc. “By the various kinds of wood” : by the various kinds of wood such as sal, sandalwood, etc. “By the various kinds of mud” : by the various kinds of mud such as clay, sand, etc. “By the various kinds of water” : by the various kinds of water such as the Ganges, the Yamunā, etc. “By the various kinds of land” : by the various kinds of land such as the Northern Kurus, the Eastern Videhas, etc. “By the various kinds of villages” : by the various kinds of villages such as the village of brahmans, the village of householders, etc. “By the various kinds of towns” : by the various kinds of towns such as the town of brahmans, the town of householders, etc. “By the various kinds of countries” : by the various kinds of countries such as the country of brahmans, the country of householders, etc. “By the various kinds of abodes” : by the various kinds of abodes such as the abode of brahmans, the abode of householders, etc. “By the various kinds of trees” : by the various kinds of trees such as the ironwood tree, the sandalwood tree, etc. “By the various kinds of grass” : by the various kinds of grass such as the reed, the sugar-cane, etc. “By the various kinds of creepers” : by the various kinds of creepers such as the jasmine creeper, the trumpet-flower creeper, etc. “By the various kinds of leaves” : by the various kinds of leaves such as the lotus leaf, the pipphali leaf, etc. “By the various kinds of fruits” : by the various kinds of fruits such as the mango fruit, the bread-fruit, etc. “By the various kinds of medicines” : by

original: vutto. Cittakilamatho tappaccayajāto daṭṭhabbo. Tenāha – “tassa kirā”tiādi. Cittadarathopi🔽paṭippassambhīti ānetvā sambandho. Maggenevāti yathādhigatena ariyamaggeneva. Assāti
analyzed: vuttaḥ citta kilamathaḥ tad paccaya jātaḥ daṭṭhabbaḥ tena āha tassa kirāti ādi  paṭippassambhi iti ānetvā sambandhaḥ maggena iva āti yathā adhigatena ariya maggena iva assa ati
translated: The bodily fatigue that arises with that is to be seen. Hence he said: “It is said of him” , etc. The mental fatigue, too,

original: abhayassa rājakumārassa. Etaṃ kāyacittadarathadvayaṃ.
analyzed: abhayassa rāja kumārassa etam
