Thus it is said: ‘The Bodhi Tree should be paid homage to as the Enlightened One’s throne.’ ‘In the vicinity of the village’: in the vicinity of the village. ‘For the purpose of gathering people’: ‘If I do not speak, who will speak for them? ‘, with the thought ‘I shall help the Dhamma’, for the purpose of gathering people.

original: Tasmāti yasmā “dhammakathā nāma kathetabbā evā”ti aṭṭhakathācariyā vadanti, yasmā🔽ca dhammakathā kammaṭṭhānavinimuttā nāma natthi, tasmā. Kammaṭṭhānasīsenevāti attanā🔽parihariyamānaṃ kammaṭṭhānaṃ avijahanto tadanuguṇaṃyeva dhammakathaṃ kathetvā. Anumodanaṃ🔽katvāti etthāpi “kammaṭṭhānasīsenevā”ti ānetvā sambandhitabbaṃ. Sampattaparicchedenevāti
analyzed: tasmā iti yasmā dhamma kathā nāma kathetabbā evā ti aṭṭhakathā cariyāḥ vadanti yasmā  ca dhamma kathā kammaṭṭhāna vinimuttā nāma natthi tasmā kammaṭṭhāna sīsena iva ati attanā  parihariyamānam kammaṭṭhānam a vijahanto tad anuguṇam yeva dhamma katham kathetvā anumodanam  katvā iti ettha api kammaṭṭhāna sīsena iva ati ānetvā sambandhitabbam sampatta paricchedena iva ati
translated: Therefore: because the teachers of the commentary say that a talk on the Dhamma should be given, and

original: paricito aparicitotiādivibhāgaṃ akatvā sampattakoṭiyā eva, samāgamamattenevāti attho.
analyzed: paricitaḥ a paricitaḥ iti ādi vibhāgam a katvā sampatta koṭiyā eva samāgama mattena iva ati attho
translated: because there is no talk on the Dhamma that is not a meditation subject, therefore. With the meditation subject as the starting point: without abandoning the meditation subject that he himself is practising, he should give a talk on the Dhamma that is appropriate to it. After giving the blessing: here too the words “with the meditation subject as the starting point” should be brought in and construed. With the section on the occasion: without making any distinction such as “known” or “unknown,” just with the arrival itself, is the meaning.

original: Bhayeti paracakkādibhaye.
analyzed: bhaya iti para cakka ādi bhaye
translated: Danger: from an enemy army, etc.

original: Kammajatejoti gahaṇiṃ sandhāyāha. Kammaṭṭhānavīthiṃ nārohati khudāparissamena kilantakāyattā
analyzed: kamma ja tejaḥ ti gahaṇim sandhāya āha kammaṭṭhāna vīthim na ārohati khudā parissamena kilantaka āyattā
translated: The heat of kamma: he says this referring to the taking of the iron ball. He does not mount the meditation subject’s track because his body is tired from hunger and fatigue,

original: samādhānābhāvato. Avasesaṭṭhāneti yāguyā aggahitaṭṭhāne. Poṅkhānupoṅkhanti kammaṭṭhānupaṭṭhānassa
analyzed: samādhāna abhāvataḥ avasesa ṭṭhāne iti yāguyā agga hita ṭṭhāne poṅkha anupoṅkhanti kammaṭṭhāna upaṭṭhānassa
translated: and because he has no concentration. The rest of the time: the time not taken up with gruel. In the intervals: in the intervals of the meditation subject’s practice.

original: aviccheda-dassanametaṃ, yathā poṅkhānupoṅkhaṃ pavattāya sarapaṭipāṭiyā anavicchedo,
analyzed: a viccheda dassanam etam yathā poṅkha anupoṅkham pavattāya sara paṭipāṭiyā an avicchedaḥ
translated: This is the uninterruptedness of the meditation subject, which is like the uninterruptedness of the flight of a bird from tree to tree.

original: evametassapi kammaṭṭhānupaṭṭhānassāti vuttaṃ hoti.
analyzed: evam etassa api kammaṭṭhāna upaṭṭhānassa ati vuttam hoti
translated: What is meant is that it is like the uninterruptedness of the flight of a bird from tree to tree.

original: Nikkhittadhuro bhāvanānuyoge. Vattapaṭipattiyā apūraṇena sabbavattāni bhinditvā.
analyzed: nikkhitta dhuraḥ bhāvanā anuyoge vatta paṭipattiyā a pūraṇena sabba vattāni bhinditvā
translated: He is one who has given up the burden, who is devoted to the development of the meditation subject, who has not fulfilled the practice of duties by not fulfilling the practice of duties in the observance of the proper conduct.

original: Kāme avītarāgo hoti. Kāye avītarāgo. Rūpe avītarāgo. Yāvadatthaṃ udarāvadehaṃ bhuñjitvā🔽seyyasukhaṃ passasukhaṃ middhasukhaṃ anuyutto viharati. Aññataraṃ devanikāyaṃ paṇidhāya
analyzed: kāme a vīta rāgaḥ kāye a vīta rāgaḥ rūpe a vīta rāgaḥ yāvadattham udara avadeham bhuñjitvā  seyya sukham passa sukham middha sukham anuyuttaḥ viharati aññataram devanikāyam paṇidhāya
translated: He is not free from lust in regard to sense desires, he is not free from lust in regard to the body, he is not free from lust in regard to form, he eats as much as he likes until his belly is full,🔽he devotes himself to pleasure in sleep, pleasure in sloth, pleasure in torpor, he lives the holy life aiming at some order of gods thus: ‘By this rite or this ritual or this austerity I shall become a great god or some lesser god,’—

original: brahmacariyaṃ caratī”ti evaṃ vuttaṃ pañcavidhacetovinibandhacitto. Caritvāti pavattitvā.
analyzed: brahmacariyam carati iti evam vuttam caritvā ati pavattitvā
translated: he is one whose mind is fettered in five ways, as stated.

original: Gatapaccāgatikavattavasenāti bhāvanāsahitaṃyeva bhikkhāya gatapaccāgataṃ gamanapaccāgamanaṃ
analyzed: gatapaccāgatika vatta vasena ati bhāvanā sahitam yeva bhikkhāya gata paccāgatam gamana paccāgamanam
translated: Having gone and returned: having gone and returned with the meditation subject together with the alms round.🔽He has gone and returned, thus he is one who has gone and returned; that is a practice, by means of that practice.

original: etassa atthīti gatapaccāgatikaṃ, tadeva vattaṃ, tassa vasena. Attano hitasukhaṃ kāmenti
analyzed: etassa atthi iti gata paccāgatikam tat eva vattam tassa vasena attanaḥ hita sukham kāmenti
translated: He makes his own welfare and happiness depend on others.

original: icchantīti attakāmā, dhammacchandavanto. “Dhammo”ti hi hitaṃ taṃnimittakañca sukhanti.
analyzed: icchanti iti atta kāmāḥ dhamma chandavantaḥ hi hitam tad nimittakam ca sukhanti
translated: “Who wish” : who are desirous of themselves, who have a desire for the Dhamma. For “Dhamma” is what is beneficial and the cause of happiness.

original: Atha vā viññūnaṃ dhammānaṃ attaniyattā attabhāvaparicchannattā ca attā nāma dhammo.
analyzed: atha vā viññūnam dhammānam atta niyattā atta bhāva paricchanna ttā ca attā nāma dhammo
translated: Or else, the Dhamma is called “self” because of the self-dependence of the wise in regard to the Dhamma and because of the self-possession of the Dhamma.

original: Tenāha bhagavā – “attadīpā, bhikkhave, viharatha attasaraṇā”tiādi. Taṃ kāmenti icchantīti
analyzed: tena āha bhagavā atta dīpāḥ bhikkhave viharatha atta saraṇa atiādi tam kāmenti icchanti iti
translated: Therefore the Exalted One said: “Monks, live with yourselves as an island, with yourselves as a refuge, with no other as a refuge” , etc. They who do this are desirous of themselves.

original: attakāmā. Usabhaṃ nāma vīsati yaṭṭhiyo. Tāya saññāyāti tāya pāsāṇasaññāya, “ettakaṃ
analyzed: atta kāmāḥ usabham nāma vīsati tāya saññāya ati tāya pāsāṇa saññāya ettakam
translated: “A bull” is twenty cubits. “By that sign” : by the sign of the stone, knowing “This is the extent of the place” is the idea.

original: ṭhānamāgatā”ti jānantāti adhippāyo. So eva nayo ayaṃ bhikkhūtiādiko yo ṭhāne vutto,
analyzed: ṭhānam āgatā ati jānantā ati adhippāyo saḥ eva nayaḥ ayam bhikkhu iti ādikaḥ yaḥ ṭhāne vutto
translated: The same method applies to the passage beginning “This monk” , which was stated in the place .

original: so eva nisajjāyapi nayo. Pacchato āgacchantānaṃ chinnabhattabhāvabhayenapi yonisomanasikāraṃ paribrūheti.
analyzed: eva pacchatas āgacchantānam yoni so manasikāram paribrūha iti
translated: The same method applies to sitting down. He exhorts proper attention also out of fear that those who come later may not get food.

original: Maddantāti dhaññakaraṇaṭṭhāne sālisīsāni maddantā. Mahāpadhānaṃ pūjessāmīti amhākaṃ
analyzed: maddanta ati dhañña karaṇa ṭṭhāne sāli sīsāni maddanta mahāpadhānam pūjessāmi iti amhākam
translated: “Threshing” : threshing the heads of rice in a threshing place. “I will worship the Great Preparation” :

original: atthāya lokanāthena cha vassāni kataṃ dukkaracariyaṃ evāhaṃ yathāsatti pūjessāmīti.🔽Paṭipattipūjā hi satthupūjā, na āmisapūjāti. Ṭhānacaṅkamamevāti adhiṭṭhātabbairiyāpathakālavasena🔽vuttaṃ, na bhojanādikālesu avassaṃ kātabbanisajjāya paṭikkhepavasena.🔽Vīthiṃ otaritvā ito cito anoloketvā paṭhamameva vīthiyo sallakkhetabbāti āha “vīthiyo
analyzed: atthāya lokanāthena cha vassāni katam dukkara cariyam eva aham yathāsatti pūjessāmi iti  paṭipatti pūjā hi satthu pūjā na āmisa pūjā iti ṭhāna caṅkamam eva ati adhiṭṭhātabba bairiyāpatha kāla vasena  vuttam na bhojana ādi kālesu avassam kātabba nisajjāya paṭikkhepa vasena  vīthim otaritvā itas citas anoloketvā paṭhamam eva vīthiyaḥ sallakkhetabbā ti āha vīthiyaḥ

original: sallakkhetvā”ti. Yaṃ sandhāya vuccati – “pāsādikena abhikkantenā”tiādi. Taṃ dassetuṃ🔽“tattha cā”tiādi vuttaṃ. Āhāre paṭikūlasaññaṃ upaṭṭhapetvātiādīsu yaṃ vattabbaṃ,🔽taṃ heṭṭhā vuttameva. Aṭṭhaṅgasamannāgatanti “yāvadeva imassa kāyassa ṭhitiyā”tiādinā🔽vuttehi aṭṭhahi aṅgehi samannāgataṃ katvā. Neva davāyātiādi pana paṭikkhepadassanaṃ.
analyzed: sallakkhetvā iti yam sandhāya vuccati pāsādikena abhikkantena atiādi tam dassetuṃ 🔽tattha ca itiādi vuttam āhāre paṭikūla saññam upaṭṭhapetvā ati ādīsu yam vattabbam 🔽tat heṭṭhā vuttam eva aṭṭhaṅga samannāgatan ti yāvat eva imassa kāyassa ṭhitiyā iti ādinā 🔽vuttehi aṭṭhahi aṅgehi samannāgatam katvā na iva davāya ati ādi pana paṭikkhepa dassanam

in the world, the One who has no counterpart in the world, the One who has no counterpart in the world, the One who has no counterpart

original: Paccekabodhiṃ sacchikaroti, yadi upanissayasampanno hotīti sambandho. Idañca yathā
analyzed: pacceka bodhim sacchikaroti yadi upanissaya sampannaḥ hoti iti sambandhaḥ idam ca yathā
translated: If he has the requisite conditions, he realizes the enlightenment of a Paccekabuddha.

original: heṭṭhā tīsu ṭhānesu, evaṃ ito paresu ṭhānesu upanetvā sambandhitabbaṃ. Tattha paccekabodhiyā
analyzed: heṭṭhā tīsu ṭhānesu evam itas paresu ṭhānesu upanetvā sambandhitabbam tattha pacceka bodhiyā
translated: This should be connected with the rest of the text in the same way as it has been connected with the first three instances.

original: upanissayasampadā kappānaṃ dve asaṅkhyeyyāni satasahassañca tajjaṃ puññañāṇasambhārasambharaṇaṃ,
analyzed: upanissaya sampadā kappānam dve asaṅkhyeyyāni sata sahassañca tajjam puññañāṇa sambhāra sambharaṇam
translated: Herein, the requisite conditions for the enlightenment of a Paccekabuddha are the accumulation of the requisite store of merit and knowledge during two incalculable ages and a hundred thousand aeons.

original: sāvakabodhiyaṃ aggasāvakānaṃ ekaṃ asaṅkhyeyyaṃ kappasatasahassañca, mahāsāvakānaṃ
analyzed: sāvaka bodhiyam aggasāvakānam ekam asaṅkhyeyyam kappa sata sahassam ca mahāsāvakānam
translated: For the enlightenment of a disciple, for the chief disciples it is during one incalculable age and a hundred thousand aeons,

original: kappasatasahassameva tajjaṃ sambhārasambharaṇaṃ, itaresaṃ atītāsu jātīsu vivaṭṭasannissayavasena🔽nibbattitaṃ nibbedhabhāgiyaṃ kusalaṃ. Bāhiyo dārucīriyoti bāhiyavisaye jātasaṃvaddhatāya
analyzed: kappa sata sahassam eva tajjam sambhāra sambharaṇam itaresam atītāsu jātīsu vivaṭṭa sannissaya vasena  nibbattitam nibbedha bhāgiyam kusalam bāhiyaḥ bāhiya visaye jāta saṃvaddha tāya
translated: and for the great disciples it is during a hundred thousand aeons. For the rest it is the profitable action that has arisen in the past, which is the condition for the emergence of the path,🔽by way of the “revolving of the foundation” .🔽Bāhiya of the Bark-cloth: he was called Bāhiya because he was born and grew up in the Bāhiya district, and he was called of the Bark-cloth because he had the name Dārucīriya .

original: bāhiyo, dārucīrapariharaṇena dārucīriyoti laddhasamañño. So hi āyasmā “tasmātiha
analyzed: bāhiyaḥ dāru cīra pariharaṇena dārucīriyaḥ iti laddha samañño saḥ hi tasmā ati ha
translated: For this venerable one had the name Dārucīriya because he wore a garment made of bark-cloth. He said:

original: te, bāhiya, evaṃ sikkhitabbaṃ – diṭṭhe diṭṭhamattaṃ bhavissatī”tiādivasappavattena🔽saṃkhitteneva ovādena khippataraṃ visesaṃ adhigacchi. Tena vuttaṃ “khippābhiñño vā
analyzed: te bāhiyaḥ evam sikkhitabbam diṭṭhe diṭṭha mattam bhavissati itiādi vasa ppavattena  saṃkhittena iva ovādena khippataram visesam adhigacchi tena vuttam khippa abhiññaḥ vā
translated: and he should be trained thus: “In what is seen there will be only what is seen” .🔽and he attained distinction more quickly by the brief exhortation. That is why it was said above, “or he is quick in attaining the deep knowledge, like the venerable Bahiya of the Bark-cloth, the elder” .

original: hoti seyyathāpi thero bāhiyo dārucīriyo”ti. Evaṃ mahāpañño vātiādīsu yathārahaṃ vattabbanti.🔽Tanti asammuyhanaṃ. Evanti idāni vuccamānākāradassanaṃ. Attā abhikkamatīti iminā🔽andhaputhujjanassa diṭṭhiggāhavasena abhikkame sammuyhanaṃ dasseti, ahaṃ abhikkamāmīti
analyzed: hoti seyyathā api theraḥ bāhiyaḥ dārucīriyaḥ ti evam mahā paññaḥ vā āti ādīsu yathāraham vattabbanti  tat ti a sammuyhanam evam ti idāni vuccamāna ākāra dassanam attā abhikkamati iti iminā  andha puthujjanassa diṭṭhi ggāha vasena abhikkame sammuyhanam dasseti aham abhikkamāmi iti
translated: So too with the rest of the terms beginning with “great understanding” .

original: pana iminā mānaggāhavasena, tadubhayaṃ pana taṇhāya vinā na hotīti taṇhāggāhavasenapi🔽sammuyhanaṃ dassitameva hoti, “tathā asammuyhanto”ti vatvā taṃ asammuyhanaṃ yena
analyzed: pana iminā māna ggāha vasena tat ubhayam pana taṇhāya vinā na hoti iti taṇhā ggāha vasena api  sammuyhanam dassitam eva hoti tathā a sammuyhantaḥ iti vatvā tam a sammuyhanam yena
translated: Tanti = without confusion. Evanti = seeing the way it is being spoken of now. Attā abhikkamatīti = by the expression “the self goes forth” he shows confusion by going forth in the grip of views of the blind worldling. Ahaṃ abhikkamāmīti = but by the expression “I go forth” he shows confusion by going forth in the grip of conceit. And both of these are not without craving, so confusion by going forth in the grip of craving is shown too.

original: ghanavinibbhogena hoti, taṃ dassento “abhikkamāmīti citte uppajjamāne”tiādimāha.
analyzed: ghana vinibbhogena hoti tam dassentaḥ abhikkamāmi iti citte uppajjamāna itiādim āha
translated: “Without confusion in this way” : having said this, he shows the way in which that confusion is absent by the penetration of compactness, saying “When the thought ‘I go forth’ arises” .

original: Tattha yasmā vāyodhātuyā anugatā tejodhātu uddharaṇassa paccayo. Uddharaṇagatikā
analyzed: tattha yasmā vāyodhātuyā anugatā tejodhātu uddharaṇassa paccayaḥ uddharaṇa gatikā
translated: Herein, since the fire element that accompanies the air element is a condition for lifting,🔽and since the fire element that moves upwards is a condition for carrying and conveying,

original: hi tejodhātūti uddharaṇe vāyodhātuyā tassā anugatabhāvo, tasmā imāsaṃ dvinnamettha
analyzed: hi uddharaṇe uddharaṇe tassa anugata bhāvaḥ
translated: the air element that accompanies the fire element is a condition for carrying and conveying.

original: dhātūnaṃ sāmatthiyato adhimattatā, itarāsañca omattatāti dassento “ekekapāduddharaṇe…pe…
analyzed: dhātūnam sāmatthiyataḥ adhimatta tā itarāsam ca omatta tā ati dassentaḥ ekeka pāda uddharaṇa īpe
translated: Therefore, showing that these two elements are predominant here by reason of their functional predominance, and that the others are not so, he said: “In the lifting of each step …🔽are strong.”

original: balavatiyo”ti āha. Yasmā pana tejodhātuyā anugatā vāyodhātu atiharaṇavītiharaṇānaṃ
analyzed: āha āha
translated: But since the air element that accompanies the fire element is a condition for carrying and conveying,🔽and since the air element that moves horizontally is a condition for carrying and conveying,

original: paccayo. Tiriyagatikāya hi vāyodhātuyā atiharaṇavītiharaṇesu sātisayo byāpāroti tejodhātuyā🔽tassānugatabhāvo, tasmā imāsaṃ dvinnamettha sāmatthiyato adhimattatā, itarāsañca
analyzed: paccayo tiriya gatikāya hi vāyodhātuyāḥ atiharaṇa vītiharaṇesu sa atisayaḥ byāpāraḥ ti tejaḥ dhātuyāḥ  tassa anugata bhāvaḥ tasmai imāsam adhimatta tā itarāsam ca
translated: the air element that accompanies the fire element is a condition for carrying and conveying.🔽Therefore, showing that these two elements are predominant here by reason of their functional predominance, and that the others are not so, he said: “So too in carrying and conveying.”

original: omattatāti dassento “tathā atiharaṇavītiharaṇesū”ti āha. Satipi anugamanānugantabbatāvisese
analyzed: omatta tā iti dassentaḥ tathā atiharaṇa vītiharaṇesu iti āha sati pi anugamana anugantabba tā visese
translated: Although there is no difference in the sense of being that which accompanies and that which is accompanied,

original: tejodhātuvāyodhātubhāvamattaṃ sandhāya tathā-saddaggahaṇaṃ.
analyzed: tejaḥ dhātu vāyaḥ dhātu bhāva mattam sandhāya
translated: the word “too” is used in order to refer to the mere fact of the fire element and the air element.

original: Tattha akkantaṭṭhānato pādassa ukkhipanaṃ uddharaṇaṃ, ṭhitaṭṭhānaṃ atikkamitvā purato🔽haraṇaṃ atiharaṇaṃ. Rukkhakhāṇuādipariharaṇatthaṃ, patiṭṭhitapādaghaṭṭanapariharaṇatthaṃ
analyzed: tattha akkanta ṭṭhānataḥ pādassa ukkhipanam uddharaṇam ṭhita ṭṭhānam atikkamitvā puratas  haraṇam atiharaṇam rukkha khāṇu ādi pariharaṇa attham patiṭṭhita pāda ghaṭṭana pariharaṇa attham
translated: moving it forward from the place where it is set is “shifting it”;🔽moving it sideways in order to avoid such things as stumps, or in order to avoid pressing down on the foot already set down, is “shifting sideways”.

original: vā passena haraṇaṃ vītiharaṇaṃ. Yāva patiṭṭhitapādo, tāva āharaṇaṃ atiharaṇaṃ, tato🔽paraṃ haraṇaṃ vītiharaṇanti ayaṃ vā etesaṃ viseso. Yasmā pathavīdhātuyā anugatā āpodhātu
analyzed: vā passena haraṇam vītiharaṇam yāva patiṭṭhita pādo tāva āharaṇam atiharaṇam tatas  param haraṇam ayam vai etesam visesaḥ ayam vai etesam visesaḥ anugatāḥ āpaḥ dhātu
translated: Or alternatively, moving it as far as the place where it is set down is “shifting it”, and moving it beyond that is “shifting sideways”. This is the difference between them.🔽Because the water element is the condition for the letting go of the earth element,

original: vossajjanassa paccayo. Garutarasabhāvā hi āpodhātūti vossajjane pathavīdhātuyā tassānugatabhāvo,
analyzed: vossajjanassa paccayaḥ garuta rasa bhāvā hi āpodhātu uti vossajjane pathavī dhātuyā tassa anugata bhāvaḥ
translated: and the water element has the characteristic of fluidity, the earth element is associated with it in the letting go.

original: tasmā tāsaṃ dvinnamettha sāmatthiyato adhimattatā, itarāsañca omattatāti dassento
analyzed: tasmā tāsam adhimatta tā itarāsam ca omatta tā ati dassentaḥ
translated: Therefore, in this context, these two elements are strong in their efficacy, and the other two are weak. Showing this,🔽he said, “In the letting go … they are strong” .

original: āha “vossajjane…pe… balavatiyo”ti. Yasmā pana āpodhātuyā anugatā pathavīdhātu sannikkhepanassa
analyzed: āha vossajja nepe balavatiyā iti yasmai pana āpodhātuyā anugatā pathavīdhātu sannikkhepanassa
translated: But because the earth element is associated with the water element, it is the condition for the placing down of the foot.

original: paccayo. Patiṭṭhābhāve viya patiṭṭhāpanepi tassā sātisayakiccattā āpodhātuyā tassā🔽anugatabhāvo, tathā ghaṭṭanakiriyāya pathavīdhātuyā vasena sannirumbhanassa sijjhanato
analyzed: paccayaḥ patiṭṭhā bhāve viya patiṭṭhāpane pi tassā sa atisaya kicca ttā āpodhātuyā tassā  anugata bhāvaḥ tathā ghaṭṭana kiriyāya pathavī dhātuyā vasena sannirumbhanassa sijjhanato
translated: And in the case of the act of supporting, the water element is subordinate to the earth element in the act of consolidating, which is the reason why the water element is said to be subordinate to the earth element in the act of consolidating.🔽And in the case of the act of consolidating, the earth element is subordinate to the air element in the act of shaking, which is the reason why the earth element is said to be subordinate to the air element in the act of shaking.

original: tatthāpi pathavīdhātuyā āpodhātuanugatabhāvo, tasmā vuttaṃ – “tathā sannikkhepanasannirumbhanesū”ti.
analyzed: tattha api pathavī dhātuyā āpodhātu anugata bhāvo tasmā vuttam tathā sannikkhepana sannirumbhanesu iti
translated: That is why it is said, “So too in the case of the acts of placing, consolidating, etc.”

original: Tatthāti tasmiṃ abhikkamane, tesu vā vuttesu uddharaṇādīsu chasu koṭṭhāsesu. Uddharaṇeti
analyzed: tattha ati tasmim abhikkamane tesu vā vuttesu uddharaṇa ādīsu chasu koṭṭhāsesu uddharaṇā iti
translated: “There” means in the act of lifting up, or in the six sections beginning with lifting up.🔽“Lifting up”: at the moment of lifting up.

original: uddharaṇakkhaṇe. Rūpārūpadhammāti uddharaṇākārena pavattā rūpadhammā taṃsamuṭṭhāpakā
analyzed: uddharaṇa kkhaṇe rūpa arūpa dhammā ti uddharaṇa ākārena pavattāḥ rūpa dhammāḥ tad samuṭṭhāpakā
translated: “Material and immaterial states”: material states occurring in the mode of lifting up, and the immaterial states that originate them.

original: arūpadhammā ca. Atiharaṇaṃ na pāpuṇanti khaṇamattāvaṭṭhānato. Tattha tatthevāti yattha
analyzed: arūpa dhammā ca atiharaṇam na pāpuṇanti khaṇa matta avaṭṭhānato tattha tattha iva ati yattha
translated: They do not reach the act of carrying, because they last only a moment.

original: yattha uppannā, tattha tattheva. Na hi dhammānaṃ desantarasaṅkamanaṃ atthi. Pabbaṃ
analyzed: yattha uppannā tattha tattha iva na hi dhammānam desa antara saṅkamanam atthi pabbam
translated: “There, there”: wherever they arise, there, there. For states do not move from place to place.

original: pabbantiādi uddharaṇādikoṭṭhāse sandhāya sabhāgasantativasena vuttanti veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: uddharaṇa ādi koṭṭhāse sandhāya sa bhāga santati vasena vuttan ti veditabbam
translated: “The rock, the rock”: this should be understood to be said according to the continuity of similar states in the sections beginning with lifting up.

original: Atiittaro hi rūpadhammānampi pavattikkhaṇo, gamanassādānaṃ devaputtānaṃ heṭṭhupariyāyena
analyzed: atiittaraḥ hi rūpa dhammānam pi pavatti kkhaṇaḥ gamanassa ādānam deva puttānam heṭṭhu pariyāyena
translated: For the moment of occurrence of material phenomena is more fleeting than the going and coming of the gods called “Swift” and “Swift-going,” who go back and forth

original: paṭimukhaṃ dhāvantānaṃ sirasi pāde ca baddhakhuradhārāsamāgamatopi sīghataro. Yathā🔽tilānaṃ bhajjiyamānānaṃ taṭataṭāyanena bhedo lakkhīyati, evaṃ saṅkhatadhammānaṃ uppādenāti
analyzed: paṭi mukham sirasi pāde ca baddha khura dhārā samāgamataḥ api sīghataraḥ yathā  tilānam bhajjiyamānānam taṭa taṭāyanena bhedaḥ lakkhīyati evam saṅkhata dhammānam uppādena ati
translated: between the world of the gods and the human world in an instant.

original: dassanatthaṃ “taṭataṭāyantā”ti vuttaṃ. Uppannā hi ekantato bhijjantīti.🔽Saddhiṃ rūpenāti idaṃ tassa tassa cittassa nirodhena saddhiṃ nirujjhanakarūpadhammavasena🔽vuttaṃ, yaṃ tato sattarasamacittassa uppādakkhaṇe uppannaṃ. Aññathā yadi rūpārūpadhammā
analyzed: dassana attham taṭataṭāyantā iti vuttam uppannāḥ hi ekantataḥ bhijjanti iti  saddhim rūpena ati idam tassa tassa cittassa nirodhena saddhim nirujjhanaka rūpa dhamma vasena  vuttam yam tatas sattarasama cittassa uppāda kkhaṇe uppannam aññathā yadi rūpa arūpa dhammā
translated: Just as the breaking up of sesame seeds being crushed is noticed by the sound “taṭataṭā,” so too, it is said that “taṭataṭā” in order to show the arising of conditioned phenomena.🔽For what has arisen breaks up without delay.🔽“Together with materiality”: this is said with reference to the material phenomena that cease together with the cessation of each consciousness,

original: samānakkhaṇā siyuṃ, “rūpaṃ garupariṇāmaṃ dandhanirodha”ntiādivacanehi virodho siyā.
analyzed: samāna kkhaṇāḥ siyum rūpam garu pariṇāmam virodhaḥ siyā
translated: which arise at the moment of arising of the seventeenth consciousness. Otherwise, if the material and immaterial phenomena were of the same moment, there would be a contradiction with the statement: “Materiality has slow change and slow cessation.”

original: Tathā – “nāhaṃ, bhikkhave, aññaṃ ekadhammampi samanupassāmi, yaṃ evaṃ lahuparivattaṃ,
analyzed: tathā na aham bhikkhave aññam eka dhammam pi samanupassāmi yam evam lahu parivattam
translated: So too: “Bhikkhus, I do not see even one other thing that is so quickly transformed as the mind.

original: yathayidaṃ citta”nti evamādipāḷiyā ca. Cittacetasikā hi sārammaṇasabhāvā yathābalaṃ🔽attano ārammaṇapaccayabhūtamatthaṃ vibhāventāyeva uppajjantīti tesaṃ taṃsabhāvanipphattianantaraṃ
analyzed: cittam ti evamādi pāḷiyā ca citta cetasikāḥ hi sa ārammaṇa sabhāvāḥ yathābalam  attanaḥ ārammaṇa paccaya bhūtam attham vibhāventāya iva uppajjanti iti tesam taṃsa bhāva nipphatti anantaram
translated: and so on. For mind and mental factors, which have an object, arise only by discerning the meaning that is the object condition for them, according to their strength.🔽So immediately next to the manifestation of their own individual essence,

original: nirodho, rūpadhammā pana anārammaṇā pakāsetabbā. Evaṃ tesaṃ pakāsetabbabhāvanipphatti
analyzed: nirodhaḥ rūpa dhammā pana anārammaṇāḥ pakāsetabbāḥ evam tesam pakāsetabba bhāva nipphatti
translated: and so on. For mind and mental factors, which have an object, arise only by revealing the meaning that is the object condition for them according to their respective strength. So their cessation is next to the fulfilment of their own nature. But the material phenomena, which have no object, must be demonstrated. So the fulfilment of their demonstration

original: soḷasahi cittehi hotīti taṅkhaṇāyukatā tesaṃ icchitā, lahukaviññāṇassa visayasaṅgatimattapaccayatāya🔽tiṇṇaṃ khandhānaṃ, visayasaṅgatimattatāya ca viññāṇassa lahuparivattitā, dandhamahābhūtapaccayatāya
analyzed: soḷasahi cittehi hoti iti taṅkhaṇa āyuka tā tesam icchitā lahuka viññāṇassa visaya saṅgati matta paccaya tāya  tiṇṇam khandhānam visaya saṅgatimatta tāya ca viññāṇassa lahu parivatti tā dandha mahābhūta paccaya tāya
translated: is by means of the sixteen kinds of consciousness. Thus their having a life of only a moment is intended. And because the condition for the three aggregates is merely the association with an object of the swift consciousness,🔽and because the condition for consciousness is merely the association with an object, there is swift revolution of the aggregates. But because the condition for the material phenomena is the slow revolution of the primary elements,

original: rūpadhammānaṃ dandhaparivattitā. Nānādhātuyā yathābhūtañāṇaṃ kho pana tathāgatasseva,
analyzed: rūpa dhammānam dandha parivatti tā nānā dhātuyā yathābhūta ñāṇam kho pana tathāgatassa iva
translated: the knowledge of how things are in the various elements belongs only to a Tathāgata.

original: tena ca purejātapaccayo rūpadhammova vutto, pacchājātapaccayo ca tassevāti rūpārūpadhammānaṃ
analyzed: tena ca purejāta paccayaḥ rūpa dhammaḥ uva vuttaḥ pacchājāta paccayaḥ ca tassa iva ati rūpa arūpa dhammānam
translated: And only he has stated the prenascent condition as a material phenomenon and the postnascent condition as that same material phenomenon. So the material and immaterial states🔽are

original: samānakkhaṇatā na yujjateva, tasmā vuttanayenevettha attho veditabbo.
analyzed: samāna kkhaṇa tā na tasmā vutta nayena iva ittha atthaḥ veditabbaḥ
translated: and the same moment is not tenable. Therefore the meaning should be understood in the way stated.

original: Aññaṃ uppajjate cittaṃ, aññaṃ cittaṃ nirujjhatīti yaṃ purimuppannaṃ cittaṃ, taṃ aññaṃ,
analyzed: aññam uppajjate cittam aññam cittam nirujjhati iti yat purima uppannam cittam tam aññam
translated: “Another consciousness arises, another ceases”: the consciousness that arose first is one,

original: taṃ pana nirujjhantaṃ aparassa anantarādipaccayo hutvā eva nirujjhatīti tathāladdhapaccayaṃ
analyzed: tam pana nirujjhantam aparassa anantara ādi paccayaḥ hutvā eva nirujjhati iti tathā laddha paccayam
translated: but it ceases having become a condition for the arising of another, which is different from it.

original: aññaṃ uppajjate cittaṃ. Yadi evaṃ tesaṃ antaro labbheyyāti, noti āha “avīcimanupabandho”ti.🔽Yathā vīci antaro na labbhati, “tadeveta”nti avisesavidū maññanti, evaṃ anu anu pabandho
analyzed: aññam uppajjate cittam yadi evam tesam antaraḥ labbheyya iti no ti āha avīcim an upabandho ti  yathā vīci antaraḥ na labbhati avisesa vidū maññanti evam anu anu pabandho
translated: If that is so, then there must be an interval between them.

original: cittasantāno rūpasantāno ca nadīsotova nadiyaṃ udakappavāho viya vattati.🔽Abhimukhaṃ lokitaṃ ālokitanti āha “puratopekkhana”nti. Yasmā yaṃdisābhimukho gacchati
analyzed: citta santānaḥ rūpa santāno ca nadī sotaḥ uva nadiyam udaka ppavāhaḥ viya vattati  abhimukham lokitam ālokitanti āha puratas upekkhananti yasmai yaṃdisā abhimukhaḥ gacchati
translated: “There is no interval”: just as there is no interval between the waves of a river, so too the stream of consciousness and the stream of materiality go on in succession like the flow of water in a river.🔽“Looking straight on is looking in front”: looking in front is looking straight on, because one goes, stands, or sits looking straight on.

original: tiṭṭhati nisīdati vā, tadabhimukhaṃ pekkhanaṃ ālokitaṃ, tasmā tadanugataṃ vidisālokanaṃ
analyzed: tiṭṭhati nisīdati vā tad abhimukham pekkhanam ālokitam tasmai tad anugatam vidisā ālokanam
translated: Therefore looking in the other directions that follows after that is looking sideways.

original: vilokitanti āha “vilokitaṃ nāma anudisāpekkhana”nti. Sammajjanaparibhaṇḍādikaraṇe
analyzed: vilokitam iti āha vilokitam nāma anudisā apekkhananti sammajjana paribhaṇḍa ādi karaṇe
translated: “Looking around” is looking in all directions.🔽“Looking back” is looking back to avoid danger from the rear.🔽“Looking straight on” is looking straight on to avoid danger in front.🔽“Looking to the side” is looking to the side to avoid danger on the side.

original: olokitassa, ullokāharaṇādīsu ullokitassa, pacchato āgacchantassa parissayassa parivajjanādivasena
analyzed: olokitassa ulloka āharaṇa ādīsu ullokitassa pacchatas āgacchantassa parissayassa parivajjana ādi vasena
translated: “Looking all around” is looking in all directions.

original: apalokitassa ca siyā sambhavoti āha – “iminā vā mukhena sabbānipi tāni gahitānevā”ti.
analyzed: apalokitassa ca siyā sambhavaḥ ti āha iminā vā mukhena sabbāni api tāni gahitāni eva ati
translated: “Looking around” is looking in all directions.🔽“Looking straight on” is looking straight on to avoid danger in front.🔽“Looking to the side” is looking to the side to avoid danger on the side.🔽“Looking all around” is looking in all directions.🔽“Looking around” is looking in all directions.🔽“Looking straight on” is looking straight on to avoid danger in front.🔽“Looking to the side” is looking to the side to avoid danger on the side.🔽“Looking all around” is looking in all directions.🔽“Looking around” is looking in all directions.🔽“Looking straight on” is looking straight on to avoid danger in front.🔽“Looking to the side” is looking to the side to avoid danger on the side.🔽“Looking all around” is looking in all directions.🔽“Looking around” is looking in all directions.🔽“Looking straight on” is looking straight on to avoid danger in front.🔽“Looking to the side” is looking to the side to avoid danger on the side.🔽“Looking all around” is looking in all directions.🔽“Looking around” is looking in all directions.🔽“Looking straight on” is looking straight on to avoid danger in front.🔽“Looking to the side” is looking to the side to avoid danger on the side.🔽“Looking all around” is looking in all directions.

original: Kāyasakkhinti kāyena sacchikatavantaṃ, paccakkhakārinanti attho. Sohāyasmā vipassanākāle
analyzed: kāya sakkhinti kāyena sacchikatavantam paccakkha kārinam ti attho saḥ u ha ayasmai vipassanā kāle
translated: “Looking around” is looking in all directions.

original: eva “yamevāhaṃ indriyesu aguttadvārataṃ nissāya sāsane anabhiratiādivippakāraṃ patto,
analyzed: eva yam eva aham indriyesu a gutta dvāra tam nissāya sāsane anabhirati ādi vippakāram patto
translated: “Looking straight on” is looking straight on to avoid danger in front.🔽“Looking to the side” is looking to the side to avoid danger on the side.🔽“Looking all around” is looking in all directions.🔽“Looking around” is looking in all directions.🔽“Looking straight on” is looking straight on to avoid danger in front.🔽“Looking to the side” is looking to the side to avoid danger on the side.

original: tameva suṭṭhu niggahessāmī”ti ussāhajāto balavahirottappo, tattha ca katādhikārattā
analyzed: tam eva suṭṭhu niggahessāmi iti ussāha jātaḥ bala vahira uttappaḥ tattha ca kata adhikāra ttā
translated: “Looking all around” is looking in all directions.🔽“Looking around” is looking in all directions.🔽“Looking straight on” is looking straight on to avoid danger in front.

original: indriyasaṃvare ukkaṃsapāramippatto, teneva naṃ satthā – “etadaggaṃ, bhikkhave, mama🔽sāvakānaṃ bhikkhūnaṃ indriyesu guttadvārānaṃ yadidaṃ nando”ti etadagge ṭhapesi.
analyzed: indriya saṃvare ukkaṃsa pārami patto tena iva nam satthā etat aggam bhikkhave mama 🔽sāvakānam bhikkhūnam indriyesu gutta dvārānam yat idam nando ti etad agge ṭhapesi
translated: “Looking to the side”

original: Sātthakatā ca sappāyatā ca veditabbā ālokitavilokitassāti ānetvā sambandho. Tasmāti
analyzed: sa atthaka tā ca sappāya tā ca veditabbā ālokita vilokitassa ati ānetvā sambandhaḥ tasmā ati
translated: And the meaning should be understood as “the state of being beneficial and the state of being suitable” in the sense of “looking and seeing.”

original: kammaṭṭhānāvijahanasseva gocarasampajaññabhāvatoti vuttamevatthaṃ hetubhāvena paccāmasati.🔽Attano kammaṭṭhānavaseneva ālokanavilokanaṃ kātabbaṃ, khandhādikammaṭṭhānikehi añño
analyzed: kammaṭṭhāna avijahanassa iva gocara sampajañña bhāvato ti vuttam evattham hetu bhāvena paccāmasati  attanaḥ kammaṭṭhāna vasena iva ālokana vilokanam kātabbam khandha ādi kammaṭṭhānikehi aññaḥ
translated: “Therefore” : this is a reason for the meaning already stated, namely, that the state of being mindful is the same as the state of being clearly comprehending the domain.🔽The intention is this: looking and seeing should be done only according to one’s meditation subject; one who has the aggregates, etc., as his meditation subject should not seek another method.

original: upāyo na gavesitabboti adhippāyo. Yasmā ālokitādisamaññāpi dhammamattasseva pavattiviseso,
analyzed: upāyaḥ na gavesitabbaḥ ti adhippāyaḥ yasmai ālokita ādi samaññā api dhamma mattassa iva pavatti viseso
translated: Since the mere states of looking, etc., are only a particular way of occurrence of the same dhammas,

original: tasmā tassa yāthāvato pajānanaṃ asammohasampajaññanti dassetuṃ “abbhantare”tiādi
analyzed: tasmā tassa yāthāvataḥ pajānanam a sammoha sampajaññanti dassetum abbhantara itiādi
translated: in order to show that the state of being clearly comprehending without confusion is the act of understanding that in accordance with actuality, it is said, “Inwardly” , etc.

original: vuttaṃ. Cittakiriyavāyodhātuvipphāravasenāti kiriyamayacittasamuṭṭhānavāyodhātuyā
analyzed: vuttam citta kiriya vāyodhātu vipphāra vasena ati kiriya maya citta samuṭṭhāna vāyodhātuyā
translated: By the force of the air element in the form of mental activity: by the occurrence of the air element in the form of mental activity, which is originated by the mind.

original: calanākārapavattivasena. Adho sīdatīti thokaṃ otarati. Uddhaṃ laṅghetīti laṅghantaṃ🔽viya upari gacchati.
analyzed: calana ākāra pavatti vasena adhas sīdati iti thokam otarati uddham laṅgheti iti laṅghantam  viyaḥ upari gacchati
translated: It sinks downwards: it descends a little. It rises upwards: it goes up as if floating.

original: Aṅgakiccaṃ sādhayamānanti padhānabhūtaṃ aṅgakiccaṃ nipphādentaṃ, upapattibhavassa
analyzed: aṅga kiccam sādhayamānanti padhāna bhūtam aṅga kiccam nipphādentam upapatti bhavassa
translated: Performing the function of a factor: producing the function of a factor that is the principal factor.

original: sarīraṃ hutvāti attho. Paṭhamajavanepi…pe… sattamajavanepi na hotīti idaṃ pañcadvāraviññāṇavīthiyaṃ🔽“itthī puriso”ti rajjanādīnaṃ abhāvaṃ sandhāya vuttaṃ. Tattha hi āvajjanavoṭṭhabbanānaṃ🔽ayoniso āvajjanavoṭṭhabbanavasena iṭṭhe itthirūpādimhi lobhamattaṃ, aniṭṭhe paṭighamattaṃ
analyzed: sarīram hutvā ti na hoti iti idam pañca dvāra viññāṇa vīthiyam  itthī purisaḥ iti rajjana ādīnam abhāvam sandhāya vuttam tattha hi āvajjana voṭṭhabbanānam  ayonisas āvajjana voṭṭhabbana vasena iṭṭhe itthi rūpa ādimhi lobha mattam aniṭṭhe paṭigha mattam
translated: and the body is burnt up.

original: uppajjati. Manodvāre pana “itthī puriso”ti rajjanādi hoti, tassa pañcadvārajavanaṃ🔽mūlaṃ, yathāvuttaṃ vā sabbaṃ bhavaṅgādi. Evaṃ manodvārajavanassa mūlabhūtadhammaparijānanavaseneva
analyzed: uppajjati manaḥ dvāre pana itthī puriso ti rajjana ādi hoti tassa pañca dvāra javanam  mūlam yathā vuttam vā sabbam bhavaṅga ādi evam manaḥ dvāra javanassa mūla bhūta dhamma parijānana vasena iva
translated: In the first impulsion, and so on up to the seventh impulsion, there is no lust, no hate, no delusion, no greed-rooted volition, no hate-rooted volition, no ignorance-rooted volition, no lust, no hate, no delusion, no greed, no hate, no delusion, no greed-rooted contact, no hate-rooted contact, no delusion-rooted contact, no greed-rooted feeling, no hate-rooted feeling, no delusion-rooted feeling, no greed-rooted craving, no hate-rooted craving, no delusion-rooted craving, no greed-rooted pursuit, no hate-rooted pursuit, no delusion-rooted pursuit, no greed-rooted determination, no hate-rooted determination, no delusion-rooted determination, no greed-rooted thinking, no hate-rooted thinking, no delusion-rooted thinking, no greed-rooted application, no hate-rooted application, no delusion-rooted application, no greed-rooted registration, no hate-rooted registration, no delusion-rooted registration, no greed-rooted root, no hate-rooted root, no delusion-rooted root, no greed-rooted root cause, no hate-rooted root cause, no delusion-rooted root cause, no greed-rooted condition, no hate-rooted condition, no delusion-rooted condition, no greed-rooted characteristic, no hate-rooted characteristic, no delusion-rooted characteristic, no greed-rooted manifestation, no hate-rooted manifestation, no delusion-rooted manifestation, no greed-rooted appearance, no hate-rooted appearance, no delusion-rooted appearance, no greed-rooted birth, no hate-rooted birth, no delusion-rooted birth, no greed-rooted ageing, no hate-rooted ageing, no delusion-rooted ageing, no greed-rooted dissolution, no hate-rooted dissolution, no delusion-rooted dissolution, no greed-rooted fall, no hate-rooted fall, no delusion-rooted fall, no greed-rooted reversal, no hate-rooted reversal, no delusion-rooted reversal, no greed-rooted transformation, no hate-rooted transformation, no delusion-rooted transformation, no greed-rooted change, no hate-rooted change, no delusion-rooted change.🔽This is said in order to show the non-existence of lust, etc., in the cognitive series of the five doors.

original: mūlapariññā vuttā, āgantukatāvakālikatā pana pañcadvārajavanasseva apubbabhāvavasena🔽ceva ittarabhāvavasena ca vuttā. Heṭṭhupariyavasena bhijjitvā patitesūti heṭṭhimassa🔽uparimassa ca aparāparaṃ bhaṅgappattimāha.
analyzed: mūla pariññā vuttā āgantuka tā avakālika tā pana pañca dvāra javanassa iva apubba bhāva vasena 🔽ca iva ittara bhāva vasena ca vuttā heṭṭhu pariya vasena bhijjitvā patitesu iti heṭṭhimassa 🔽uparimassa ca apara aparam bhaṅga ppattim āha
translated: For in the five-door adverting and in the impulsion that occurs next to it there is mere greed for a desirable visible datum, etc., or mere resentment

original: Tanti javanaṃ. Tassa javanassa na yuttanti sambandho. Āgantuko abbhāgato. Udayabbayaparicchinno tāvatako kālo etesanti tāvakālikāni.
analyzed: tanti javanam tassa javanassa na yuttanti sambandhaḥ āgantukaḥ abbhāgataḥ udaya bbaya paricchinno tāvatakaḥ kālaḥ etesanti tāvakālikāni
translated: “Tanti javanaṃ” means “the impulsion”. The construction is: “it is not suitable for that impulsion”. “Āgantuko abbhāgato” means “the visitor has come”. “Tāvakālikāni” means “the time is limited to that extent by rise and fall”.

original: Etaṃ asammohasampajaññaṃ. Samavāyeti sāmaggiyaṃ. Tatthāti pañcakkhandhavasena ālokanavilokane🔽paññāyamāne tabbinimutto – ko eko āloketi, ko viloketi. Upanissayapaccayoti idaṃ
analyzed: etam a sammoha sampajaññam samavāya iti sāmaggiyam tattha āti pañca kkhandha vasena ālokana vilokane  paññāyamāne tad binimuttaḥ kaḥ ekaḥ āloketi kaḥ viloketi upanissaya paccayo ti idam
translated: This is the clear comprehension of non-delusion. “Samavāyeti sāmaggiyaṃ” means “the combination is combined”. “Tattha” means “in the looking forwards and looking backwards that occur by way of the five aggregates”.

original: suttantanayena pariyāyato vuttaṃ. Sahajātapaccayoti nidassanamattametaṃ aññamaññasampayuttaatthiavigatādipaccayānampi labbhanato.
analyzed: suttanta nayena pariyāyataḥ vuttam sahajāta paccayaḥ ti nidassanamattam etam aññam añña sampayutta atthi avigata ādi paccayānam pi labbhanato
translated: “Ko eko āloketi, ko viloketi” means “who is it that looks forwards and looks backwards?” “Upanissayapaccayo” means “the decisive-support condition”. This is said by way of the method of the sutta. “Sahajātapaccayo” is only an indication, because the other conditions such as mutuality, association, presence, non-disappearance, etc., are also applicable.

original: Kāleti samiñjituṃ yuttakāle samiñjantassa, tathā pasāretuṃ yuttakāle pasārentassa. “Maṇisappo nāma ekā sappajātī”ti vadanti. Laḷananti kampanaṃ, līḷākaraṇaṃ vā.
analyzed: kāleti samiñjitum yutta kāle samiñjantassa tathā pasāretum yutta kāle pasārentassa maṇisappaḥ nāma ekā sappa jātī iti vadanti laḷanam ati kampanam līḷā karaṇam vā
translated: “Kāleti” means “at the time suitable for bending, he bends; at the time suitable for stretching, he stretches”. “Maṇisappo nāma ekā sappajātī” means “the jewel-snake is a kind of snake”. “Laḷan” means “shaking”, or “playing”.

original: Uṇhapakatiko pariḷāhabahulakāyo. Sīlassa vidūsanena ahitāvahattā micchājīvavasena
analyzed: uṇha pakatiko pariḷāha bahula kāyo sīlassa vidūsanena ahita āvaha tā micchājīva vasena
translated: “Uṇhapakatiko pariḷāhabahulakāyo” means “he is of hot nature, his body is full of fever”. “Micchājīvena ahitāvahanato” means “because of bringing harm by wrong livelihood”.

original: uppannaṃ asappāyaṃ. “Cīvarampi acetana”ntiādinā cīvarassa viya kāyopi acetanoti kāyassa
analyzed: uppannam asappāyam cīvaram pi acetana nti ādinā cīvarassa viya kāyaḥ api acetanoti kāyassa
translated: “The robe is not a self” and so on, the body is also not a self.

original: attasuññatāvibhāvanena “abbhantare”tiādinā vuttamevatthaṃ paridīpento itarītarasantosassa
analyzed: atta suñña tā vibhāvanena abbhantara iti ādinā vuttam eva attham paridīpentaḥ itarītara santosassa
translated: By the development of the emptiness of self in the body, he shows the meaning stated by “in the body” and so on.

original: kāraṇaṃ dasseti. Tenāha “tasmā”tiādi.
analyzed: kāraṇam tena āha tasmā itiādi
translated: He shows the reason for being satisfied with whatever is obtained. Therefore he says “therefore” and so on.

original: Catupañcagaṇṭhikāhatoti āhatacatupañcagaṇṭhiko, catupañcagaṇṭhikāhi vā hatasobho.🔽Aṭṭhavidhopi atthoti aṭṭhavidhopi payojanaviseso. Mahāsivattheravādavasena “imassa
analyzed: catu pañca gaṇṭhikā āhataḥ iti āhata catu pañca gaṇṭhikaḥ vā  aṭṭhavidhaḥ api attho ti aṭṭhavidhaḥ api payojana visesaḥ mahā siva thera vāda vasena imassa
translated: He is struck by four or five blows: he is struck by four or five blows, or he is struck by four or five blows.🔽The eight kinds of meaning: the eight kinds of special purpose.

original: kāyassa ṭhitiyā”tiādinā nayena vutto daṭṭhabbo. Imasmiṃ pakkhe “neva davāyātiādinā
analyzed: kāyassa ṭhitiyā iti ādinā nayena vuttaḥ daṭṭhabbaḥ imasmin pakkhe na iva davāya ati ādinā
translated: According to the view of the Elder Maha Sivaka, it should be seen in the way stated by “for the continuance of this body” and so on.

original: nayenā”ti pana idaṃ paṭikkhepaṅgadassanamukhena pāḷi āgatāti katvā vuttanti daṭṭhabbaṃ.
analyzed: nayena āti pana idam paṭikkhepa aṅga dassana mukhena āgatā iti katvā vuttanti daṭṭhabbaṃ
translated: In this case, “by the way beginning with ‘not for play’” should be seen as stated in the text by the method of showing the reason for the rejection.

original: Pathavīsandhārakajalassa taṃsandhārakavāyunā viya paribhuttassa āhārassa vāyodhātuyāva
analyzed: pathavī sandhāraka jalassa tad sandhāraka vāyunā viya paribhuttassa āhārassa
translated: The air element in the body is like the water that supports the earth, which is supported by the air. The food that is eaten is supported by the air element.

original: āsaye avaṭṭhānanti āha – “vāyodhātuvaseneva tiṭṭhatī”ti. Atiharatīti yāva mukhā abhiharati.
analyzed: āsaye avaṭṭhānanti āha vāyo dhātu vasena iva tiṭṭhati iti atiharati iti yāva mukhā abhiharati
translated: It is “not fixed in the receptacle” means it is not fixed in the receptacle of the body. “It is only by means of the air element that it remains” means it remains only by means of the air element.🔽“It carries it out” means it carries it out as far as the mouth.

original: Vītiharatīti tato kucchiyaṃ vimissaṃ karonto harati. Atiharatīti vā mukhadvāraṃ atikkāmento
analyzed: vītiharati iti tatas kucchiyam vimissam karontaḥ harati atiharati iti vā mukha dvāram atikkāmento
translated: “It carries it through” means it carries it through, mixing it in the stomach. Or alternatively, “it carries it out” means it carries it out by going beyond the door of the mouth.

original: harati. Vītiharatīti kucchigataṃ passato harati. Parivattetīti aparāparaṃ cāreti.
analyzed: harati vītiharati iti kucchi gatam passataḥ harati parivatteti iti apara aparam cāreti
translated: “It carries it through” means it carries it through by going beyond the stomach. “It turns it over” means it turns it over again and again.

original: Ettha ca āhārassa dhāraṇaparivattanasañcuṇṇanavisosanāni pathavīdhātusahitā eva vāyodhātu
analyzed: ettha ca āhārassa dhāraṇa parivattana sañcuṇṇana visosanāni pathavī dhātu sahitā eva vāyo dhātu
translated: And here the air element performs the functions of holding, turning over, grinding, and cleansing the nutriment together with the earth element.

original: karoti, na kevalāti tāni pathavīdhātuyā kiccabhāvena vuttāni, sā eva dhāraṇādīni🔽kiccāni karontassa sādhāraṇāti vuttāni. Allattañca anupāletīti yathā vāyodhātuādīhi🔽aññehi visosanaṃ na hoti, tathā anupāleti allabhāvaṃ. Tejodhātūti gahaṇīsaṅkhātā
analyzed: karoti na kevalā ti tāni pathavī dhātuyā kicca bhāvena vuttāni eva dhāraṇā ādīni  kiccāni karontassa vuttāni anupāleti iti yathā vāyodhātu ādīhi  aññehi visosanam na hoti tathā anupāla iti alla bhāvam tejaḥ dhātu iti gahaṇī saṅkhātā
translated: It does not do so alone. Therefore the earth element is mentioned as performing the function of holding, etc.,🔽because it is the common factor in all the functions. “It prevents it from dripping out” means it prevents it from dripping out by not allowing it to be cleansed by the air element, etc.,🔽in such a way that it would drip out. “The fire element” is the fire element called “that which is to be eaten.”

original: tejodhātu. Sā hi antopaviṭṭhaṃ āhāraṃ paripāceti. Añjaso hotīti āhārassa pavisanādīnaṃ
analyzed: tejaḥ dhātu sā hi anta upaviṭṭham āhāram paripāceti añjasas hoti iti āhārassa pavisana ādīnam
translated: For that ripens the nutriment that is inside. “It makes it soft” means it makes it soft by not allowing it to become hard by the earth element, etc.,

original: maggo hoti. Ābhujatīti pariyesanavasena, ajjhoharaṇajiṇṇājiṇṇatādipaṭisaṃvedanavasena
analyzed: maggaḥ hoti ābhujati iti pariyesana vasena ajjhoharaṇa jiṇṇa ajiṇṇa tā ādi paṭisaṃvedana vasena
translated: It is the path. He adverts: he adverts by way of seeking and by way of experiencing the eaten and the eaten-up, etc.,

original: ca āvajjeti, vijānātīti attho. Taṃtaṃvijānanassa paccayabhūtoyeva hi payogo “sammāpayogo”ti
analyzed: ca āvajjeti vijānāti iti attho taṃ taṃ vijānanassa paccaya bhūtaḥ yā iva hi payogo sammā payogo ti
translated: The meaning is that he cognizes. For it is only the act that is a condition for the cognizing of this or that that is called “right effort.”

original: vutto. Yena hi payogena pariyesanādi nipphajjati, so tabbisayavijānanampi nipphādeti
analyzed: vuttaḥ yena hi payogena pariyesana ādi nipphajjati saḥ tad visaya vijānanam pi nipphādeti
translated: For the act by means of which seeking, etc., is produced also produces the consciousness that has that as its object,

original: nāma tadavinābhāvato. Atha vā sammāpayogaṃ sammāpaṭipattiṃ anvāya āgamma ābhujati
analyzed: nāma tad avinābhāvataḥ atha vā sammā payogam sammā paṭipattim anvāya āgamma ābhujati
translated: because the name is inseparable from it. Or alternatively, he adverts by following, by coming by, right effort, right practice.

original: samannāharati. Ābhogapubbako hi sabbopi viññāṇabyāpāroti tathā vuttaṃ.🔽Gamanatoti bhikkhācāravasena gocaragāmaṃ uddissa gamanato. Pariyesanatoti gocaragāme
analyzed: samannāharati ābhoga pubbakaḥ hi sabbaḥ api viññāṇa byāpāraḥ ti tathā vuttam  gamanato ti bhikkhā cāra vasena gocara gāmam uddissa gamanato pariyesanato ti gocara gāme
translated: For all consciousness-concomitants are included in adverting, it is said.🔽By going: by going to the village where alms are given, by way of the alms round.🔽By seeking: by wandering for alms in the village where alms are given.

original: bhikkhatthaṃ āhiṇḍanato. Paribhogatoti āhārassa paribhuñjanato. Āsayatoti pittādiāsayato.
analyzed: bhikkha attham āhiṇḍanataḥ paribhogataḥ ti āhārassa paribhuñjanataḥ āsayataḥ ti pitta ādi āsayataḥ
translated: By using: by using the food. By location: by location in bile, etc.,

original: Āsayati ettha ekajjhaṃ pavattamānopi kammabalavavatthito hutvā mariyādavasena aññamaññaṃ
analyzed: āsayati ettha ekajjham pavattamānaḥ api kamma bala vavatthitaḥ hutvā mariyāda vasena aññam aññam
translated: though occurring together, is distinguished by the force of kamma and is defined by the limits of each.

original: asaṅkarato sayati tiṭṭhati pavattatīti āsayo, āmāsayassa upari tiṭṭhanako pittādiko.🔽Mariyādattho hi ayamākāro. Nidheti yathābhutto āhāro nicito hutvā tiṭṭhati etthāti🔽nidhānaṃ, āmāsayo, tato nidhānato. Aparipakkatoti gahaṇīsaṅkhātena kammajatejena🔽avipakkato. Paripakkatoti yathābhuttassa āhārassa vipakkabhāvato. Phalatoti nipphattito.
analyzed: asaṅkarataḥ sayati tiṭṭhati pavattati iti āsayaḥ āma āsayassa upari tiṭṭhanako pitta ādiko  mariyādattho hi ayam ākāraḥ nidheti yathābhuttaḥ āhāraḥ nicitaḥ hutvā tiṭṭhati ettha ati  nidhānam tatas nidhānataḥ a paripakkato ti gahaṇī saṅkhātena kamma ja tejena  a vipakkato paripakkato ti yathābhuttassa āhārassa vipakka bhāvato phalato ti nipphattito
translated: It is a receptacle because it lies, stays, and occurs without confusion. It is the bile, etc., that lie above the receptacle of digested food.🔽For this is the meaning of the term “receptacle”: it is a store because what is eaten is stored there and lies there in a collected state.🔽It is a receptacle because it is a storehouse. It is undigested because it is not digested by the fire element that is the cause of digestion, which is a kind of action originating in kamma.🔽It is digested because it is digested by the fire element that is the cause of digestion. It is the outcome because it is the result.

original: Nissandatoti ito cito ca vissandanato. Sammakkhanatoti sabbaso makkhanato. Ayamettha🔽saṅkhepo, vitthāro pana visuddhimaggasaṃvaṇṇanāya gahetabbo.🔽Sarīrato sedā muccantīti vegasandhāraṇena uppannapariḷāhato sarīrato sedā muccanti.🔽Aññe ca rogā kaṇṇasūlabhagandarādayo. Aṭṭhāneti manussāmanussapariggahe ayuttaṭṭhāne
analyzed: nissandato ti itas ca itas ca vissandanato sammakkhanato ti sabbaso makkhanato ayam ettha 🔽saṅkhepaḥ vitthāraḥ pana visuddhi magga saṃvaṇṇanāya gahetabbo 🔽sarīrataḥ sedāḥ muccanti iti vega sandhāraṇena uppanna pariḷāhataḥ sarīrataḥ sedāḥ muccanti 🔽aññe ca rogā kaṇṇa sūla bhagandara ādayaḥ aṭṭhāne iti manussa amanussa pariggahe ayutta ṭṭhāne

original: khettadevāyatanādike. Kuddhā hi manussā amanussāpi vā jīvitakkhayaṃ pāpenti. Vissaṭṭhattā
analyzed: khetta devāyatana ādike kuddhāḥ hi manussāḥ amanussāḥ api vā jīvita khayam pāpenti vissaṭṭha ttā
translated: in a field, a shrine, etc. For angry men and spirits can kill him.🔽Because it is not his own, and because it is not given by anyone else, and because it is disgusting,

original: neva tassa bhikkhuno attano, kassaci anissajjitattā jigucchanīyattā ca na parassa,
analyzed: na iva tassa bhikkhuno attanaḥ kassaci a nissajjita ttā jigucchanīya ttā ca na parassa
translated: it is not the other’s.

original: udakatumbatoti veḷunāḷiādiudakabhājanato. Tanti chaḍḍitaudakaṃ.🔽Ettha ca eko iriyāpatho dvīsu ṭhānesu āgato, so pubbe abhikkamapaṭikkamagahaṇena.
analyzed: udaka tumbataḥ iti veḷu nāḷi ādi udaka bhājanataḥ tanti chaḍḍita audakam  ettha ca ekaḥ iriyāpathaḥ dvīsu ṭhānesu āgato so pubbe abhikkama paṭikkama gahaṇena
translated: From a water-vessel: from a bamboo tube, etc., used as a water-vessel. That: the water that has been thrown out.🔽And here one bodily formation has been given in two places, namely, in the first and second sections.🔽“In going forwards and returning: in the act of going forwards and in the act of coming back.🔽In going forwards and coming back: in the act of going forwards and in the act of coming back.

original: “Gamanepi purato pacchato ca kāyassa abhiharaṇaṃ vuttanti idha gamanameva gahita”nti
analyzed: gamane pi puratas pacchatas ca kāyassa abhiharaṇam vuttanti idha gamanam eva gahitanti
translated: In looking straight on and in looking away: in the act of looking straight on and in the act of looking away.🔽In bending and in stretching: in the act of bending and in the act of stretching.

original: apare. Yasmā idha sampajaññakathāyaṃ asammohasampajaññameva dhuraṃ, tasmā antarantare
analyzed: apare yasmai idha a sammoha sampajaññam eva dhuram tasmai antar antare
translated: In wearing the outer cloak, the upper robe, and the inner clothing: in the act of wearing the outer cloak, the upper robe, and the inner clothing.🔽In eating, drinking, chewing, and savouring: in the act of eating, drinking, chewing, and savouring.🔽In passing excrement and urine: in the act of passing excrement and urine.

original: iriyāpathe pavattānaṃ rūpārūpadhammānaṃ tattha tattheva nirodhadassanavasena sampajānakāritā
analyzed: iriyāpathe pavattānam rūpa arūpa dhammānam tattha tattha iva nirodha dassana vasena sampajāna kāri tā
translated: In walking, standing, sitting, falling asleep, waking, talking, and keeping silent: in the act of walking, standing, sitting, falling asleep, waking, talking, and keeping silent.

original: gahitāti. Majjhimabhāṇakā pana evaṃ vadanti – eko hi bhikkhu gacchanto aññaṃ cintento,
analyzed: gahitā ti majjhima bhāṇakā pana evam vadanti ekaḥ hi bhikkhu gacchantaḥ aññam cintentaḥ
translated: The Majjhima reciters say that one bhikkhu, while going, thinks thus: ‘I am going.’

original: aññaṃ vitakkento gacchati, eko kammaṭṭhānaṃ avissajjetvāva gacchati, tathā eko tiṭṭhanto,
analyzed: aññam vitakkentaḥ gacchati ekaḥ kammaṭṭhānam a vissajjetvā ava gacchati tathā ekaḥ tiṭṭhantaḥ
translated: He goes thinking of something else, he goes without giving up his meditation subject. So too the other three.

original: nisīdanto, sayanto aññaṃ cintento, aññaṃ vitakkento sayati, eko kammaṭṭhānaṃ avissajjetvāva🔽sayati. Ettakena pana na pākaṭaṃ hotīti caṅkamanena dīpenti. Yo bhikkhu caṅkamanaṃ
analyzed: nisīdantaḥ sayantaḥ aññam cintentaḥ aññam vitakkentaḥ sayati ekaḥ kammaṭṭhānam a vissajjetvā ava  sayati ettakena pana na pākaṭam hoti iti caṅkamanena dīpenti yaḥ bhikkhu caṅkamanaṃ
translated: He lies down thinking of something else, he lies down without giving up his meditation subject.🔽But this is not made clear by the mere words, so they illustrate it by means of walking up and down.

original: otaritvā caṅkamanakoṭiyaṃ ṭhito pariggaṇhāti – “pācīnacaṅkamanakoṭiyaṃ pavattā rūpārūpadhammā🔽pacchimacaṅkamanakoṭiṃ appatvā ettheva niruddhā, pacchimacaṅkamanakoṭiyaṃ pavattāpi
analyzed: otaritvā caṅkamana koṭiyam ṭhitaḥ pariggaṇhāti pācīna caṅkamana koṭiyam pavattāḥ rūpa arūpa dhammāḥ  pacchima caṅkamana koṭim ap patvā etthā iva niruddhā pacchima caṅkamana koṭiyam pavattā api
translated: A bhikkhu who has gone down from his lodging and is standing at the end of the walk considers thus: “The material and immaterial states occurring at the eastern end of the walk have ceased there without reaching the western end.🔽Those occurring at the western end have ceased there without reaching the eastern end.

original: pācīnacaṅkamanakoṭiṃ appatvā ettheva niruddhā, caṅkamanamajjhe pavattā ubho koṭiyo
analyzed: pācīna caṅkamana koṭim ap patvā ettha iva niruddhā caṅkamana majjhe pavattāḥ ubho koṭiyaḥ
translated: Those occurring in the middle of the walk have ceased there without reaching either end.

original: appatvā ettheva niruddhā, caṅkamane pavattā rūpārūpadhammā ṭhānaṃ appatvā ettheva
analyzed: a patvā ettha iva niruddhā caṅkamane pavattāḥ rūpa arūpa dhammāḥ ṭhānam a patvā ettha iva
translated: The material and immaterial states occurring in the walk have ceased there without reaching the lodging.

original: niruddhā, ṭhāne pavattā nisajjaṃ appatvā ettheva niruddhā, nisajjāya pavattā sayanaṃ
analyzed: niruddhā ṭhāne pavattā nisajjam a patvā etthā iva niruddhā nisajjāya pavattā sayanam
translated: Those occurring in the lodging have ceased there without reaching the walk.

original: appatvā ettheva niruddhā”ti, evaṃ pariggaṇhanto pariggaṇhanto eva cittaṃ bhavaṅgaṃ
analyzed: a patvā ettha iva niruddhā iti evam pariggaṇhantaḥ pariggaṇhantaḥ eva cittam bhavaṅgam
translated: As he discerns it thus, he directs his mind to the life-continuum.

original: otāreti, uṭṭhahanto pana kammaṭṭhānaṃ gahetvāva uṭṭhahati. Ayaṃ bhikkhu gatādīsu
analyzed: otāreti uṭṭhahantaḥ pana kammaṭṭhānam gahetvā ava uṭṭhahati ayam bhikkhu gata ādīsu
translated: But when he is rising up, he rises up only after taking the meditation subject with him.🔽This bhikkhu is called “one who is fully aware of the postures.

original: sampajānakārī nāma hotīti.
analyzed: sampajānakārī nāma hoti iti
translated: he is said to be one who acts with clear comprehension.

original: Evampi sutte kammaṭṭhānaṃ avibhūtaṃ hoti, kammaṭṭhānaṃ avibhūtaṃ na kātabbaṃ, tasmā
analyzed: evam pi sutte kammaṭṭhānam avibhūtam hoti kammaṭṭhānam avibhūtam na kātabbam tasmā
translated: Thus the meditation subject is not clarified in the texts, and the meditation subject should not be left unclarified.

original: so bhikkhu yāva sakkoti, tāva caṅkamitvā ṭhatvā nisīditvā sayamāno evaṃ pariggahetvā🔽sayati – “kāyo acetano mañco acetano, kāyo na jānāti ‘ahaṃ mañce sayito’ti, mañcopi
analyzed: saḥ bhikkhu yāva sakkoti tāva caṅkamitvā ṭhatvā nisīditvā sayamānaḥ evam pariggahetvā  sayati kāyaḥ acetanaḥ mañcaḥ acetanaḥ kāyaḥ na jānāti aham mañce sayitā iti mañcaḥ upi
translated: So this bhikkhu should discern thus while walking, standing, sitting, and lying down,

original: na jānāti ‘mayi kāyo sayito’ti, acetano kāyo acetane mañce sayito”ti, evaṃ pariggaṇhanto
analyzed: na jānāti mayi kāyo sayito ti acetanaḥ kāyaḥ acetane mañce sayito ti evam pariggaṇhanto
translated: and then he should lie down thinking, “The body is unconscious, the bed is unconscious; the body does not know, ‘I am lying on a bed,’ nor does the bed know, ‘A body is lying on me’; an unconscious body is lying on an unconscious bed.”🔽As he discerns it thus, he directs his mind to the life-continuum.

original: eva cittaṃ bhavaṅgaṃ otāreti, pabujjhanto kammaṭṭhānaṃ gahetvāva pabujjhatīti ayaṃ
analyzed: eva cittam bhavaṅgam otāreti pabujjhantaḥ kammaṭṭhānam gahetvā ava pabujjhati iti ayaṃ
translated: When he is waking up, he wakes up only after taking the meditation subject with him.

original: sutte sampajānakārī nāma hoti. Kāyikādikiriyānibbattanena tammayattā āvajjanakiriyānibbattakattā🔽āvajjanakiriyāsamuṭṭhitattā ca javanaṃ, sabbampi vā chadvārappavattaṃ kiriyāmayapavattaṃ🔽nāma, tasmiṃ sati jāgaritaṃ nāma hotīti pariggaṇhanto jāgarite sampajānakārī nāma.🔽Apica rattindivaṃ cha koṭṭhāse katvā pañca koṭṭhāse jaggantopi jāgarite sampajānakārī nāma hotīti.🔽Vimuttāyatanasīse ṭhatvā dhammaṃ desentopi bāttiṃsatiracchānakathaṃ pahāya dasakathāvatthunissitasappāyakathaṃ🔽kathentopi bhāsite sampajānakārī nāma hoti. Aṭṭhatiṃsāya ārammaṇesu cittaruciyaṃ
analyzed: sutte sampajāna kārī nāma hoti kāyika ādi kiriyā nibbattanena tammaya ttā āvajjana kiriyā anibbattaka ttā  āvajjana kiriyā samuṭṭhita ttā ca javanam sabbam pi vā cha dvāra ppavattam kiriyā āmaya pavattam  nāma tasmin sati jāgaritam nāma hoti iti pariggaṇhantaḥ jāgarite sampajānakārī nāma  apica rattindivam cha koṭṭhāse katvā pañca koṭṭhāse jaggantaḥ api jāgarite sampajānakārī nāma hoti iti  vimutta āyatana sīse ṭhatvā dhammam desentaḥ api bāttiṃsa tiracchāna katham pahāya dasa kathā vatthu nissita sappāya katham  kathentaḥ api bhāsite sampajāna kārī nāma hoti aṭṭhatiṃsāya ārammaṇesu citta ruciyam

original: nāma. Dutiyañhi jhānaṃ vacīsaṅkhārappahānato visesato tuṇhībhāvo nāmāti. Oṭṭhe cātiādīsu
analyzed: nāma dutiyam hi jhānam vacī saṅkhāra pahānataḥ visesato tuṇhībhāvaḥ nāma ati oṭṭhe ca ati ādīsu
translated: The second jhāna is called “silence” because of the special quality of the cessation of discursive thinking.

original: ca-saddena kaṇṭhasīsanābhiādīnaṃ saṅgaho daṭṭhabbo. Tadanurūpaṃ payoganti tassa uppattiyā
analyzed: ca saddena kaṇṭha sīsa nābhi ādīnam saṅgahaḥ daṭṭhabbo tad anurūpam tassa uppattiyā
translated: The word “etc.” in the phrase “in the throat, etc.” should be understood to include the chest, the head, and the mouth.

original: anucchavikaṃ cittassa pavattiākārasaññitaṃ payogaṃ, yato sabbe vicārādayo nipphajjanti.
analyzed: anucchavikam cittassa pavatti ākāra saññitam payogam yatas sabbe vicāra ādayaḥ nipphajjanti
translated: The “effort appropriate to that” is the effort that is suitable for the arising of that jhāna, which is called the mode of operation of the mind.

original: Upādārūpapavattiyāti viññattivikārasahitasaddāyatanuppattiyā. Evanti vuttappakārena.
analyzed: upādā rūpa pavattiyā ti viññatti vikāra sahita sadda āyatana uppattiyā evam ti vutta ppakārena
translated: The “occurrence of the derivative materiality” is the occurrence of the sound base together with intimation.🔽In the seven instances, the word “mixed” is used because of the non-confusion of the mindfulness.

original: Sattasupi ṭhānesu asammuyhanavasena “missaka”nti vuttaṃ. Maggasammāsatiyāpi kāyānupassanādianurūpattā
analyzed: sattasu pi ṭhānesu asammuyhana vasena missakanti vuttam magga sammāsatiyā api kāya anupassanā ādi anurūpa ttā
translated: The mindfulness of the path is also in conformity with the clear comprehension of the body, etc.

original: sampajaññānurūpapubbabhāgaṃ sattaṭṭhāniyassa ekantalokiyattā.
analyzed: sampajaññā anurūpa pubba bhāgam satta ṭṭhāniyassa ekanta lokiya ttā
translated: The seven stations of consciousness are entirely mundane because they are the preliminary stage in conformity with clear comprehension.

original: Satisuttavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: sati sutta vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The commentary on the Sati-sutta is finished.

original: 3. Bhikkhusuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: bhikkhu sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: The Bhikkhu-sutta

original: 369. Yasmā so bhikkhu “desetu me, bhante, bhagavā saṃkhittena dhamma”nti saṃkhittena
analyzed: yasmai saḥ bhikkhu desetu me bhante bhagavā saṃkhittena dhammanti saṃkhittena
translated: Since the bhikkhu said, “Venerable sir, let the Blessed One teach me the Dhamma in brief,” the Blessed One

original: dhammadesanaṃ yāci, tassa saṃkhittarucibhāvato, tasmā saṃkhitteneva dhammaṃ desetukāmo
analyzed: dhamma desanam yāci tassa saṃkhitta ruci bhāvataḥ tasmā saṃkhittena iva dhammam desetu kāmo
translated: He asked for a teaching, and because he was interested in a brief one, the Blessed One, who wanted to teach him the Dhamma in brief,

original: bhagavā “tasmātihā”tiādimāhāti vuttaṃ – “yasmā saṃkhittena desanaṃ yācasi, tasmā”ti.
analyzed: bhagavā saṃkhittena desanam yācasi tasmā iti
translated: said: “Therefore, bhikkhu, you should train yourself thus: ‘My mind will be steadied in samādhi, unified, and well-concentrated.’ ”

original: Kammassakatādiṭṭhikasseva lokiyalokuttaraguṇavisesā ijjhanti, na diṭṭhivipannassa,
analyzed: kammassaka tā diṭṭhikassa iva lokiya lokuttara guṇa visesāḥ ijjhanti na diṭṭhi vipannassa
translated: The special qualities, mundane and supramundane, are successful only for one who has the right view that kamma is one’s own property, not for one whose view is perverted.

original: tasmā vuttaṃ “diṭṭhīti kammassakatādiṭṭhī”ti.
analyzed: tasmā vuttam diṭṭhi iti kammassaka tā diṭṭhi iti
translated: Therefore it is said: “‘View’: the view that kamma is one’s own property.”

original: 4. Sālasuttavaṇṇanā🔽370. Yathānusiṭṭhaṃ paṭipajjamāne apāyadukkhe apātanavasena dhāraṇaṭṭhena dhammo,
analyzed: sāla sutta vaṇṇanā  yathānusiṭṭham paṭipajjamāne apāya dukkhe apātana vasena dhāraṇa ṭṭhena dhammaḥ
translated: The Sāḷa Sutta🔽The Dhamma is so called because it bears one to the state of unaging and undying by the way of practice in accordance with the teaching.

original: sāsanabrahmacariyaṃ, tadeva tadaṅgādivasena kilesānaṃ vinayanaṭṭhena vinayoti āha
analyzed: sāsana brahmacariyam tat eva tad aṅga ādi vasena vinayana ṭṭhena āha
translated: The Dispensation is the life of purity. That itself is the Vinaya because it bears down defilements by the way of the requisite of the factors of the path, etc.

original: – “dhammoti vā…pe… nāma”nti. Paṭipakkhadhammehi anabhibhūtatāya eko udetīti ekodīti
analyzed: dhammaḥ ti vāpe nāmanti paṭipakkha dhammehi an abhibhūta tāya ekaḥ udeti iti ekodī iti
translated: Therefore it is said: “‘Dhamma’: either the Dispensation, which is the life of purity, or the path, which is the bearer of welfare, is called ‘Dhamma.’ …🔽‘Vinaya’: either the Dispensation, which is the life of purity, or the bearer of defilements is called ‘vinaya.’ ”

original: laddhanāmo samādhi bhūto jāto etesanti ekodibhūtā. Ettha ca ekodibhūtāti etena upacārajjhānāvaho
analyzed: samādhi bhūtaḥ jātaḥ etesanti ekodibhūtāḥ ettha ca ekodibhūtā ati etena upacāra jhāna āvahaḥ
translated: The concentration that has arisen and become is called “one-pointed” because it rises up alone, not being overcome by opposing states.

original: pubbabhāgiko samādhi vutto. Samāhitāti etena upacārappanāsamādhi. Ekaggacittāti etena🔽subhāvito vasippatto appanāsamādhi vuttoti veditabbo. Navakabhikkhūhi bhāvitasatipaṭṭhānā
analyzed: pubbabhāgikaḥ samādhi vuttaḥ samāhitā ati etena upacāra ppanā samādhi ekagga cittā ati etena  su bhāvitaḥ vasi ppattaḥ appanā samādhi vuttaḥ ti veditabbaḥ navaka bhikkhūhi bhāvita sati paṭṭhānā
translated: and concentration in the prior stage is what is meant by “concentration” here. “With mind concentrated”: this refers to access concentration. “With mind unified”: this refers to

original: pubbabhāgā. Te hi yathābhūtañāṇāya bhāvitā. Yathābhūtañāṇanti hi sotāpattimaggañāṇaṃ🔽idhādhippetaṃ. Khīṇāsavehi bhāvitasatipaṭṭhānāpi pubbabhāgā. Tesañhi katakaraṇīyānaṃ
analyzed: pubbabhāgā te hi yathābhūta ñāṇāya bhāvitāḥ yathābhūta ñāṇam ti hi sa utāpatti magga ñāṇam  idha adhippetam khīṇāsavehi bhāvita sati paṭṭhānā api pubbabhāgā tesam hi kata karaṇīyānam
translated: absorption concentration, which is well developed and has reached mastery. The development of the foundations of mindfulness by the new bhikkhus is the prior stage. For they develop them for the purpose of knowledge of things as they really are. “Knowledge of things as they really are” here means the path of stream-entry.

original: diṭṭhadhammasukhavihārāya satipaṭṭhānabhāvanā, sekkhānaṃ pana satipaṭṭhānabhāvanā
analyzed: diṭṭhadhamma sukha vihārāya sati paṭṭhāna bhāvanā sekkhānam pana sati paṭṭhāna bhāvanā
translated: The development of the foundations of mindfulness by those whose cankers are destroyed is also the prior stage. For they develop the foundations of mindfulness for the purpose of abiding in bliss here and now,

original: pariññatthāya pavattā lokiyā, parijānanavasena pavattā lokuttarāti “missakā”ti vuttaṃ.
analyzed: pariññā atthāya pavattā lokiyā parijānana vasena pavattā lokuttarā ti missakā ti vuttam
translated: but the development of the foundations of mindfulness by those in training proceeds for the purpose of full understanding. It is mundane when it proceeds by way of full understanding and supramundane when it proceeds by way of full-understanding knowledge. Thus it is said to be “mixed.”

original: 5. Akusalarāsisuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: akusalarāsi sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: . The exposition of the “Discourse on the Aggregate of Unprofitable Things” is finished.

original: 371. Pañcame kevaloti kusaladhammehi asammisso, tato eva sakalo sukkapakkho anavajjaṭṭho. Sesaṃ vuttanayameva.
analyzed: pañcame kevalaḥ ti kusala dhammehi asammissaḥ tatas eva sakalaḥ sukka pakkhaḥ anavajja ṭṭhaḥ sesam vutta nayam eva
translated: . In the fifth, “entirely” means unmixed with unprofitable things; thus it is the whole bright side, the profitable class. The rest is as already explained.

original: 6. Sakuṇagghisuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: sakuṇagghi sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: . The exposition of the “Discourse on the Bird-Lore” is finished.

original: 372. Pākatikasakuṇakulesu balavabhāvato tesaṃ hananato sakuṇagghi. Senoti vuttaṃ🔽“senassetaṃ adhivacana”nti, senaviseso pana so veditabbo. Āmisatthāya pattattā “lobhasāhasena🔽pattā”ti vuttaṃ, lobhanimittena sāhasākārena pattāti attho. Naṅgalena kaṭṭhaṃ kasitaṃ🔽naṅgalakaṭṭhaṃ, taṃ karīyati etthāti naṅgalakaṭṭhakaraṇanti āha – “adhunā kaṭṭhaṃ
analyzed: pākatika sakuṇa kulesu balava bhāvataḥ tesam hananataḥ sakuṇagghi senaḥ ti vuttam  senassa itam adhivacanan ti sena visesaḥ pana saḥ veditabbaḥ āmisa atthāya patta ttā lobha sāhasena  pattā iti vuttam lobha nimittena sāhasa ākārena pattā iti atthaḥ naṅgalena kaṭṭham kasitam  naṅgala kaṭṭham tam ettha iti naṅgala kaṭṭha karaṇam iti āha adhunā kaṭṭham
translated: In the case of the families of ordinary birds, it is a bird-killer because of the killing of them by reason of its strength. It is a hawk, it is said.🔽This is a designation for a hawk. But it should be understood that it is a particular kind of hawk. It is called “obtained by the means of greed and violence” because it is obtained for the sake of flesh. The meaning is that it is obtained by the means of greed in the form of violence.🔽The ploughshare has ploughed the ground,🔽so it is a ploughshare-ground. It is made here, thus it is a ploughshare-ground-maker. Therefore he said: “Now, the ground that is ploughed by a ploughshare” .🔽

original: khettaṭṭhāna”nti. Leḍḍuyo tiṭṭhanti etthāti leḍḍuṭṭhānaṃ, leḍḍunimittaṃ kasitaṭṭhānaṃ.🔽Vajjatīti vadaṃ, vacanaṃ. Kucchitaṃ vadaṃ avadaṃ. Garahane hi ayaṃ a-kāro yathā –🔽“aputto abhariyā”ti. Avadaṃ mānetīti avadamānā, attano balamadena lāpaṃ atimaññitvā🔽vadantīti attho. Tenevāha “gaccha kho, tvaṃ lāpa, tatrapi me gantvā na mokkhasī”ti.
analyzed: khetta ṭṭhānam ti leḍḍuyaḥ tiṭṭhanti ettha ati leḍḍu ṭṭhānam leḍḍu nimittam kasita ṭṭhānam 🔽vajjati iti vadam vacanam kucchitam vadam avadam gara hane hi ayam akāraḥ yathā 🔽a puttaḥ a bhariyā ati avadam mānā iti iti a vadamānā attanaḥ bala madena lāpam atimaññitvā 🔽vadanti iti tena iva āha gaccha kho tvam lāpa tatra api me gantvā na mokkhasi iti
translated: In the case of the families of ordinary birds, it is a bird-hawk because of its strength in killing them. “Senā” is said to be a designation for an army, but it should be understood that it is a particular kind of army. Because it is obtained for the sake of material goods, it is said that it is “obtained by the recklessness of greed” . The meaning is that it is obtained by the recklessness of the sign of greed.  The plough-land is the land that is ploughed with a plough. It is made there, thus it is a plough-land-maker . He said: “Now the land that is ploughed with a plough is called plough-land” .  The stone-land is the place where stones lie, the land that is ploughed with a stone .  He said: “The place where stones lie is called stone-land” .  The place where the land is ploughed with a plough is called plough-land. The place where the land is ploughed with a stone is called stone-land.  He said: “The place where the land is ploughed with a plough is called plough-land” .  The place where the land is ploughed with a stone is called stone-land.  He said: “The place where the land is ploughed with a stone is called stone-land” .  He said: “The place where the land is ploughed with a stone is called stone-land” .  He said: “The place where the land is ploughed with a stone is called stone-land” .  He said: “The place where the land is ploughed with a stone is called stone-land” .  He said: “The place where the land is ploughed with a stone is called stone-land” .  He said: “The place where the land is ploughed with a stone is called stone-land” .  He said: “The place where the land is ploughed with a stone is called stone-land” .  He said: “The place where the land is ploughed with a stone is called stone-land” .  He said: “The place where the land is ploughed with a stone is called stone-land” .  He said: “The place where the land is ploughed with a stone is called stone-land” .  He said: “The place where the land is ploughed with a stone is called

original: Yaṃ pana aṭṭhakathāyaṃ vuttaṃ “attano balassa suṭṭhu vaṇṇaṃ vadamānā”ti, tattha attato
analyzed: yam pana aṭṭhakathāyam vuttam attanaḥ balassa suṭṭhu vaṇṇam vadamānā ati tattha attataḥ
translated: But what is said in the Commentary, “praising the excellence of his own strength,” is said by taking what is implied by the words.

original: āpannaṃ gahetvā vuttaṃ. “Vadamāno”ti vā pāṭho, sārambhavasena avhāyantoti attho.
analyzed: āpannam gahetvā vuttam vadamānaḥ iti vā pāṭhaḥ sa ārambha vasena avhāyantaḥ iti attho
translated: Or the reading may be “vadamāno,” in which case the meaning is “boasting by saying.”

original: Tenāha “ehi kho dāni sakuṇagghī”ti. Suṭṭhu ṭhapetvāti jiyāmuttasarassa viya sīghapātayogyatākaraṇena
analyzed: tena āha ehi kho dāni sakuṇagghi iti suṭṭhu ṭhapetvā ati jiyā mutta sarassa viya sīgha pāta yogya tā karaṇena
translated: Hence he said, “Come now, you bird-catcher.”

original: ubho pakkhe sammā ṭhapetvā. Ayanti sakuṇagghi. Ñatvāti yathābhūtadassanena attano
analyzed: ubho pakkhe sammā ṭhapetvā ayanti yathā bhūta dassanena attanaḥ
translated: Having set them right: having set them right by making them fit to be shot down quickly, like a jīvamjīvaka bird.🔽You: the bird-catcher.🔽Having known: having known by his own knowledge, by seeing things as they are.

original: ñāṇena jānitvā. Phālīyitthāti phālacchedatikhiṇasikhare sukkhaleḍḍusmiṃ bhijjittha.
analyzed: ñāṇena jānitvā phālīyittha ati phāla cheda tikhiṇa sikhare sukkhaleḍḍusmim bhijjittha
translated: It broke: it broke on the dry piece of wood at the sharp point of the ploughshare.

original: 7. Makkaṭasuttavaṇṇanā🔽373. Sañcāroti sañcaraṇaṃ. Lepanti silesasadisaṃ ālepanaṃ. Kājasikkā viyāti kājadaṇḍake
analyzed: makkaṭa sutta vaṇṇanā  sañcāroti sañcaraṇam silesa sadisam ālepanam kāja sikkā kāja daṇḍake
translated: The Commentary on the Makkaṭa Sutta

original: olaggetabbā sikkā viya. Apica catasso rajjuyo upari bandhanaṭṭhānañcāti pañcaṭṭhānaṃ.
analyzed: olaggetabbā sikkā viya apica catasso rajjuyo upari bandhana ṭhānam ca ati pañca ṭṭhānam
translated: Sañcāraṇaṃ sañcāraṃ. Lepanaṃ silesadisaṃ ālepanaṃ. Kājadaṇḍake olaggetabbā sikkā viya. Apica catasso rajjuyo upari bandhanaṭṭhānañcāti pañcaṭṭhānaṃ.

original: Oḍḍitoti olambito. Thunantoti nitthunanto.
analyzed: oḍḍitaḥ iti olambitaḥ thunantaḥ iti nitthunantaḥ
translated: Oḍḍito olambito. Thunanto nitthunanto.

original: 8. Sūdasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: sūda sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: The Commentary on the Sūda Sutta

original: 374. Āhārasampādanena taṃtaṃāhāravatthugate sūdeti paggharetīti sūdo, bhattakārako.
analyzed: āhāra sampādanena taṃ taṃ āhāra vatthu gate sūda iti pagghara iti iti sūdaḥ bhatta kārako
translated: The cook is one who cooks, who makes the food by preparing the various kinds of food.

original: Daharehi manāpataraṃ accetabbato atikkamitabbato accayā, bhojane rasavisesā, tasmā🔽nānaccayehīti nānappakārarasavisesehīti attho. Tena vuttaṃ “nānaccayehī”tiādi. Aggīyati
analyzed: daharehi manāpataram accetabbataḥ atikkamitabbataḥ accayā bhojane rasa visesā tasmā  nānaccayehi iti nānā pakāra rasa visesehi iti attho tena vuttam nānaccayehi itiādi
translated: The various kinds of taste are the different kinds of taste in food that are acceptable because they are pleasing to the young.🔽The meaning is that they are different kinds of taste in different kinds of food. That is why “various kinds of taste” is said.

original: asaṅkarato vibhajīyatīti aggo, ambilameva aggo ambilaggoti āha – “ambilaggehīti ambilakoṭṭhāsehī”ti.
analyzed: asaṅkarataḥ vibhajīyati iti aggaḥ ambilam eva aggaḥ ambi laggaḥ iti āha ambi laggehi iti ambila koṭṭhāsehi iti
translated: The sour is the best, thus it is the sour-best . He said “sour-best” meaning “sour-portion.”

original: Dātuṃ abhiharitabbatāya abhihārā, deyyadhammā. Tenāha – “abhihaṭānaṃ dāyāna”nti.
analyzed: dātum abhiharitabba tāya abhihārāḥ deyya dhammā tena āha
translated: The things to be brought are the things to be given. That is why he said “of the things brought to give.”

original: Idaṃ me kammaṭṭhānaṃ anulomaṃvāti idaṃ mama kammaṭṭhānaṃ evaṃ pavattamānaṃ anulomāvasānameva
analyzed: idam me kammaṭṭhānam anulomam vā ati idam mama kammaṭṭhānam evam pavattamānam anuloma avasānam eva
translated: This meditation subject of mine is in conformity, thus this meditation subject of mine occurs in conformity with the path.

original: hutvā tiṭṭhati. Evaṃ puna pavattamānaṃ ussakkitvā visesanibbattanatthameva hotīti
analyzed: hutvā tiṭṭhati evam puna pavattamānam ussakkitvā visesa nibbattana attham eva hoti iti
translated: It is only after burning that it stands. So too, occurring again, it occurs only for the purpose of attaining distinction by striving.

original: evaṃ nimittaṃ gahetuṃ na sakkoti bālo abyatto, paṇḍito pana sakkoti. Attano cittassāti
analyzed: evam nimittam gahetum na sakkoti bālaḥ abyatto paṇḍito pana sakkoti attano cittassa ati
translated: The fool, the untaught ordinary man, cannot take up the sign in this way. But the wise man can. In his own mind:

original: attano bhāvanācittassa. Pubbabhāgavipassanā satipaṭṭhānāva kathitā “sakassa cittassa
analyzed: attanaḥ bhāvanā cittassa pubbabhāga vipassanā sati paṭṭhānā ava kathitā sakassa cittassa
translated: of his own development-consciousness.

original: nimittaṃ uggaṇhātī”ti vuttattā.
analyzed: nimittam uggaṇhāti iti vutta ttā
translated: The insight of the preliminary stage is called the foundations of mindfulness because it is said that “he apprehends the sign of his own mind.”

original: 9. Gilānasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: gilāna sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: The Description of the Sickly-Discourse

original: 375. Pādagāmoti nagarassa padasadiso mahantagāmo. Tenevāha “vesāliyaṃ viharati veḷuvagāmake”ti.
