analyzed: katvā dhammam desessanti iti navavidham lokuttaram dhammam pabodhessanti iti attho  ettha ca paññapessanti iti ādīhi chahi padehi cha attha padāni dassitāni āditaḥ pana  dvīhi padehi cha byañjana padāni ettāvatā tepiṭakam buddha vacanam saṃvaṇṇanā nayena
translated: so they will teach the Dhamma after establishing the meaning they have understood by means of reasons and examples. Therefore the commentator says, “having made it lead to the goal,” the meaning of which is that they will teach the ninefold supramundane Dhamma.

original: saṅgahetvā dassitaṃ hoti. Vuttañhetaṃ nettiyaṃ “dvādasa padāni suttaṃ, taṃ sabbaṃ
analyzed: saṅgahetvā dassitam hoti vuttam ha etam nettiyam dvādasa padāni suttam tam sabbam
translated: And here the six terms beginning with “they will announce” show the six kinds of meaning, while the first two terms show the six kinds of phrasing. So far the Buddha’s word consisting of the three Piṭakas is shown by the method of commentary as being collected together. For this is said in the Netti: “A sutta is twelve terms, all that

original: byañjanañca attho cā”ti.
analyzed: byañjanam ca atthaḥ ca ati
translated: and the letter and the spirit.”🔽“The whole of the spiritual life” is the whole of the spiritual life of the Master’s Dispensation.

original: Sikkhattayasaṅgahitanti adhisīlasikkhādisikkhattayasaṅgahaṃ. Sakalaṃ sāsanabrahmacariyanti🔽anavasesaṃ satthusāsanabhūtaṃ seṭṭhacariyaṃ. Samiddhanti sammadeva vaḍḍhitaṃ. Jhānassādavasenāti
analyzed: sikkhattaya saṅgahitanti adhi sīla sikkhā ādi sikkhattaya saṅgaham sakalam sāsana brahmacariyam ti  anavasesam satthu sāsana bhūtam seṭṭha cariyam samiddhanti sammat eva vaḍḍhitam jhāna ssāda vasena ati
translated: “Flourished” means that it grew in the right way.

original: tehi tehi bhikkhūhi samadhigatajhānasukhavasena. Vuḍḍhippattanti uḷārapaṇītabhāvūpagamanena
analyzed: tehi tehi bhikkhūhi samadhigata jhāna sukha vasena uḷāra paṇīta bhāva upagamanena
translated: “By the excellence of their jhana” means by the excellence of the jhana bliss attained by those bhikkhus.🔽“It reached growth” means that it reached complete growth by attaining to the state of the sublime and the choice.

original: sabbaso parivuḍḍhimupagataṃ. Sabbapāliphullaṃ viya abhiññāsampadāhi sāsanābhivuḍḍhiyā
analyzed: sabbasas parivuḍḍhim upagatam sabba pāli phullam viya abhiññā sampadā hi sāsana abhivuḍḍhiyā
translated: “It was in full flower” means that by the growth of the Dispensation through the excellence of the direct knowledges it reached the peak.

original: matthakappattito. Patiṭṭhitavasenāti patiṭṭhānavasena, patiṭṭhappattiyāti attho.
analyzed: matthaka ppattitaḥ patiṭṭhita vasena āti patiṭṭhāna vasena patiṭṭha ppattiyā ati attho
translated: “By the establishment” means by the establishment; the meaning is, by the attainment of establishment.

original: Paṭivedhavasena bahuno janassa hitaṃ bāhujaññaṃ. Tenāha “mahājanābhisamayavasenā”ti.
analyzed: paṭivedha vasena bahuno janassa hitam bāhujaññam tena āha mahājana abhisamaya vasena ati
translated: “The welfare of the many” is the welfare of the multitude by the penetration of the Dhamma. Therefore it is said, “by the penetration of the Dhamma for the multitude.”

original: Puthu puthulaṃ bhūtaṃ jātaṃ, puthuttaṃ bhūtaṃ pattanti vā puthubhūtaṃ. Tenāha “sabbākārena
analyzed: puthu puthulam bhūtam jātam puthuttam bhūtam pattanti vā puthubhūtam tena āha sabba ākārena
translated: “The born” is what has come to be by being born; it has reached the state of the born. Therefore it is said, “by the penetration of the Dhamma for the multitude.”

original: puthulabhāvappatta”nti. Suṭṭhu pakāsitanti sammadeva ādikalyāṇādibhāvena paveditaṃ.🔽Satiṃ sūpaṭṭhitaṃ katvāti ayaṃ kāyādivibhāgo attabhāvasaññito dukkhabhāro mayā ettakaṃ
analyzed: puthula bhāva pattanti suṭṭhu pakāsitanti sammad eva ādi kalyāṇa ādi bhāvena paveditam  satim su upaṭṭhitam katvā iti ayam kāya ādi vibhāgaḥ atta bhāva saññitaḥ dukkha bhāraḥ mayā ettakam
translated: “It has been well proclaimed” : it has been well revealed as being good in the beginning, etc.

original: kālaṃ vahito, idāni pana na vahitabbo, etassa avahanatthaṃ cirataraṃ kālaṃ ariyamaggasambhāro🔽sambhato, svāyaṃ ariyamaggo paṭividdho, yato ime kāyādayo asubhādito sabhāvādito
analyzed: kālam vahitaḥ idāni pana na vahitabbaḥ etassa a vahana attham cirataram kālam ariya magga sambhāraḥ  sambhataḥ svāyam ariya maggo paṭividdhaḥ yatas ime kāya ādayaḥ asubha āditaḥ sabhāva āditaḥ
translated: “Having established mindfulness well” : “This body, etc., which is conceived as a self and is a burden of suffering, has been carried by me for so long a time; but now it is not to be carried any more. For the purpose of not carrying it, the requisites for the noble path have been accumulated for a long time.

original: sammadeva pariññātāti catubbidhampi satiṃ yathātathaṃ visaye suṭṭhu upaṭṭhitaṃ katvā.
analyzed: sammat eva pariññātā ati catubbidham pi satim yathātatham visaye suṭṭhu upaṭṭhitam katvā
translated: Now this noble path has been penetrated, by which these body, etc., have been fully understood as they really are, as foul, etc., and as to their individual essences.” Thus having established the fourfold mindfulness well in the object as it really is.

original: Ñāṇena paricchinditvāti yasmā imassa attabhāvasaññitassa dukkhabhārassa vahane payojanabhūtaṃ
analyzed: ñāṇena paricchinditvā ati yasmai imassa atta bhāva saññitassa dukkha bhārassa vahane payojana bhūtam
translated: “Having discerned with knowledge” : since the benefit for oneself, which was the purpose of carrying this burden of suffering conceived as a self, was completed at the foot of the Bodhi tree,

original: attahitaṃ bodhimūle eva parisamāpitaṃ, parahitaṃ pana buddhaveneyyavinayanaṃ parisamāpitaṃ
analyzed: atta hitam bodhi mūle eva parisamāpitam para hitam pana buddha veneyya vinayanam parisamāpitam
translated: and the benefit for others, the training of those to be trained by the Buddha, was completed,

original: matthakappattaṃ, taṃ dāni māsattayeneva parisamāpanaṃ pāpuṇissati, tasmā āha “visākhapuṇṇamāyaṃ
analyzed: matthaka ppattam tam dāni māsa ttayena iva parisamāpanam pāpuṇissati tasmai āha visākhapuṇṇamāyam
translated: He will reach the end of it in three months’ time, and so he said: ‘On the full-moon day of the month of Visakha I shall attain final Nibbana.’

original: parinibbāyissāmī”ti, evaṃ buddhañāṇena paricchinditvā saccabhāgena vinicchayaṃ katvā.
analyzed: parinibbāyissāmi iti evam buddha ñāṇena paricchinditvā sacca bhāgena vinicchayam katvā
translated: Thus, having defined it by means of the knowledge of a Buddha and having made a decision by means of the truth principle,

original: Āyusaṅkhāraṃ vissajīti āyuno jīvitassa abhisaṅkharaṇaṃ phalasamāpattidhammaṃ na samāpajjissāmīti
analyzed: āyu saṅkhāram vissaji iti āyunaḥ jīvitassa abhisaṅkharaṇam phala samāpatti dhammam na samāpajjissāmi iti
translated: he ‘released the life-determining formation’ . He did not enter upon the attainment of the state of fruition.

original: vissaji, taṃ vissajjaneneva tena abhisaṅkharīyamānaṃ jīvitasaṅkhāraṃ na pavattayissāmīti
analyzed: vissaji tam vissajjanena iva tena abhisaṅkharīyamānam jīvita saṅkhāram na pavattayissāmi iti
translated: By releasing it, he did not cause to occur the life-determining formation that was being formed by it.

original: vissaji. Tenāha “tatthā”tiādi.
analyzed: vissaji tena āha tattha atiādi
translated: Therefore he said: ‘Therein’ , etc.

original: Ṭhānamahantatāyapi pavattiākāramahantatāyapi mahanto pathavīkampo. Tattha ṭhānamahantatāya🔽bhūmicālassa mahantataṃ dassetuṃ “tadā…pe… akampitthā”ti vuttaṃ, sā pana jātikhettabhūtā
analyzed: ṭhāna mahanta tāya api pavatti ākāra mahanta tāya api mahantaḥ pathavī kampaḥ tattha ṭhāna mahanta tāya  bhūmicālassa mahantatam dassetum tadā āpe akampittha iti vuttam sā pana jāti khetta bhūtā
translated: The earthquake was great in extent and great in appearance. To show the greatness of the earthquake in extent,🔽it was said: ‘At that time the earth quaked and shook and trembled’ , etc. But that extent was the ten-thousandfold world system, which is the field of the Buddha’s knowledge, and not any other.

original: dasasahassī lokadhātu eva, na yā kāci. Yā mahābhinīhāramahājātiādīsupi akampittha,
analyzed: dasa sahassī lokadhātu eva na yā kāci yā mahā abhinīhāra mahā jāti ādīsu pi akampittha
translated: It did not quake in the great resolve, the great conception, etc.

original: tadāpi tattakāya eva kampane kiṃ kāraṇaṃ? Jātikhettabhāvena tasseva ādito pariggahassa🔽katattā, pariggahaṇañcassa dhammatāvasena veditabbaṃ. Tathā hi purimabuddhānampi🔽tattakameva jātikhettaṃ ahosi. Tathā hi vuttaṃ “dasasahassī lokadhātu nissaddā hoti
analyzed: tadā api tatta kāyaḥ eva kampane kim kāraṇam jāti khetta bhāvena tassa iva āditas pariggahassa  kata ttā pariggahaṇam ca assa dhamma tā vasena veditabbam tathā hi purima buddhānam pi  tattakam eva jāti khettam ahosi tathā hi vuttam dasa sahassī lokadhātu nissaddā hoti
translated: And his apprehension should be understood to have been in accordance with the natural order of things. For the place of birth of the previous Buddhas was the same.🔽For it is said: “The ten-thousandfold world became silent and still … the great ocean trembled and quaked … the ten-thousandfold world quaked” .🔽The quaking of the earth is said to have extended to the edge of the water, and to have been accompanied by the proclamation of the six kinds of supernormal knowledge.

original: nirākulā…pe… mahāsamuddo ābhujati, dasasahassī pakampatī”ti ca ādi. Udakapariyantaṃ🔽katvā chappakārappavedhanena. Avītarāge bhiṃsetīti bhiṃsano, so eva bhiṃsanakoti🔽āha “bhayajanako”ti. Devabheriyoti devadundubhisaddassa pariyāyavacanamattaṃ, na🔽cettha kāci bherī devadundubhīti adhippetā, atha kho uppātabhāvena labbhamāno ākāsato
analyzed: nirākulāpe mahā samuddaḥ ābhujati dasa sahassī pakampati iti ca ādi udaka pariyantam  katvā cha pakāra ppavedhanena avīta rāge bhiṃseti iti bhiṃsano saḥ eva bhiṃsanakaḥ iti  āha bhaya janakā iti deva bheriyā iti deva dundubhi saddassa na  ca ittha kāci bherī devadundubhī iti adhippetā atha kho uppāta bhāvena labbhamānaḥ ākāsataḥ
translated: “Frightening” means “causing fear” in those who have not yet overcome the fear of the world.🔽“The divine drum” is a synonym for the sound of the divine drum. Herein, no drum is intended as the divine drum, but rather the sound that is heard in the sky as a result of the shaking .🔽Therefore it is said: “The divine drum” and so on. “The divine drum” is a synonym for the sound of the divine drum. Herein, no drum is intended as the divine drum, but rather the sound that is heard in the sky as a result of the shaking .

original: nigghosasaddo. Tenāha “devo”tiādi. Devoti megho. Tassa hi tadā acchabhāvena ākāsassa
analyzed: nigghosa saddaḥ tena āha deva iti ādi deva uti meghaḥ tassa hi tadā accha bhāvena ākāsassa
translated: Therefore it is said: “The divine drum” and so on. “The divine drum” is a synonym for the sound of the divine drum. Herein, no drum is intended as the divine drum, but rather the sound that is heard in the sky as a result of the shaking .🔽Therefore it is said: “The divine drum” and so on. “The divine drum” is a synonym for the sound of the divine drum. Herein, no drum is intended as the divine drum, but rather the sound that is heard in the sky as a result of the shaking .🔽Therefore it is said: “The divine drum” and so on. “The divine drum” is a synonym for the sound of the divine drum. Herein, no drum is intended as the divine drum, but rather the sound that is heard in the sky as a result of the shaking .🔽Therefore it is said: “The divine drum” and so on. “The divine drum” is a synonym for the sound of the divine drum. Herein, no drum is intended as the divine drum, but rather the sound that is heard in the sky as a result of the shaking .

original: vassābhāvena sukkhagajjitasaññite sadde niccharante devadundubhisamaññā. Tenāha “devo
analyzed: vassa abhāvena sukkha gajjita saññite sadde niccharante deva dundubhi samaññā tena āha devaḥ
translated: When the sound of the dry rubbing together of the branches of trees in the wind occurs, it is called the “thunder of the gods.”

original: sukkhagajjitaṃ gajjī”ti.
analyzed: sukkha gajjitam gajjīti
translated: Therefore it is said: “The gods thundered with the sound of dry rubbing together.”

original: Pītivegavissaṭṭhanti “evaṃ ciratarakālaṃ vahito ayaṃ attabhāvasaññito dukkhabhāro,
analyzed: pīti vega vissaṭṭhanti evam ciratara kālam vahitaḥ ayam atta bhāva saññitaḥ dukkha bhāro
translated: “With the bursting of rapture” : the Blessed One, being pleased with the thought “After such a long time, this burden of the aggregates, which is called the self,

original: dāni na cirasseva nikkhipissāmī”ti sañjātasomanasso bhagavā sabhāveneva pītivegavissaṭṭhaṃ
analyzed: dāni na cirassa iva nikkhipissāmi iti sañjāta somanassaḥ bhagavā sabhāvena iva pīti vega vissaṭṭham
translated: will soon be laid down,” uttered this inspired utterance with the bursting of his natural rapture.

original: udānaṃ udāneti, evaṃ udānentena ayampi attho sādhito hotīti dassanatthaṃ aṭṭhakathāyaṃ
analyzed: udānam udāneti evam udānentena ayam pi atthaḥ sādhitaḥ hoti iti dassana ttham aṭṭhakathā ayam
translated: In order to show that this meaning is also accomplished by the utterance of the inspired utterance, in the commentary

original: “kasmā”tiādi vuttaṃ.
analyzed: kasmā itiādi vuttam
translated: it is said: “Why?”🔽The word tula is used in the sense of “to measure” .

original: Tulīyatīti tulanti tula-saddo kammasādhanoti dassetuṃ “tulita”nti vuttaṃ. Appānubhāvatāya
analyzed: tulīyati iti tulanti tula saddo kamma sādhano ti dassetum tulitam ti vuttam appa anubhāva tāya
translated: It is limited because of its smallness.

original: paricchinnaṃ. Tathā hi taṃ paṭipakkhena parito khaṇḍitabhāvena parittanti vuccati.
analyzed: paricchinnam tathā hi tam paṭipakkhena paritas khaṇḍita bhāvena parittanti vuccati
translated: For it is called paritta because it is broken up all around by its opposite.

original: Paṭipakkhavikkhambhanato dīghasantānatāya vipulaphalatāya ca na tulaṃ na paricchinnaṃ.
analyzed: paṭipakkha vikkhambhanataḥ dīgha santāna tāya vipula phala tāya ca na tulam na paricchinnam
translated: It is not tula, not limited, because it is not limited by its opposite, because it has a long continuity, and because it has a vast fruit.

original: Yehi kāraṇehi pubbe avisesato “mahaggataṃ atula”nti vuttaṃ, tāni kāraṇāni rūpāvacarato🔽āruppassa sātisayaṃ vijjantīti arūpāvacaraṃ atulanti vuttaṃ, itarañca tulanti. Appavipākanti
analyzed: yehi kāraṇehi pubbe avisesataḥ mahaggatam atulam ti vuttam tāni kāraṇāni rūpāvacarataḥ  āruppassa sa atisayam vijjanti iti arūpāvacaram atulanti vuttam itaram ca tulanti appa vipākam ti
translated: The reasons for which it was said above without distinction that the great is incomparable are reasons that are more outstanding in the immaterial than in the fine-material sphere.

original: tīsupi kammesu yaṃ appavipākaṃ hīnaṃ, taṃ tulaṃ. Bahuvipākanti yaṃ mahāvipākaṃ paṇītaṃ,
analyzed: tīsu pi kammesu yam appa vipākam hīnam tam tulam bahu vipākam ti yam mahā vipākam paṇītam
translated: So the immaterial is called “incomparable” and the other “comparable.” The “small” is that which has small result among the three kinds of kamma. The “great” is that which has great result.

original: taṃ atulaṃ. Yaṃ panettha majjhimaṃ, taṃ hīnaṃ ukkaṭṭhanti dvidhā bhinditvā dvīsu🔽bhāgesu pakkhipitabbaṃ. Hīnattikavaṇṇanāyaṃ vuttanayeneva appabahuvipākataṃ niddhāretvā
analyzed: tam atulam yam pana ittha majjhimam tam hīnam ukkaṭṭhanti dvidhā bhinditvā dvīsu  bhāgesu pakkhipitabbam hīna ttika vaṇṇanāyam vutta nayena iva appa bahu vipāka tam niddhāretvā
translated: But what is middling here should be classed in two ways after dividing it into inferior and superior.

original: tassa vasena tulātulabhāvo veditabbo. Sambhavati etasmāti sambhavoti āha “sambhava^🔽hetubhūta”nti. Niyakajjhattaratoti sasantānadhammesu vipassanāvasena gocarāsevanāya
analyzed: tassa vasena tula atula bhāvaḥ veditabbo sambhavati etasmā ati sambhavaḥ ti āha sambhava  hetu bhūtam ti sa santāna dhammesu vipassanā vasena gocara āsevanāya
translated: And after extracting the small and great result, its state as comparable or incomparable should be understood according to the small and great result.🔽“The cause for its occurrence” is the cause for its arising.

original: ca rato. Savipākaṃ samānaṃ pavattivipākamattadāyikammaṃ savipākaṭṭhena sambhavaṃ,
analyzed: ca rato sa vipākam samānam pavatti vipāka matta dāyi kammam sa vipāka ṭṭhena sambhavam
translated: “Delighting in his own thoughts” is delighting in the objects of insight in the states of his own continuity by means of the development of the meditation subject.

original: na ca taṃ kāmādi^ bhavābhisaṅkhārakanti tato visesanatthaṃ sambhavanti vatvā “bhavasaṅkhāra”nti
analyzed: na ca tam kāma ādi bhava abhisaṅkhārakanti tatas visesana attham sambhavanti vatvā bhava saṅkhāranti
translated: and it is not the formation of craving, etc., for existence, therefore, in order to distinguish it, it is said, “the formation of existence.”

original: vuttaṃ. Ossajīti ariyamaggena avassaji. Kavacaṃ viya attabhāvaṃ pariyonandhitvā ṭhitaṃ
analyzed: vuttam ossaji iti ariya maggena avassaji kavacam viya atta bhāvam pariyonandhitvā ṭhitam
translated: Having said “the formation of existence,” it is said, “he has laid down,” etc. Having surrounded his person with the armor of the noble path,

original: attani sambhūtattā attasambhavaṃ kilesañca abhindīti kilesabhedasahabhāvikammossajjanaṃ
analyzed: sambhūta ttā atta sambhavam kilesam ca kilesa bheda saha bhāvi kamma ussajjanam
translated: he has broken the defilements that have arisen in himself, and therefore he has broken the defilements.

original: dassento tadubhayassa kāraṇamāha “ajjhattarato samāhito”ti.
analyzed: dassentaḥ tat ubhayassa kāraṇam āha ajjhattarataḥ samāhitaḥ iti
translated: Showing the laying down that is concomitant with the breaking of the defilements, he says, “delighting in the internal, being composed,” etc.

original: Paṭhamavikappe avasajjanameva vuttaṃ. Ettha avasajjanākāroti taṃ dassento “atha vā”tiādimāha.
analyzed: paṭhama vikappe avasajjanam eva vuttam ettha avasajjana ākāraḥ ti tam dassentaḥ atha vā iti ādim āha
translated: In the first part of the verse, only the laying down is mentioned. Here, in order to show the manner of laying down, he says, “Or else, having discerned,” etc.

original: Tattha tīrentoti “uppādo bhayaṃ, anuppādo khema”ntiādinā vīmaṃsanto. Tulento tīrentotiādinā🔽saṅkhepato vuttamatthaṃ vitthārato dassetuṃ “pañcakkhandhā”tiādiṃ vatvā bhavasaṅkhārassa
analyzed: tattha tīrento ti uppādaḥ bhayam anuppādaḥ khemanti ādinā vīmaṃsanto tulento tīrento itiādinā  saṅkhepataḥ vuttam attham vitthārataḥ dassetum pañca kkhandhā ti ādim vatvā bhava saṅkhārassa
translated: Herein, having discerned means having investigated with the thought, “Arising is fearful, non-arising is safe.” Having weighed means having weighed with the thought, “Arising is fearful, non-arising is safe.”🔽In order to show in detail the meaning stated in brief, he says, “The five aggregates,” etc.🔽He shows the manner of laying down the formation of existence in its true nature.

original: avasajjanākāraṃ sarūpato dasseti. Evantiādinā pana udānagāthāvaṇṇanāyaṃ ādito vuttamatthaṃ
analyzed: avasajjana ākāram sarūpataḥ dasseti evam ti ādinā pana udāna gāthā vaṇṇanāyam āditas vuttam attham
translated: In the verse beginning with “Thus,” etc., he shows the meaning stated at the beginning of the exposition of the verses.

original: nigamanavasena dasseti. Abhītabhāvañāpanatthañcāti ayampi attho saṅgahitoti daṭṭhabbaṃ.
analyzed: nigamana vasena dasseti abhīta bhāva ñāpana attham ca iti ayam pi attho saṅgahito ti daṭṭhabbam
translated: and he shows it by way of the conclusion. And the meaning “in order to show that he is not afraid” is also included, it should be understood.

original: Cāpālavaggavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: cāpāla vagga vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The commentary on the Cāpāla chapter is finished.

original: 2. Pāsādakampanavaggo
analyzed: pāsāda kampana vaggo
translated: The Chapter on the Shaking of the Palace

original: 1-2. Pubbasuttādivaṇṇanā
translated: The commentary on the first discourse, etc.

original: 823-824. Parato imasmiṃ pāsādakampanavagge dasamasutte āvi bhavissanti. Chaabhiññāpādakāti
analyzed: paratas imasmin pāsādakampana vagge dasama sutte āvi bhavissanti cha abhiññāpādakā ti
translated: will be given later in the tenth discourse in this chapter on the shaking of the palace.🔽The bases of spiritual success that are the basis for the six kinds of direct knowledge:

original: channaṃ abhiññānaṃ pādakabhūtā padhānabhūtā. Yathā paṭhamasutte, tathā dutiyatatiyasuttesupi
analyzed: channam abhiññānam pādaka bhūtā padhāna bhūtā yathā paṭhama sutte tathā dutiya tatiya suttesu pi
translated: the bases of spiritual success that are the basis, the foundation, for the six kinds of direct knowledge. As in the first discourse, so also in the second and third discourses.

original: ca chaabhiññāpādakā iddhipādā kathitāti attho.
analyzed: ca cha abhiññā pādakā iddhipādā kathitā ati attho
translated: The meaning is that the bases of spiritual success that are the basis for the six kinds of direct knowledge are stated.

original: 3. Chandasamādhisuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: chanda samādhi sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: The Explanation of the Discourse on Concentration Due to Zeal

original: 825. Yo samādhissa nissayabhūto chando, so idhādhippetoti āha “chandanti kattukamyatāchanda”nti.
analyzed: yaḥ samādhissa nissaya bhūto chando saḥ idha adhippeto ti āha chandanti kattu kamya tā chandanti
translated: The zeal that is the support for concentration is intended here, thus he says “zeal” .

original: Tassa ca adhipateyyaṭṭho nissayaṭṭho, na vinā taṃ chandaṃ nissāyāti āha – “nissāyāti
analyzed: tassa ca adhipateyya ṭṭhaḥ nissaya ṭṭhaḥ na vinā tam chandam nissāya ati āha nissāya ati
translated: And the meaning of “predominance” is the meaning of “support,” not without that zeal as support. Thus he says “support” .

original: nissayaṃ katvā, adhipatiṃ katvāti attho”ti. Padhānabhūtāti seṭṭhabhūtā, seṭṭhabhāvo
analyzed: nissayam katvā adhipatim katvā ati attho ti padhāna bhūtā ati seṭṭha bhūtā seṭṭha bhāvaḥ
translated: The meaning is that it is made the support, made the predominant factor. The meaning of “predominance” is the meaning of “best,” “most excellent.”

original: ca ekassapi catukiccasādhanavasena pavattiyā, tato eva bahuvacananiddeso, padhānasaṅkhāraṭṭhena
analyzed: ca ekassa api catu kicca sādhana vasena pavattiyā tatas eva bahuvacana niddeso padhāna saṅkhāra ṭṭhena
translated: It is called “formation of striving” because it is a formation of striving.

original: padhānasaṅkharaṇato. “Chandaṃ ce nissāya…pe… ayaṃ vuccati chandasamādhī”ti imāya
analyzed: padhāna saṅkharaṇataḥ chandam ce ayam vuccati imāya
translated: In the text “When depending on will … this is called concentration due to will”

original: pāḷiyā chandādhipati samādhi chandasamādhīti adhipatisaddalopaṃ katvā samāso vuttoti
analyzed: pāḷiyā chanda adhipati samādhi chanda samādhi iti adhipati sadda lopam katvā samāsaḥ vutto ti
translated: the compound chandasamādhi is stated by dropping the word adhipati, which means “predominant,”

original: viññāyati, adhipatisaddatthadassanavasena vā chandahetuko, chandādhiko vā samādhi🔽chandasamādhi. Tena “chandasamādhinā ceva padhānasaṅkhārehi padhānabhūtasaṅkhārehi
analyzed: viññāyati adhipati saddattha dassana vasena vā chanda hetukaḥ chanda adhikaḥ vā samādhi  tena chanda samādhinā ca iva padhāna saṅkhārehi padhāna bhūta saṅkhārehi
translated: and it is known that the compound is formed in this way. Or alternatively, concentration is due to will, either because it has will as its cause or because will is predominant,🔽so it is concentration due to will. Hence it is said, “Endowed with concentration due to will and with formations of striving that are formations of striving that are predominant” .

original: ca samannāgatā”ti vakkhati, taṃ ānetvā sambandho. Padhānabhūtāti vīriyabhūtā. Keci
analyzed: ca samannāgatā iti vakkhati tam ānetvā sambandhaḥ padhāna bhūtā ati vīriya bhūtā keci
translated: The construction is to be analysed as follows. Formations of striving that are predominant: formations of energy that are predominant.🔽Some say that the word “striving” is used for the purpose of excluding the formations of the formed, etc.

original: vadanti – “saṅkhatasaṅkhārādinivattanatthaṃ padhānaggahaṇa”nti. Atha vā taṃ taṃ visesaṃ
analyzed: vadanti atha vā tam tam visesam
translated: Or alternatively, it is a formation because it forms, makes, each particular thing,

original: saṅkharotīti saṅkhāro, sabbampi vīriyaṃ. Tattha catukiccasādhakato tadaññassa nivattanatthaṃ
analyzed: saṅkharoti iti saṅkhāro sabbam pi vīriyam tattha catu kicca sādhakato tad aññassa nivattana attham
translated: and all energy is that. Herein, it is said to be “formations of striving that are predominant” for the purpose of excluding other energy that does not fulfil the four tasks.

original: padhānaggahaṇanti. Yathā chando chandasamādhinā ceva padhānasaṅkhārehi ca samannāgato,🔽evaṃ chandasamādhi chandena ceva padhānasaṅkhārehi ca samannāgato. Padhānasaṅkhārāpi
analyzed: yathā chando chanda samādhinā ca iva padhāna saṅkhārehi ca samannāgataḥ  evam chandena ca iva padhāna saṅkhārehi ca samannāgataḥ
translated: “The application of energy”: Just as zeal is possessed of concentration due to zeal and of the mental formations consisting in the application of energy,

original: chandena ceva chandasamādhinā ca samannāgatāti tīsupi padesu samannāgatasaddo yojetabbo.🔽Tasmāti yasmā tayopi chandādayo ekacittuppādapariyāpannā, tasmā sabbe te dhammā ekato
analyzed: chandena ca iva chanda samādhinā ca samannāgatā ati tīsu pi padesu samannāgata saddo yojetabbo  tasmā iti yasmā tayo pi chanda ādayo eka cittuppāda pariyāpannā tasmā sabbe te dhammā ekatas
translated: so concentration due to zeal is possessed of zeal and of the mental formations consisting in the application of energy. And the mental formations consisting in the application of energy are possessed of zeal and of concentration due to zeal. So the word “possessed” should be construed in each of the three terms.

original: katvā “ayaṃ vuccati…pe… iddhipādo”ti vuttanti. Evaṃ chandādīnaṃyeva cettha iddhipādabhāvo
analyzed: katvā ayam iddhipādo ti vuttam ti evam chanda ādīnam yeva ca ittha iddhipāda bhāvaḥ
translated: “Therefore”: because all three—zeal, energy, and concentration—are included in a single consciousness-moment, therefore all these states are combined and called “the road to power that is concentration due to zeal and is accompanied by the mental formation of the application of energy.” Thus only zeal, etc., are called “roads to power” here,

original: vutto, vibhaṅge pana tesaṃ iddhibhāvo sampayuttānaṃ iddhipādabhāvo vuttoti dassento🔽“iddhipādavibhaṅge panā”tiādimāha.
analyzed: vuttaḥ vibhaṅge pana tesam iddhi bhāvo sampayuttānam iddhipāda bhāvaḥ vutto ti dassento  iddhi pāda vibhaṅge panāti ādim āha
translated: but in the Vibhaṅga the power is in them and the road to power is in the associated states. Showing this, he says, “But in the analysis of the road to power,” etc.

original: Idāni nesaṃ iddhipādatāpi sambhavatīti dassento “apicā”tiādimāha. Tattha chandañhi
analyzed: idāni na īsam iddhipāda tā api sambhavati iti dassentaḥ api ca iti ādim āha tattha chandan hi
translated: Now, in order to show that they are also roads to power, he says, “Besides, it is said,” etc. Herein,

original: bhāvayato padhānaṃ katvā bhāventassa tathā pavattapubbābhisaṅkhāravasena ijjhamāno🔽chando iddhi nāma, tassa nissayabhūtā padhānasaṅkhārā iddhipādo nāma. Sesadvayepi
analyzed: bhāvayataḥ padhānam katvā bhāventassa tathā pavatta pubba abhisaṅkhāra vasena ijjhamāno  chando iddhi nāma tassa nissaya bhūtā padhāna saṅkhārā iddhipādo nāma sesa dvaye pi
translated: When he develops it by making predominance of desire the condition for the jhāna factors, it succeeds by means of the prior prenascent volition.🔽The desire is called success, and the predominance consisting in the prenascent volition is called the basis for success. So too with the other two.

original: eseva nayo. Tathā bhāvayantassa mukhyatāmattaṃ sandhāya vuttaṃ, ijjhanattho pana
analyzed: esa iva nayaḥ tathā bhāvayantassa mukhya tā mattam sandhāya vuttam ijjha natthaḥ pana
translated: This is said with reference to the pre-eminent state of the desire, etc., in the development. But the meaning of “succeeds” is common to all three.

original: sabbesaṃ samānanti dassento “sampayutta…pe… ijjhantiyevā”ti āha.
analyzed: sabbesam samānanti dassento sampayuttape ijjhantiyā iva āha
translated: To show this he says, “The associated … succeed too” .

original: Iddhipāde asaṅkarato dassetuṃ “apicā”tiādi vuttaṃ. Tattha chandādayoti chandasamādhipadhānasaṅkhārā.🔽Sesiddhipādesūti vīriyiddhipādādīsu. Tattha vīriyasamādhipadhānasaṅkhārasamannāgatoti🔽dvikkhattuṃ vīriyaṃ āgataṃ, tattha purimaṃ samādhivisesaṃ, vīriyādhipatisamādhi eva
analyzed: iddhipāde asaṅkarataḥ dassetum api ca atiādi vuttam tattha chanda ādayaḥ ti chanda samādhi padhāna saṅkhārā  sesa iddhipādesu ti vīriya iddhipāda ādīsu tattha vīriya samādhi padhāna saṅkhāra samannāgataḥ ti  dvi khattum vīriyam āgatam tattha purimam samādhi visesam vīriya adhipati samādhi eva
translated: “And further” is said to show the bases for success without confusion. Herein, desire, etc., are desire, concentration, and the predominance consisting in the volition.🔽In the other bases for success, etc., is in the energy basis for success, etc. Herein, associated with concentration and predominance consisting in the volition is🔽the second occurrence of energy. Herein, the first is a special kind of concentration, namely, concentration dominated by energy.

original: vīriyasamādhīti dutiyaṃ samannāgamaṅgadassanaṃ. Dveyeva hi sabbattha samannāgamaṅgāni
analyzed: vīriya samādhi iti dutiyam samannāgam aṅga dassanam dveyā iva hi sabbattha samannāgam aṅgāni
translated: The second is a faculty of concentration. For there are only two faculties, namely,

original: samādhi padhānasaṅkhāro ca, chandādayo samādhivisesanāni, padhānasaṅkhāro pana padhānavacaneneva
analyzed: ca chanda ādayaḥ samādhi visesanāni padhāna saṅkhāraḥ pana padhāna vacanena iva
translated: and concentration is the effort-factor. The will, etc., are the specific qualities of concentration. But the effort-factor is distinguished by the word “effort” itself,

original: visesito, na chandādīhīti na idha vīriyādhipatitā padhānasaṅkhārassa vuttā hoti.
analyzed: visesitaḥ na chanda ādīhi iti na idha vīriya adhipati tā padhāna saṅkhārassa vuttā hoti
translated: not by the will, etc. So it is not said here that the effort-factor is governed by energy.

original: Vīriyañca samādhiṃ visesetvā ṭhitameva samannāgamaṅgavasena padhānasaṅkhāravacanena
analyzed: vīriyam ca samādhim visesetvā ṭhitam eva samannāgam aṅga vasena padhāna saṅkhāra vacanena
translated: And since concentration is established as distinguished by energy, it is said by the word “effort-factor” as a factor of possession.

original: vuttanti nāpi dvīhi vīriyehi samannāgamo vutto hoti. Yasmā pana chandādīhi visiṭṭho
analyzed: vuttanti na api dvīhi vīriyehi samannāgamaḥ vuttaḥ hoti yasmā pana chanda ādīhi visiṭṭhaḥ
translated: So it is not said that there is possession of two energies. But since concentration is distinguished by the will, etc.,

original: samādhi, tathāpi visiṭṭheneva ca tena sampayutto padhānasaṅkhāro sesadhammā ca, tasmā
analyzed: tathā api visiṭṭhena iva ca tena sampayutto padhāna saṅkhāro sesa dhammā ca tasmā
translated: and is associated with what distinguishes it, namely, the effort-factor and the remaining states,

original: samādhivisesanānaṃ vasena cattāro iddhipādā vuttā, visesanabhāvo ca chandādīnaṃ taṃtaṃavassayadassanavasena
analyzed: samādhi visesanānam vasena cattāro iddhipādāḥ vuttāḥ visesana bhāvaḥ ca chanda ādīnam taṃ taṃ avassaya dassana vasena
translated: it is said that the four bases for success are distinguished by the specific qualities of concentration. And the specific quality of the will, etc., is🔽seen to be their respective predominance.

original: hotīti “chandasamādhi…pe… iddhipādo”ti ettha nissayatthepi pāda-sadde upādāyaṭṭhena
analyzed: hoti iti chanda sama adhipe iddhipādo ti ettha nissaya tthe pi pāda sadde upādāya ṭṭhena
translated: So the word “base” is used here in the sense of a footing in the way stated,

original: chandādīnaṃ iddhipādatā vuttā hoti, teneva abhidhamme uttaracūḷabhājaniye “cattāro🔽iddhipādā chandiddhipādo”tiādinā chandādīnaṃyeva iddhipādatā vuttā, pañhapucchake🔽ca – “cattāro iddhipādā idha bhikkhu chandasamādhī”tiādināva uddesaṃ katvāpi puna🔽chandādīnaṃyeva kusalādibhāvo vibhatto. Upāyiddhipādadassanatthameva hi nissayiddhipādadassanaṃ
analyzed: chanda ādīnam iddhipāda tā vuttā hoti tena iva abhidhamme uttaracūḷabhājaniye cattāro  iddhipādā chandā iddhipādā iti ādinā chanda ādīnam yeva iddhipāda tā vuttā pañha pucchake  ca cattāro iddhipādāḥ idha bhikkhu chanda samādhi iti ādinā no uddesam katvā api puna  kusala ādi bhāvaḥ vibhattaḥ upāya iddhipāda dassana attham eva hi nissaya iddhipāda dassanam
translated: The four bases for success are stated to be will-power, etc., in the Abhidhamma in the Uttaracuda Vagga of the Vibhanga, where it is said: “The four bases for success are the base for success consisting in will-power, etc.” And in the Questions of Milinda, where the four bases for success are stated thus: “Here, a bhikkhu, having gone into the forest, or to the root of a tree, or to an empty place, sits down cross-legged, holding his body erect, and arouses will-power for the purification of unpurified will-power” , etc., the profitable, etc., state of will-power, etc., is also explained. For the purpose of showing the bases for success as means, the bases for success as requisites are shown.

original: kataṃ, aññathā catubbidhatā na hotīti ayamettha pāḷivasena atthavinicchayo. Tattha🔽upāyiddhipādadassanatthamevāti chandādike dhure jeṭṭhake pubbaṅgame katvā nibbattitasamādhi
analyzed: katam aññathā catubbidha tā na hoti iti ayam ettha pāḷi vasena attha vinicchayo tattha  upāyi iddhipāda dassana attham evā ti chanda ādike dhure jeṭṭhake pubbaṅgame katvā nibbattita samādhi
translated: The four bases for success are stated to be will, etc., in the Abhidhamma in the Uttaracuda Vagga of the Vibhanga, where it is said: “The four bases for success are the base for success consisting in will, the base for success consisting in energy, the base for success consisting in citta, the base for success consisting in investigation” . And in the Questions of Milinda, after the four bases for success had been stated in the way beginning, “The four bases for success are: Here, bhikkhus, a bhikkhu wields the various kinds of success that are achieved by concentration of cognizance accompanied by will” , their profitable, etc., nature was again stated thus, “The four bases for success are profitable” , etc. And the demonstration of the bases for success consisting in requisites was given only in order to show the bases for success consisting in method. Otherwise there would be no tetrad. This is the exposition of the meaning according to the texts. Herein,

original: chandādhipatisamādhīti chandādīnaṃ iddhiyā adhigamūpāyadassanaṃ upāyiddhipādadassanaṃ,
analyzed: chanda adhipati samādhi iti chanda ādīnam iddhiyāḥ adhigama upāya dassanam upāya iddhipāda dassanam
translated: only in order to show the bases for success consisting in method: concentration produced by making will, etc., the chief, the foremost, the forerunner, is concentration accompanied by will, concentration accompanied by energy, concentration accompanied by cognizance, and concentration accompanied by investigation. The showing of will, etc., as the method for achieving success is the showing of the bases for success consisting in method.

original: tadatthameva “tathābhūtassa vedanākkhandho…pe… viññāṇakkhandho”ti tattha tattha pāḷiyaṃ
analyzed: tad attham eva tathābhūtassa vedanā kkhandho upe viññāṇa kkhandho ti tattha tattha pāḷiyam
translated: Only in order to show that, the passage in the texts beginning, “In one whose cognizance is thus concentrated, the material form khandha … the feeling khandha … the perception khandha … the determinations khandha … the consciousness khandha” ,

original: nissayiddhipādadassanaṃ kataṃ chandādivisiṭṭhānaṃyeva vedanākkhandhādīnaṃ adhippetattā.
analyzed: nissaya iddhipāda dassanam katam chanda ādi visiṭṭhānam yeva vedanā khandha ādīnam adhippeta ttā
translated: The demonstration of the bases of success as a footing is made in order to show that only the aggregates of feeling, etc., distinguished by will, etc., are intended.

original: Evañcetaṃ sampaṭicchitabbaṃ, aññathā kevalaṃ iddhisampayuttānaṃyeva khandhānaṃ vasena
analyzed: evam ca itam sampaṭicchitabbam aññathā kevalam iddhi sampayuttānam yeva khandhānam vasena
translated: If this is admitted, then, if the bases of success are taken as aggregates associated with success only,

original: iddhipādabhāve gayhamāne tesaṃ catubbidhatā na hoti visesakāraṇabhāvatoti adhippāyo.
analyzed: iddhipāda bhāve gayhamāne tesam catubbidha tā na hoti visesa kāraṇa bhāvato ti adhippāyaḥ
translated: their fourfoldness does not exist, since there is no reason for a distinction. This is the intention.

original: Kecīti uttaravihāravāsino. Anibbattoti hetupaccayehi na nibbatto, na sabhāvadhammo,🔽paññattimattanti adhippāyo. Vādamaddanatthāya hoti, abhidhamme ca āgato uttaracūḷavāroti
analyzed: keci iti uttaravihāra vāsinaḥ anibbattaḥ ti hetu paccayehi na nibbattaḥ na sabhāva dhammo  paññattimattanti adhippāyaḥ vāda maddana atthāya hoti abhidhamme ca āgataḥ uttaracūḷavāraḥ ti
translated: “Some” are the residents of the Northern Monastery. “Not originated” : not originated by causes as conditions, not a natural state,🔽the intention is that it is a mere designation. It is for the purpose of crushing the doctrine of the T⁄rthikas, and it is stated in the Abhidhamma in the Uttaraculvavara.

original: yojanā. Cattāro iddhipādātiādi uttaracūḷavāradassanaṃ. Ime pana uttaracūḷavāre āgatā iddhipādā.
analyzed: yojanā cattāro iddhipādā ati ādi uttaracūḷavāra dassanam ime pana uttaracūḷavāre āgatāḥ iddhipādāḥ
translated: The demonstration of the bases of success as a footing is made in order to show that only the aggregates of feeling, etc., distinguished by will, etc., are intended.

original: Raṭṭhapālatthero chande sati kathaṃ nānujānissantīti sattāhāni bhattāni abhuñjitvā
analyzed: raṭṭhapāla tthero chande sati katham na anujānissanti iti satta ahāni bhattāni a bhuñjitvā
translated: The elder Raṭṭhapāla, thinking, “How can they not allow it when there is will?” did not eat for seven days.

original: mātāpitaro anujānāpetvā pabbajitvā chandameva nissāya arahattaṃ pāpuṇīti āha – “raṭṭhapālatthero
analyzed: mātā pitaraḥ anujānāpetvā pabbajitvā chandam eva nissāya arahattam pāpuṇi iti āha raṭṭhapāla tthero
translated: So it was said: “The Elder Raṭṭhapāla

original: chandaṃ dhuraṃ katvā lokuttaradhammaṃ nibbattesī”ti. Soṇattheroti sukhumālasoṇatthero.
analyzed: chandam dhuram katvā lokuttara dhammam nibbattesi iti soṇa thero ti sukhumālasoṇa tthero
translated: Produced the supramundane state by making zeal predominant.” The Elder Soṇa was the Elder Sukka’s friend.

original: So hi āyasmā attano sukhumālabhāvaṃ acintetvā ativelaṃ caṅkamanena pādesu uṭṭhitesupi
analyzed: saḥ hi sukhumāla bhāvam a cintetvā ativelam caṅkamanena pādesu uṭṭhitesu pi
translated: For this venerable one, while not thinking about his own slenderness, did not relax his effort even when his feet swelled through excessive walking,

original: ussāhaṃ avissajjento vīriyaṃ dhuraṃ katvā lokuttaradhammaṃ nibbattesi. Sambhutatthero
analyzed: ussāham a vissajjentaḥ vīriyam dhuram katvā lokuttara dhammam nibbattesi sambhuta thero
translated: and he produced the supramundane state by making energy predominant. The Elder Sambhūta

original: “cittavato ce alamariyañāṇadassanaviseso ijjheyya, mayhaṃ ijjheyyāti cittaṃ dhuraṃ
analyzed: cittavataḥ ce alam ariya ñāṇa dassana viseso ijjheyya mayham ijjheyya ati cittam dhuram
translated: “If the attainment of the distinction of knowledge and insight were possible for one who is not concentrated, it would be possible for me,🔽since I am concentrated. ” He produced the supramundane state by making consciousness predominant.

original: katvā lokuttaradhammaṃ nibbattesi. Mogharājā “paññavato ce maggabhāvanā ijjheyya,
analyzed: katvā lokuttara dhammam nibbattesi mogha rājā paññavataḥ ce magga bhāvanā ijjheyya
translated: Mogharāja attained Arahantship by making understanding predominant, by making understanding foremost, by making understanding principal, thinking: “If the development of the path were possible for one who is not wise,

original: mayhaṃ ijjheyyā”ti paññāpubbaṅgamaṃ paññādhuraṃ paññājeṭṭhakaṃ katvā arahattaṃ pāpuṇīti
analyzed: mayham ijjheyya ati paññā pubbaṅgamam paññā dhuram paññā jeṭṭhakam katvā arahattam pāpuṇi iti
translated: it would be possible for me, since I am wise.”🔽So it was said: “The Elder Mogharāja

original: āha “mogharājā vīmaṃsaṃ dhuraṃ katvā lokuttaradhammaṃ nibbattesī”ti. Idāni nesaṃ
analyzed: āha mogha rājā vīmaṃsam dhuram katvā lokuttara dhammam nibbattesi iti idāni
translated: Produced the supramundane state by making investigation predominant.” Now, as regards these elders,

original: ariyānaṃ upaṭṭhānussāhamantajātisampadaṃ nissāya rañño santike laddhavisese amaccaputte🔽nidassanabhāvena dassetuṃ “tattha yathā”tiādimāha. Ettha ca punappunaṃ chanduppādanaṃ🔽tosanaṃ viya hotīti chandassa upaṭṭhānasadisatā vuttā, thāmabhāvato ca vīriyassa🔽sūrattasadisatā, cintanappadhānattā cittassa mantasaṃvidhānasadisatā, yonisomanasikāra-sambhūtesu
analyzed: ariyānam upaṭṭhāna ussāham anta jāti sampadam nissāya rañño santike laddha visese amacca putte  nidassana bhāvena dassetum tattha yathā iti ādim āha ettha ca punappunam chanda uppādanam  tosanam viya hoti iti chandassa upaṭṭhāna sadisa tā vuttā thāma bhāvato ca vīriyassa  sūratta sadisa tā cintana ppadhāna ttā cittassa manta saṃvidhāna sadisa tā yoni so manasikāra sambhūtesu
translated: and the son of a minister who had obtained a position in the king’s presence through the excellence of his birth, which was due to the support of the Noble Ones.

original: kusaladhammesu paññā seṭṭhāti vīmaṃsāya jātisampattisadisatā vuttā.
analyzed: kusala dhammesu paññā seṭṭhā ti vīmaṃsāya jāti sampatti sadisa tā vuttā
translated: In order to show them by way of illustration, he said, “Herein, just as … “ Herein, the repeated production of desire is like the pleasing of the king. Thus the similarity of desire to support is stated. And because of its firmness, energy is like the sword. Because of the predominance of reflection, consciousness is like the arrangement of the army. And because of the excellence of the wholesome states that arise through proper attention, understanding is like the excellence of birth of the army.

original: 4. Moggallānasuttavaṇṇanā🔽826. Uddhaccapakatikāti vikkhittasabhāvā, vibbhantacittāti attho. Anavaṭṭhitatāya🔽vipphanditacittatāya vipphandamānacittā. Tucchatāya naḷo viyāti naḷo, māno, uggato
analyzed: moggallāna sutta vaṇṇanā  uddhacca pakatikā ati vikkhitta sabhāvā vibbhanta cittā ati attho anavaṭṭhita tāya  vipphandita citta tāya vipphandamāna cittā tuccha tāya naḷaḥ viyāti naḷaḥ mānaḥ uggataḥ
translated: . Moggallāna Sutta Commentary🔽Restless by nature : of scattered nature; the meaning is, with a distracted mind. Because of their lack of stability,

original: naḷo etesanti unnaḷāti āha – “unnaḷāti…pe… vuttaṃ hotī”ti. Capalāti cāpalyatā nāma
analyzed: naḷaḥ etesan ti unnaḷā iti āha unnaḷā atipe vuttam hoti iti capalā ati cāpalyatā nāma
translated: they are “with minds that are restless, “ because of their minds’ being agitated. They are “like reeds because of their worthlessness. “ “Reeds” is a term for conceit. Those who are conceited are called “reedy” . “ Fickle” : fickleness is a term for

original: lolabhāvo. Murāti kharavacanā, pharusavacanāti attho. Vikiṇṇavācā nāma samphappalāpinoti
analyzed: lola bhāvaḥ murā ati khara vacanā pharusa vacanā ti atthaḥ vikiṇṇa vācāḥ nāma samphappalāpino ti
translated: The state of being greedy. “ Rough” means speaking harsh words, speaking roughly. “ Scattered speech” means one who is a prattler.

original: vuttaṃ “asaṃyatavacanā”tiādi. Paṭipattidhamme pamuṭṭhā vinaṭṭhā paṭivinaṭṭhā sati🔽etesanti muṭṭhasatīti āha – “naṭṭhassatino”ti. Ubbhantacittāti samādhino abhāvena
analyzed: vuttam asaṃyata vacana ati ādi paṭipatti dhamme pamuṭṭhā vinaṭṭhā paṭivinaṭṭhā sati  etesan ti muṭṭha satī iti āha naṭṭha satino ti ubbhanta cittā ati samādhino abhāvena
translated: It is said, “one who speaks without restraint.” “ Forgetful” means those who are confused about the practice of the path, who are destroyed, who are perverted.🔽“ Forgetful” means those who are confused about the practice of the path, who are destroyed, who are perverted.🔽“ Their minds are floating” means that because of the absence of concentration, their minds are floating up and up with restlessness.

original: uddhacceneva uparūpari bhantacittā. Pākatindriyā abhāvitakāyatāya gāmadārakā viya🔽pakatibhūtaindriyā. Nemo vuccati bhūmiyā baddhabhāvanimittapadeso, gambhīro nemo
analyzed: uddhaccena iva pākatindriyāḥ abhāvita kāya tāya  pakati bhūta aindriyāḥ nemaḥ vuccati bhūmiyā baddha bhāva nimitta padesaḥ gambhīraḥ nemaḥ
translated: “ Their faculties are undisciplined” means that because their bodies are undeveloped, their faculties are like those of village boys.🔽“ A stump” is said to be a place where a sign of development is bound to the earth. “ Deep-rooted” means that one who has this is “deep-rooted.”

original: etassāti gambhīranemo. Suṭṭhu nikhātotiādi tassa pādassa suppatiṭṭhitabhāvadassanaṃ.
analyzed: etassa iti gambhīra nemaḥ suṭṭhu nikhātaḥ itiādi tassa pādassa suppatiṭṭhita bhāva dassanaṃ
translated: “ Well-planted” and so on show the well-established nature of that foot.

original: 5. Uṇṇābhabrāhmaṇasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: uṇṇābha brāhmaṇa sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: . Commentary on the Discourse on the Brahmin Uṇṇābha

original: 827. Pahānatthanti anuppādapahānatthaṃ.
analyzed: pahāna attham ti anuppāda pahāna attham
translated: “For the purpose of abandoning” means for the purpose of non-arising abandonment.

original: 9. Iddhādidesanāsuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: iddha ādi desanā sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: . Commentary on the Discourse on the Teaching of Supernatural Power and so on

original: 831. Abhiññāpādakaṃ catutthajjhānaṃ adhippetaṃ “iddhilābhāya pavattatī”ti vacanato.
analyzed: abhiññā pādakam catuttha jhānam adhippetam iddhi lābhāya pavattati iti vacanato
translated: The fourth jhāna, which is the basis for direct knowledge, is intended, because of the statement “it occurs for the attainment of supernatural power.”🔽.

original: 10. Vibhaṅgasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: vibhaṅga sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: 10. The explanation of the Vibhanga Sutta

original: 832. Chandaṃ uppādetvāti bhāvanāchandaṃ uppādetvā. Līnākāroti bhāvanācittassa layāpatti. Kosajjena vokiṇṇāpajjanaṃ vuttaṃ.
analyzed: chandam uppādetvā ati bhāvanā chandam uppādetvā līna ākāraḥ ti bhāvanā cittassa laya āpatti kosajjena vokiṇṇa āpajjanam vuttaṃ
translated: Having aroused zeal: having aroused zeal for development. Slackness: the occurrence of slackness in the mind of development. The word “interruption” is said to mean the occurrence of indolence.

original: Evaṃ pasādābhāvena cittassa vikkhepāpatti, tattha pasāduppādanena yaṃ sampahaṃsanaṃ
analyzed: evam pasāda abhāvena cittassa vikkhepa āpatti tattha pasāda uppādanena yam sampahaṃsanam
translated: Thus the occurrence of distraction in the mind through the absence of confidence is said. The kind of encouragement that is desired there for the arousing of confidence

original: icchitabbaṃ, tassa uppādanākāraṃ dassetuṃ vuttaṃ “so buddhadhammasaṅghaguṇe āvajjetvā”tiādi.
analyzed: icchitabbam tassa uppādana ākāram dassetum vuttam saḥ buddha dhamma saṅgha guṇe āvajjetvā atiādi
translated: is shown by the words “he should advert to the special qualities of the Buddha, the Dhamma, and the Sangha.”

original: Vatthukāme ārabbha vikkhitto punappunaṃ vikkhitto hotiyevāti vuttaṃ “anuvikkhitto”ti.
analyzed: vatthu kāme ārabbha vikkhittaḥ punappunam vikkhittaḥ hoti yeva ati vuttam anuvikkhittaḥ ti
translated: Being distracted again and again with regard to sense desires, he is said to be “continually distracted.”

original: Uppathaṃ paṭipannassa cittassa daṇḍanaṭṭhena niggaṇhanaṭṭhena suttāni eva daṇḍoti
analyzed: uppatham paṭipannassa cittassa daṇḍana ṭhena niggaṇhana ṭṭhena suttāni eva daṇḍoti
translated: The suttas are a rod in the sense of a punishment for the mind that has gone astray.🔽Therefore the words “with the rod of the suttas” mean

original: suttadaṇḍo, tena suttadaṇḍena cittaṃ tajjetvā. Pañcakāmaguṇe ārabbha pavatto cittavikkhepo
analyzed: suttadaṇḍaḥ tena suttadaṇḍena cittam tat jetvā pañca kāmaguṇe ārabbha pavattaḥ citta vikkhepo
translated: having goaded the mind with the rod of the suttas. The distraction of mind that occurs again and again with regard to the five strands of sense pleasure

original: punappunaṃ uppajjatevāti vuttaṃ “anuvikkhitto anuvisaṭo”ti.
analyzed: punappunam uppajjate iva iti vuttam anuvikkhittaḥ anuvisaṭaḥ ti
translated: is said to be “continually distracted, continually dissipated.”

original: Purepacchābhāvo kammaṭṭhānassa manasikāravasena uggahavasena vāti tadubhayaṃ dassetuṃ🔽“katha”ntiādi vuttaṃ. Atilīnādīsu catūsu ṭhānesūti atilīnātipaggahitasaṃkhittaanuvikkhittasaññitesu🔽catūsu ṭhānesu. Tattha bhāvanaṃ anajjhogāhetvāva saṅkoco atilīnatā, ajjhogāhetvā🔽anto saṅkoco saṃkhittatā, antosaṅkhepo atipaggahitatā, accāraddhavīriyatā anuvikkhittatā.🔽Bahiddhā visamavitakkānubhāvanaṃ āpajjanto dvattiṃsākāravasena aṭṭhikasaññāvasena🔽vā gahetabbanti āha – “sarīravasena veditabba”nti. Tenāha “uddhaṃ pādatalā”tiādi.🔽Aññamaññaṃ asaṅkarato ākirīyanti pakārato ṭhapīyantīti ākārā, bhāgāti āha – “yehi
analyzed: purepacchā bhāvaḥ kammaṭṭhānassa manasikāra vasena uggaha vasena vā ati tat ubhayam dassetuṃ  katham tiādi vuttam atilīna ādīsu catūsu ṭhānesu ati līna ati paggahita saṃkhitta anuvikkhitta saññitesu  catūsu ṭhānesu tattha bhāvanam an ajjhogāhetvā ava saṅkocaḥ ati līna tā ajjhogāhetvā  antaḥ saṅkocaḥ saṃkhitta tā antosaṅkhepaḥ ati paggahita tā accāraddha vīriya tā anuvikkhitta tā  bahiddhā visama vitakka anubhāvanam āpajjantaḥ dvattiṃsa ākāra vasena aṭṭhika saññā vasena  vā gahetabbanti āha sarīra vasena veditabbanti tena āha uddham pāda tala ati ādi  aññam aññam asaṅkarataḥ ākirīyanti pakārataḥ ṭhapīyanti iti ākārāḥ bhāgāḥ iti āha
translated: The meaning of the words “before” and “after” is stated in order to show both the prior and subsequent order of the meditation subject.🔽“How?” is said in order to show the prior and subsequent order of the meditation subject by way of attention and by way of learning.🔽In the four instances beginning with “too slack” : in the four instances called “too slack,” “too tense,” “constricted,” and “distracted.”🔽Herein, non-penetration of development is slackness.🔽Penetration of it is tension.🔽The contraction of the mind is constriction.🔽The over-exerted effort is distraction.🔽He should be grasped by means of the thirty-two aspects or by means of the perception of a skeleton.🔽Thus it is said: “It should be known by means of the body.” Therefore it is said: “From the soles of the feet upwards” , etc.🔽The aspects are the parts into which the body is divided by the thirty-two aspects or by the perception of a skeleton. They are called “aspects” because they are arranged in groups by being collected together.🔽

original: niddhāretvā paricchindīyatīti nimittaṃ, upaṭṭhānaṃ. Yo bhikkhūtiādi ālokasaññaṃ yo
analyzed: niddhāretvā paricchindīyati iti nimittam upaṭṭhānam yaḥ bhikkhu uti ādi āloka saññam yaḥ
translated: The sign is the appearance of the sign, the perception of the sign. The establishment is the apprehending and discerning of the sign. The bhikkhu who:🔽

original: uggaṇhāti, taṃ dassanaṃ. Aṅgaṇeti vivaṭaṅgaṇe. Ālokasaññaṃ manasikaroti rattiyaṃ.🔽Vīriyādīsupīti yathā “idha bhikkhu chandaṃ uppādetvā”ti chande vitthāranayo vutto,
analyzed: uggaṇhāti tam dassanam aṅgaṇeti vivaṭaṅgaṇe āloka saññam manasikaroti rattiyam  vīriya ādīsu pi iti yathā idha bhikkhu chandam uppādetvā ti chande vitthāra nayaḥ vutto
translated: The sign is the appearance of the light, the defining of it is the access. The seeing is the apprehending of the light-sign by one who is “a bhikkhu” in the way described under zeal. In a place with an open space: in a place with an open space in it. He gives attention to the sign of light: at night.

original: vīriyādīsupi eso eva vitthāranayo yojetabbo.
analyzed: vīriya ādīsu pi esaḥ eva vitthāra nayaḥ yojetabbo
translated: So too with energy, etc., The method of explanation in the case of zeal should be understood in detail in the same way as in the case of faith.

original: Pāsādakampanavaggavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.🔽3. Ayoguḷavaggo
analyzed: pāsādakampana vagga vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā  ayaḥ guḷa vaggo
translated: The section on the shaking of the palace is ended.🔽The Group of Similes on Fire

original: 2. Ayoguḷasuttavaṇṇanā🔽834. Iminā catumahābhūtamayenāti iminā sabbalokapaccakkhena catūhi mahābhūtehi nibbattena
analyzed: ayoguḷa sutta vaṇṇanā  iminā catu mahābhūta mayena ati iminā sabba loka paccakkhena catūhi mahābhūtehi nibbattena
translated: The Simile of the Lump of Iron

original: catumahābhūtamayena. Manomayo pana nimmitakāyo bhagavato rucivasena paresaṃ paccakkho
analyzed: catu mahābhūta mayena manaḥ mayaḥ pana nimmita kāyaḥ bhagavataḥ ruci vasena paresam paccakkho
translated: With this body made of four great primaries: with this body that is a visible fact to all the world and is made of the four great primaries. But the mind-made body created by one who has attained the divine eye is a visible fact only to the one who creates it.

original: hoti. Omātīti avamāti. Ava-pubbo hi mā-saddo sattiatthopi hotīti “pahoti sakkotī”ti
analyzed: hoti omā atīti avamā ati avapubbaḥ hi mā saddo satti atthaḥ pi hoti iti pahoti sakkoti iti
translated: It is not heavy: it is not ponderous. For the prefix ava- has the sense of down, and the verbal root -mā- has the sense of striking, thus it is said: “It is capable, it is powerful” .

original: attho vutto. Asambhinnapadanti asādhāraṇapadaṃ aññattha anāgatattā. Kāyassa citte
analyzed: atthaḥ vuttaḥ asambhinna padam ti asādhāraṇa padam aññattha anāgata ttā kāyassa citte
translated: The meaning has been stated. The words are not mixed up: the words are not shared in common, because they are not found elsewhere. The body and the mind

original: samodahanaṃ āropanaṃ tannissitatākaraṇañca atthato cittagatiyā pavattanamevāti āha
analyzed: samodahanam āropanam tad nissita tā karaṇam ca atthataḥ citta gatiyā pavattanam eva ati āha
translated: are brought together, are made to coincide, and are made to be in association with each other. In fact, this is the occurrence of the mind’s occurrence. Therefore it is said:

original: “cittagatiyā pesetī”ti.
analyzed: cittagatiyā peseti iti
translated: “He directs the mind to the mind’s occurrence.”

original: Tattha cittagatigamanaṃ nāma cittavasena kāyassa pariṇāmanena “ayaṃ kāyo imaṃ cittaṃ🔽viya hotū”ti kāyassa cittena samānagatikatāṭhapanaṃ. Kathaṃ pana kāyo dandhapavattiko🔽lahupavattinā cittena samānagatiko hotīti? Na sabbathā samānagatiko. Yatheva hi kāyavasena
analyzed: tattha citta gati gamanam nāma citta vasena kāyassa pariṇāmanena ayam kāyaḥ imam cittam  viya hotu uti kāyassa cittena samāna gatika tā ṭhapanam katham pana kāyaḥ dandha pavattikaḥ  lahu pavattinā cittena samāna gatikaḥ hoti iti na sabbathā samāna gatikaḥ yathā iva hi kāya vasena
translated: Herein, the mind’s occurrence is the body’s transformation by means of the mind, the body’s being made to have the same occurrence as the mind by the mind’s being made to occur thus: “Let this body be like this mind.”

original: cittapariṇāmane cittaṃ sabbathā kāyena samānagatikaṃ na hoti. Na hi kadāci taṃ sabhāvasiddhena
analyzed: citta pariṇāmane cittam sabbathā kāyena samāna gatikam na hoti na hi kadāci tam sa bhāva siddhena
translated: But how can the body, which occurs sluggishly, have the same occurrence as the mind, which occurs rapidly? It does not have the same occurrence in every way. For just as, in the transformation of the mind by means of the body, the mind does not have the same occurrence as the body in every way,🔽because it is never able to occur by the means of a material state, which occurs sluggishly, having itself reverted to the mode of existence of that material state,

original: attano khaṇena avattitvā dandhavuttikassa rūpadhammassa vasena pavattituṃ sakkoti,
analyzed: attano khaṇena avattitvā dandhavuttikassa rūpa dhammassa vasena pavattitum sakkoti
translated: which exists by its own individual essence,

original: “idaṃ cittaṃ ayaṃ kāyo viya hotū”ti pana adhiṭṭhānena dandhagatikassa kāyassa anuvattanato🔽yāva icchitaṭṭhānappatti, tāva kāyagatianulomeneva hutvā santānavasena pavattamānaṃ
analyzed: idam cittam ayam kāyaḥ viya hotu uti pana adhiṭṭhānena dandha gatikassa kāyassa anuvattanato  yāva icchita ṭṭhāna ppatti kāya gati anulomena iva hutvā santāna vasena pavattamānam
translated: But when he resolves, “Let my mind be like my body, let my body be like my mind,” then the mind, which occurs in continuity, is called “turned into the body’s movement” in the sense that it follows the slow movement of the body until it reaches the place wanted.

original: cittaṃ kāyagatiyā pariṇāmitaṃ nāma hoti. Evaṃ “ayaṃ kāyo idaṃ cittaṃ viya hotū”ti🔽adhiṭṭhānena pageva sukhalahusaññāya sampāditattā abhāvitiddhipādānaṃ viya dandhaṃ
analyzed: cittam kāya gatiyā pariṇāmitam nāma hoti evam ayam kāyaḥ idam cittam viya hotu uti  adhiṭṭhānena pagā iva sukha lahu saññāya sampādita ttā abhāvita iddhipādānam viya dandham
translated: And when he resolves, “Let my body be like my mind,” then the body, which is called “turned into the movement of the mind” in the sense that it reaches the place wanted with the swiftness of thought, occurs in such wise that it reaches the place wanted with the swiftness of thought, not in a single thought-moment, but in a continuity of thought-moments,🔽because it is turned more slowly than the bases of success, like the earth-based success of the ploughman.🔽And this is done because he has already effected the perception of lightness.

original: avattitvā yathā lahukaṃ katipayacittavāreneva icchitaṭṭhānappatti hoti, evaṃ pavattamāno🔽kāyo cittagatiyā pariṇāmito nāma hoti, na ekacittakkhaṇeneva icchitaṭṭhānappattiyā,🔽evañca katvā bāhāsamiñjanapasāraṇūpamāpi upacārena vinā suṭṭhutaraṃ yuttā hotīti.
analyzed: avattitvā yathā lahukam katipaya cittavārena iva icchita ṭṭhāna ppatti hoti evam pavattamānaḥ  kāyaḥ citta gatiyā pariṇāmitaḥ nāma hoti na eka citta kkhaṇena iva icchita ṭṭhāna ppattiyā  evañca katvā bāhā samiñjana pasāraṇa upamā api upacārena vinā suṭṭhutaram yuttā hoti iti
translated: And this is better in detail than the simile of the bending and stretching of the arm, which is only a rough one.

original: Aññathā dhammatāvilomatā siyā, nāpi dhammānaṃ lakkhaṇaññathattaṃ iddhibalena kātuṃ
analyzed: aññathā dhamma tā viloma tā siyā nā api dhammānam lakkhaṇa aññathattam iddhi balena kātum
translated: Otherwise there would be a contradiction of the true natural order. Nor can the specific characteristics of states be made otherwise by the power of supernormal power.

original: sakkā, bhāvaññathattameva pana kātuṃ sakkāti.
analyzed: sakkā bhāvaññathattam eva pana kātum sakkā iti
translated: It can be done, but only by a change of state.

original: 3-10. Bhikkhusuttādivaṇṇanā
analyzed: bhikkhu sutta ādi vaṇṇanā
translated: Commentary on the Bhikkhu Sutta, etc.

original: 835-842. “Dvinnaṃ phalāna”nti āgatasuttaṃ sandhāya “dve phalāni ādiṃ katvā”ti vuttaṃ. Sesaṃ suviññeyyameva.
analyzed: dvinnam phalānam ti āgata suttam sandhāya dve phalāni ādim katvā iti vuttam sesam su viññeyyam eva
translated: The words “starting with the two fruits” are said in reference to the sutta that has the words “two fruits” at the beginning. The rest is easy to understand.

original: Ayoguḷavaggavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: ayoguḷa vagga vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The commentary on the Ayoguḷa Vagga is finished.

original: Iddhipādasaṃyuttavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: iddhipāda saṃyutta vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The commentary on the Iddhipada Samyutta is finished.

original: 8. Anuruddhasaṃyuttaṃ
analyzed: anuruddha saṃyuttam
translated: The Connected Discourses with Anuruddha

original: 1. Rahogatavaggo
analyzed: rahas gata vaggo
translated: The Section on Seclusion

original: 1-2. Paṭhamarahogatasuttādivaṇṇanā
analyzed: paṭhama rahogata sutta ādi vaṇṇanā
translated: Commentary on the First Seclusion Sutta, etc.

original: 899-900. Chattiṃsāya ṭhānesūti ajjhattaṃ kāye samudayadhammānupassī, vayo, samudayavayo,
analyzed: chattiṃsāya ṭhānesu uti ajjhattam kāye samudaya dhamma anupassī vayo samudaya vayo
translated: In thirty-six instances: contemplating in oneself the rise of the body, the fall, the rise and fall,

original: bahiddhā samudayo, vayo, samudayavayo, ajjhattabahiddhā samudayo, vayo, samudayavayadhammānupassīti
analyzed: bahiddhā samudayaḥ vayaḥ samudaya vayaḥ ajjhatta bahiddhā samudayaḥ vayaḥ samudaya vaya dhamma anupassī iti
translated: the rise externally, the fall, the rise and fall, the rise and fall internally and externally,

original: nava anupassanā, tathā vedanāya citte dhammesūti evaṃ chattiṃsāya ṭhānesu. Dutiye🔽dvādasasu ṭhānesūti kāye ajjhattaṃ bahiddhā ajjhattabahiddhā, vedanāya citte dhammesūti
analyzed: nava anupassanā tathā vedanāya citte dhammesu uti evam chattiṃsāya ṭhānesu dutiye  dvādasasu ṭhānesu uti kāye ajjhattam bahiddhā ajjhatta bahiddhā vedanāya citte dhammesu uti
translated: contemplating the rise and fall of the body, and likewise in the case of feeling, consciousness, and mental objects.🔽In the second sutta

original: evaṃ dvādasasu ṭhānesu.
analyzed: evam dvādasasu ṭhānesu
translated: in twelve instances: in oneself, externally, and internally and externally, in the case of the body, and likewise in the case of feeling, consciousness, and mental objects.

original: 3. Sutanusuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: sutanu sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: 3. Commentary on the Sutta on the Good Person

original: 901. Imāya pāḷiyāti imāya hīnattikapāḷiyā. Ime dhammā hīnā lāmakaṭṭhena. Ime dhammā majjhimā hīnapaṇītānaṃ majjhe bhavāti. Uttamaṭṭhena attappakaṭṭhena padhānabhāvaṃ nītāti paṇītā.
analyzed: imāya pāḷiyā ati imāya hīnattika pāḷiyā ime dhammā hīnāḥ lāmaka ṭṭhena ime dhammāḥ majjhimāḥ hīna paṇītānam majjhe bhavāti uttama aṭṭhena attappaka ṭṭhena padhāna bhāvam nītā ati paṇītā
translated: “These things are inferior” : these things are inferior in the sense of being low. “These things are middling” : they are middling between the inferior and the superior. “These things are superior” : they are superior in the sense of being excellent and in the sense of being the culmination of development.

original: 4-7. Paṭhamakaṇḍakīsuttādivaṇṇanā🔽902-905. Kaṇḍakā etissā atthīti kaṇḍakī, karamandagaccho. Osadhibhāvāpekkhāya itthiliṅganiddeso,
analyzed: kaṇḍakā etissā atthi iti kaṇḍakī osadhi bhāva apekkhāya itthi liṅga niddeso
translated: . Commentary on the First Discourse on the Thorn-Apple Tree, etc.🔽“Thorn-apple” : it has thorns, i.e., the fruit of the karamardaka tree. The feminine gender is used in the description because of the expectation of the feminine gender in the word for “herb” .

original: tabbahulatāya taṃ vanaṃ “kaṇḍakīvana”nteva paññāyittha. Sahassalokanti sahassacakkavāḷalokaṃ.
analyzed: tad bahu latāya tam vanam kaṇḍakī vana ntā iva paññāyittha sahassa lokam ti sahassa cakkavāḷa lokam
translated: Because of the abundance of thorn-apple trees, the forest was known as “the thorn-apple forest.” “The world of a thousand worlds” : the world of a great chiliocosm.

original: Dasacakkavāḷasahassaṃ ekāvajjanassa āpāthaṃ āgacchati tathā ālokavaḍḍhanassa katattā.
analyzed: dasa cakkavāḷa sahassam ekāvajjanassa āpātham āgacchati tathā āloka vaḍḍhanassa kata ttā
translated: A great chiliocosm comes within the range of a single thought-unit of the Buddha, because the range of his vision has been extended to that extent.

original: 9. Ambapālivanasuttavaṇṇanā
translated: . Commentary on the Sutta on the Mango Grove

original: 907. Arahattabhāvadīpakanti arahattassa atthibhāvadīpakaṃ. “Arahattabhāvadīpika”nti vā pāṭho.
analyzed: arahatta bhāva dīpakanti arahattassa atthi bhāva dīpakam arahatta bhāva dīpikam ti vā pāṭhaḥ
translated: “Illuminating the state of arahantship” : illuminating the existence of arahantship. The reading “arahantbhāvadīpikā” is also allowable.

original: Rahogatavaggavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: rahogata vagga vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The commentary on the “In Private” chapter is finished.

original: 2. Dutiyavaggavaṇṇanā
analyzed: dutiya vagga vaṇṇanā
translated: . Commentary on the Second Chapter

original: 909-922. Dasabalañāṇanti dasavidhabalañāṇaṃ. Ekadesenāti padesavasena. Sāvakānampi
analyzed: dasa bala ñāṇam ti dasavidha bala ñāṇam eka desena ati padesa vasena sāvakānam pi
translated: The knowledge of the ten powers is the ten kinds of knowledge of the powers . By a part : by a portion .

original: attano abhinīhārānurūpaṃ ñāṇaṃ pavattatīti te kālapadesavasena ceva yathāparicayasattapadesavasena
analyzed: attanaḥ abhinīhāra anurūpam ñāṇam pavattati iti te kāla padesa vasena ca iva yathā paricaya satta padesa vasena
translated: The knowledge of disciples also occurs in accordance with their own aspiration. Therefore they know the places by the time and by the portion as they have learned them.

original: ca ṭhānānīti jānanti, sammāsambuddhānaṃ pana anantañāṇatāya sabbattheva appaṭihatameva
analyzed: ca ṭhānāni iti jānanti sammāsambuddhānam pana ananta ñāṇa tāya sabbattha iva a paṭihatam eva
translated: But because the knowledge of the Perfectly Enlightened Ones is infinite, their knowledge is unobstructed in all cases.

original: ñāṇanti āha – “sabbaññubuddhānaṃ panā”tiādi. Etaṃ dasabalañāṇaṃ anantavisayattā nippadesaṃ
analyzed: ñāṇam ti āha sabbaññu buddhānam pana atiādi etam dasa bala ñāṇam ananta visaya ttā nippadesam
translated: Therefore it is said: “But in the case of the omniscient Buddhas” , etc. This knowledge of the ten powers, because its domain is infinite, is without a portion ;

original: anūnatāya sabbākāraparipūraṃ.
analyzed: anūna tāya sabba ākāra paripūram
translated: because it is not deficient, it is fulfilled in all its aspects.

original: Dutiyavaggavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: dutiya vagga vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The commentary on the second sub-chapter is finished.

original: Anuruddhasaṃyuttavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: anuruddha saṃyutta vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The commentary on the Connected Discourses with Anuruddha is finished.

original: 9. Jhānasaṃyuttavaṇṇanā
translated: The Connected Discourses with Jhāna

original: 923. Jhānasaṃyuttaṃ suviññeyyameva, missakanti vadanti.
analyzed: jhāna saṃyuttam su viññeyyam eva missakanti vadanti
translated: The Connected Discourses with Jhāna are easy to understand. They are called “mixed” .

original: Jhānasaṃyuttavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: jhāna saṃyutta vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The commentary on the Connected Discourses with Jhāna is finished.

original: 10. Ānāpānasaṃyuttaṃ🔽1. Ekadhammavaggo
analyzed: āna apāna saṃyuttam  eka dhamma vaggaḥ
translated: The Connected Discourses with Ānāpānasati🔽The chapter on one thing

original: 1. Ekadhammasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: ekadhamma sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: The explanation of the discourse on one thing

original: 977. Etthāti etasmiṃ paṭhamasutte. Vuttameva, tasmā tattha vuttanayeneva veditabbanti adhippāyo.
analyzed: ettha iti etasmin paṭhama sutte vuttam eva tasmā tattha vutta nayena iva veditabbanti adhippāyaḥ
translated: Herein, in this first sutta: what has been said there should be understood in the way already stated. This is the purport.

original: 6. Ariṭṭhasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: ariṭṭha sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: The Commentary on the Ariṭṭha Sutta

original: 982. No-saddo pucchāyaṃ, tasmā nūti iminā samānatthoti āha “bhāvetha nū”ti. Kāmacchandoti
analyzed: no saddo puccha ayam tasmā nu iti iminā samāna atthaḥ ti āha bhāvetha nu iti kāmacchandaḥ iti
translated: The word no is a particle of interrogation, and so it has the same meaning as the word nu in the phrase bhāvetha nū ti.🔽The word desire for sense desires is a term for craving for the five strands of sense pleasure.

original: vatthukāmesu icchāti āha “pañcakāmaguṇikarāgo”ti. Dvādasasu āyatanadhammesu saparasantatipariyāpannesu.🔽Iminā kāmacchandappahānakittanena paṭighasaññāpaṭivinayakittanena ca anāgāmimaggaṃ🔽katheti pañcorambhāgiyasaññojanasamucchedassa byākatattā. Vipassanaṃ dassentoti “vipassanaṃ
analyzed: vatthu kāmesu icchā ati āha dvādasasu āyatana dhammesu sa para santati pariyāpannesu  iminā kāma chanda ppahāna kittanena paṭigha saññā paṭivinaya kittanena ca anāgāmi maggam  kathā iti pañcorambhāgiya saññojana samucchedassa byākata ttā vipassanam dassento ti vipassanam
translated: The word in the twelve bases and in the things of one’s own and other continuums.🔽By this praise of the abandoning of desire for sense desires and by the praise of the removal of perception of resistance, he shows the non-return path.

original: anuyuñjathā”ti dassento.
analyzed: anuyuñjatha iti
translated: By the statement “you should develop the perception of the unattractiveness of the body” he shows insight.

original: 8. Padīpopamasuttavaṇṇanā
translated: The Commentary on the Simile of the Lamp

original: 984. “Neva kāyopi kilamati na cakkhūnī”ti aṭṭhakathāyaṃ paduddhāro kato. “Kāyopi
analyzed: na iva kāyaḥ api kilamati na cakkhūni iti aṭṭhakathā ayam paduddhāro kato kāyopi
translated: In the commentary to the sutta it is said: “Neither the body nor the eyes tire.”

original: kilamati, cakkhūnipi vihaññantī”ti vatvā yattha yathā hoti, tāni dassetuṃ “dhātukammaṭṭhānasmiṃ🔽hī”tiādi vuttaṃ. Cakkhūni phandanti kilamantītiādi ativelaṃ upanijjhāyane hotīti🔽katvā vuttaṃ. Imasmiṃ pana kammaṭṭhāneti ānāpānakammaṭṭhāne. Evamāhāti “bhikkhu cepi🔽ākaṅkheyya, neva kāyo kilameyyā”ti evamāha.
analyzed: kilamati cakkhūni pi vihaññanti iti vatvā yattha yathā hoti tāni dassetum dhātu kammaṭṭhānasmiṃ  hi itiādi vuttam cakkhūni phandanti kilamanti itiādi ativelam upanijjhāyane hoti iti  katvā vuttam imasmin pana kammaṭṭhāne ti āna apāna kammaṭṭhāne evam āha ati bhikkhu ce pi  ākaṅkheyya na iva kāyaḥ kilameyya iti evam āha
translated: and the eyes are fatigued. ” After saying this, in order to show how this comes about, he said, “In the case of the meditation subject of the elements … ”🔽The eyes water and are fatigued, etc., are said because of over-strenuous application.🔽In this meditation subject: in the meditation subject of breathing.🔽Thus spoke: if a bhikkhu should wish, his body would not be fatigued, etc.🔽

original: Labbhatīti aṭṭhakathādhippāye ṭhatvā vuttaṃ, parato āgatena theravādena so anicchito.🔽Na hi tārakarūpamuttāvaḷikādisadisaṃ nimittūpaṭṭhānākāramattaṃ khaṇamattaṭṭhāyinaṃ🔽kasiṇanimittesu viya ugghāṭanaṃ kātuṃ sakkoti. Tenāha “na labbhatevā”ti. Ānisaṃsadassanatthaṃ🔽gahito, ānāpānassatisamādhismiṃ siddhe ayaṃ guṇo sukheneva ijjhatīti. Yasmā bhikkhūti
analyzed: labbhati iti aṭṭhakathā adhippāye ṭhatvā vuttam paratas āgatena thera vādena saḥ anicchitaḥ 🔽na hi tāraka rūpa muttā vaḷikā ādi sadisam nimitta upaṭṭhāna ākāra mattam khaṇa matta ṭṭhāyinam 🔽kasiṇa nimittesu viya ugghāṭanam kātum sakkoti tena āha na labbhateva iti ānisaṃsa dassana attham 🔽gahitaḥ āna apāna sati samādhismim siddhe ayam guṇo sukhena iva ijjhati iti yasmai bhikkhu iti
translated: and the eyes are fatigued. ” After saying this, in order to show how this comes about, he said, “In the case of the meditation subject of the elements … ” . The eyes water and are fatigued, etc., are said because of over-insistence on gazing. In this meditation subject : in the meditation subject of mindfulness of breathing. He said thus : he said: “If a bhikkhu should wish: ‘Let neither my body nor my eyes be fatigued’ … ” . He can : this is said with reference to the intention of the commentary. The view of the Theravada is not accepted here. For it is not possible to remove the sign of the in-breaths and out-breaths, which is merely the mode of appearance of the object, which is like the pattern of a garland of stars, etc., and which lasts only a moment, as one removes the kasiṇa materiality. That is why it is said, “He cannot remove it. ” It is taken for the purpose of showing the advantage, since this quality is easily accomplished when concentration by mindfulness of breathing is accomplished. If a bhikkhu :

original: imasmiṃ vāre nāgatanti yathā purimavāre “bhikkhu cepi ākaṅkheyyā”ti āgataṃ, evaṃ
analyzed: imasmin vāre yathā purima vāre bhikkhu ce pi ākaṅkheyya ati āgatam evam
translated: In this section, “if a bhikkhu should wish” is not stated as it was in the previous section.

original: idha “bhāvite kho, bhikkhave, ānāpānassatisamādhimhī”ti āgatavāre bhikkhuggahaṇamakataṃ,
analyzed: idha bhāvite kho bhikkhave āna apāna sati samādhimhi iti āgata vāre bhikkhu ggahaṇam akatam
translated: In the section that begins, “Bhikkhus, when concentration by mindfulness of breathing is developed and made much of,” the word “bhikkhu” is not mentioned.

original: tasmā “so”ti na vuttaṃ.
analyzed: tasmā saḥ iti na vuttam
translated: Therefore the word “he” is not used.

original: 9. Vesālīsuttavaṇṇanā🔽985. Pākāraparikkhepavaḍḍhanenāti pākāraparikkhepena bhūmiyā vaḍḍhanena. Rājagahasāvatthiyo
analyzed: vesālī sutta vaṇṇanā  pākāra parikkhepa vaḍḍhanena ati pākāra parikkhepena bhūmiyāḥ vaḍḍhanena rājagaha sāvatthiyaḥ
translated: Commentary on the Discourse on Vesali

original: viya idampi ca nagaraṃ…pe… sabbākāravepullataṃ pattaṃ. Anekapariyāyenāti ettha pariyāyasaddo🔽kāraṇavacanoti āha “anekehi kāraṇehī”ti, ayaṃ kāyo aviññāṇakopi saviññāṇakopi evampi
analyzed: viya idam pi ca nagaraṃpe sabba ākāra vepulla tam pattam aneka pariyāyena āti ettha pariyāya saddaḥ  kāraṇa vacanaḥ iti āha anekehi kāraṇehi iti ayam kāyaḥ aviññāṇakaḥ api sa viññāṇakaḥ api evam pi
translated: By the extension of the rampart’s perimeter: by the extension of the earth by the extension of the rampart’s perimeter. Like Rajagaha and Savatthi, this city too… reached the fullness of prosperity in every respect. By many a method: here the word “method”

original: asubho evampi asubhoti nānāvidhehi kāraṇehīti attho. Asubhākārasandassanappavattanti
analyzed: asubhaḥ evam pi asubhaḥ ti nānāvidhehi kāraṇehi iti atthaḥ asubha ākāra sandassana ppavattanti
translated: means a reason. Therefore it is said: “by many a reason.” This body, whether it is without consciousness or with consciousness, is thus impure, thus foul. The meaning is: by various reasons. The discourse that leads to the turning away of the mind from the body:

original: kesādivasena tatthāpi vaṇṇādito asubhākārassa sabbaso dassanavasena pavattaṃ. Kāyavicchandanīyakathanti
analyzed: kesa ādi vasena tattha api vaṇṇa āditaḥ asubha ākārassa sabbasas dassana vasena pavattam kāya vicchandanīya kathanti
translated: the discourse that leads to the turning away of the mind from the body by showing the various aspects of foulness such as the hair of the head, etc., by the complete demonstration of the aspects of foulness such as colour, etc., in the body.

original: attano parassa ca karajakāye vicchandanuppādanakathaṃ. Muttaṃ vātiādinā byatirekamukhena
analyzed: attano parassa ca karaja kāye vicchanda nuppādana katham muttam vāti ādinā byatireka mukhena
translated: The discourse on the production of desire and lust in one’s own and another’s physical body. “The body is a thing unclean” :🔽he shows the body’s unallowableness by way of a superlative.

original: kāyassa amanuññataṃ dasseti. Tattha ādito tīhi padehi adassanīyatāya asārakatāya
analyzed: kāyassa amanuñña tam dasseti tattha āditaḥ tīhi padehi a dassanīya tāya asāraka tāya
translated: Therein, by the first three terms he shows its unallowableness by way of its being invisible and its being insubstantial;

original: ca, majjhe catūhi duggandhatāya, ante ekena lesamattenapi manuññatābhāvamassa dasseti.
analyzed: ca majjhe catūhi duggandha tāya ante ekena lesa mattena api manuñña tā bhāvam assa dasseti
translated: by the middle four terms, by way of its foul smell; and by the last term, by way of its being allowed even as a mere ulcer.

original: Atha khotiādinā anvayato sarūpeneva amanuññatāya dassanaṃ. “Kesalomādī”ti saṅkhepato
analyzed: atha kho ti ādinā anvayato sarūpena iva amanuñña tāya dassanam kesa loma ādi iti saṅkhepato
translated: “And then” : he shows its unallowableness by way of its nature itself. “Hair of the head, etc.” :

original: vuttamatthaṃ vibhāgena dassetuṃ “yepī”tiādi vuttaṃ.
analyzed: vuttam attham vibhāgena dassetum ye pi itiādi vuttam
translated: he says “and so on” in order to show by analysis the meaning stated in brief.

original: Vaṇṇentoti vitthārento. Asubhāyāti asubhamātikāya. Phātikammanti bahulīkāro. Kilesacorehi anabhibhavanīyattā jhānaṃ “cittamañjūsa”nti vuttaṃ. Nissāyāti pādakaṃ katvā.
analyzed: vaṇṇento ti vitthārento asubhāya ati asubha mātikāya phāti kammanti bahulīkāro kilesa corehi an abhibhavanīya ttā jhānam citta mañjūsanti vuttam nissāya ati pādakam katvā
translated: “Describing” : expounding. “The meditation subject of foulness” : the meditation subject of the thirty-two-fold aspect of foulness. “Practice” : repetition. “The mind’s treasure-store” : the jhāna is called the mind’s treasure-store because it is not to be overcome by the thieves of defilements. “Having made that the basis” : having made it the support.

original: Apare pana “tasmiṃ kira addhamāse na koci buddhaveneyyo ahosi, tasmā bhagavā evamāha
analyzed: apare pana tasmin kira addha māse na koci buddha veneyyaḥ ahosi tasmai bhagavā evam āha
translated: But it is said that during that fortnight there was no one to be developed by the Buddha, and that is why the Blessed One said this.

original: – ‘icchāmahaṃ, bhikkhave’tiādī”ti vadanti. Pare kirāti kira-saddo arucisaṃsūcanattho.
analyzed: icchāmaham bhikkhave tiādi iti vadanti pare kira ati kira saddaḥ aruci saṃsūcana atthaḥ
translated: The word “they say” is a sign of displeasure.

original: Tenāha “idaṃ pana icchāmatta”nti.
analyzed: tena āha idam pana
translated: That is why he said, “But this is just a wish” .

original: Anekakāraṇasammissoti ettha kāraṇaṃ nāma kāyassa asuciduggandhajegucchapaṭikūlatāva.🔽Sabbamakaṃsūti puthujjanā nāma sāvajjepi tattha anavajjasaññino hutvā karaṇakārāpanasamanuññatābhedaṃ
analyzed: aneka kāraṇa sammissaḥ ti ettha kāraṇam nāma kāyassa asuci duggandha jeguccha paṭikūla tā vat  puthujjanāḥ nāma sāvajje pi tattha anavajja saññinaḥ hutvā karaṇa kārāpana samanuñña tā bhedam
translated: “With many reasons mixed up” : the reasons are the foulness, stench, and repulsiveness of the body.🔽“All the evil”: ordinary people, thinking that what is blameworthy is not so,🔽have done all the evil that is of the kinds of action, of causing others to act, and of consenting to action.

original: sabbaṃ pāpaṃ akaṃsu. Kāmaṃ dasānussatiggahaṇeneva ānāpānassati gahitā, sā pana tattha
analyzed: sabbam pāpam kāmam dasa anussati gahaṇena iva ānāpāna ssati gahitā sā pana tattha
